reviewText:
PRAISE THE SUN!

If only I could be so grossly incandescent!

Jolly co-operation!

^^These quotes will be part of your life forever.

The Demon's Souls and Dark Souls games are my favorite series this gen. They changed the way I look at ARPGs with the fantastic combat and the open worlds you can play within. The combat is just amazing with every weapon having different mechanics and animations so you can try tons of different styles of  gameplay from big swords to daggers to dual wielding to being a pokey turtle with a spear and giant shield.  Not just melee, but Pyromancy, Sorcery, and Miracles are available too with their wands and gloves and can all be used by every player if your skills are good enough. Don't forget to use the items too for some fun ways of attackign enemies like poison arrows and darts.

This game is an RPG with a story that isn't spoon fed to you. This series tells a story through item descriptions and other obscure places. It is a world of lore that is found through reading items and very few cutscenes. You awaken in this world and everyone is just as crazy as you will feel.

You upgrade your levels by collecting souls to increase your attributes, which allow you to wield more weapons and cast different magics. STamina is important. Very important. Don't skimp on it.

This series introduced a fascinating online mechanic. While I like the messages and the blood stains more in Demon's Souls, Dark Souls still has them. Messages can be left from other players that can either help, or trick you into a death. These are all pre-written messages and you choose from a list for obvious reasons. Blood stains allow you to view how other explorers have died! Sometimes these are hilarious.

The big online aspect , however is the PvP and the co-op it provides. If you have used Humanity to get into human form you can be INVADED by other players on the server at any time as long as you have not killed the area boss. XXXXXX Has Invaded ....." starts the heart pumping immediately as you play cat and mouse while you search each other out. Ultimately one of you finds the other with a sneak attack
date:
or you just make a friendly bow and start to circle each other for a one on one fight to the death! You can even have summoned phantoms help you out if you find their summon signs first to fell these invaders.

The Co-op aspect works like the messages where summon signs are placed upon the ground and you can summon Blue Phantoms (other players) to help you through the area and ultimately defeat the boss.

Dark Souls also introduced Covenants
recommended: which allow you to join mysterious groups within the world. Each group has different benefits for members. They will put you in a bullseye for more invaders
hoursPlayed: allow you to team up easier for co-op with friendly players

Dark Souls™: Prepare To Spend 3 Hours Modding And Troubleshooting Errors To Make It A Decent Port™ Edition

But after that, this game is delicious. It feels like the developers have been isolated from society for several years while making this game, and never had any idea of the standards that have been set in modern game development.
The standards where button mashing is always a legitimate option, where the player's hand is held with constant instruction and navigational aid (even to the point where games play themselves), where there is no consequence for dying.

This game is oblivious to all of that. The combat is extremely satisfying; complex and risky, without being overly convoluted. Button mashing WILL get you killed right away. Every weapon has its own moveset, handling, and attributes. You will die a lot. Success comes from learning the mechanics, attack animations, enemy AI, physics, and reasons behind your mistakes.

It becomes the most fun thing ever and oh mah gawwwwd the boss designs are wicked intense, and environments are gorgeous and seamlessly intertwined. It's an open world where you can get lost and discover places early"

reviewText:
This is the game guys.
Along with its predecessor Demon's Souls this game has become my favorite game of all time and even rivals games like The Legend of Zelda, Metroid, Metal Gear Solid, Okami and Mass Effect. Games that I hold dearly in my heart because they are special to me.

If you have played Demon's Souls you will feel right at home. Like Demon's Souls, Dark Souls is an incredibly rewarding game.
The story and lore is fascinating and deep even though the game is not very good at telling you these things.

The combat in this game is top notch and the vast amount of unique weapons, armour and spells give you plenty opportunities to experiment with them and pick the one you like the most.

I wouldn't say that Dark Souls is a hard game. It just doesn't hold your hand like most games do today and I think it is a nice nod to the unforgiving NES/SNES era. The difficulty of this game lies in the skill of the player. Also to get the best experience out of this game. Play this game with no guide or anything whatsoever.

Now you may ask yourself, does this games have flaws? Yes, it does. The PC version has a large amount of framedrops (You will especially notice this if you have played the console version too), online matchmaking could be done better and a controller is almost required to play this game smoothly.

But do these flaws stop me from enjoying this game? HELL NO!

I say go get this game if you want a deep action RPG/dungeon crawler that will entertain you for hours.




Praise The Sun, Sunbros!!  \o/

reviewText:
It's certainly novel for a game's subtitle to boast of your impending slaughter, but Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition is unusual in most respects. Its combat is abnormally precise, its narrative is largely embedded within optional NPC interactions, and its multiplayer features are unconventional and initially largely hidden. While the PC version is a shabby port, there is simply no other action RPG out there like Dark Souls, which is so good that it adversely affected my opinion of how all previous RPGs handled combat.

However, I must start out with a warning: the PC port is a disappointing wasted opportunity to technically improve on the console version of Dark Souls, and it lacks many features you probably expect as standard. The resolution is locked at 1280x720 (aka 720p), the framerate is locked at 30fps, and there are no high resolution textures. There's a mouse & keyboard control option, but control is so bad that it's not practical, so you'll definitely want a gamepad to play. Fortunately, there's a must-have unofficial patch available that improves the rendering resolution. With it, everything looks much crisper, although you're stuck with low-resolution textures.

That said, Dark Souls is still an amazing game. There's no hand-holding - to succeed, you need to invest time diligently exploring, learning the combat system, and developing your skills to overcome challenges. The open-world design makes it likely that you'll wander into high-level areas that'll mercilessly slap some perspective into your character. It's a tough, but fair experience. Deaths aren't cheap, but success needs to be well earned.

Dark Souls – likes it predecessor – is a third-person dungeon crawl at its core. In the almost overbearingly gloomy realm of Lordran, a sizeable open-world that you’ll explore high and low, threats loom just about anywhere you look. From a few established hubs in the world, you’ll expand outward, constantly facing adversity in the endless gnarled faces of ever-dangerous creatures that stand between you and ending the calamotous period called the Age of Fire…or, if the tone of the world sucks you under, to usher in a different calamity entirely. The game’s plot is purposely minimalistic and tells its story through the limitations of its sparsely populated world. Like most everything else in the game, the flavour of the game’s lore and plot is largely left with the player’s curiousity and interpretation, which suits it just fine. Dark Souls is a game focused squarely on combat that demands precision, smarts, and persistence.

Most action-oriented games place you in frenetic fights that move swiftly, and although fluidity is very much a key to success in Dark Souls, the combat here feels weighty and deliberate. Your character’s movements, burdened with heavy armour and weaponry, feel appropriately strained. You can’t make a last minute dodge out of harm’s way or just mash on the attack button, either. Every action in the game is methodical yet extremely powerful if used judiciously and properly. Each blow you land and fatal swipe you dodge is the result of skilled observation and timing, of knowing your characters strengths and limits and exploiting each to the fullest. Know your character and pull your punches wisely, and you’ll slay the toughest of foes. Attack wildly and evade flippantly, and you’ll soon find your enemies taking advantage of your every misstep.

Death is swift and common in Dark Souls, though it’s never an end. In fact, your character will likely be dead – or “hollowed” – for much of your play time, complete with a decayed and eyeless face. Each time you die, you’ll lose all of the souls you accrued from enemies – which serve as both experience points to upgrade your stats and currency to purchase items – and respawn at the last bonfire you visited, which serve as sigh-relieving points of rest in the game world. Bonfires refill your stock of estus flasks – the game’s healing item – as well as recharge uses of your spells. Yet even these points of safety come with a catch; use a bonfire, and all enemies excepting bosses respawn, ready to make an attempt on your life once more.

The game’s death mechanics also introduce yet another unique aspect to Dark Souls – the importance and privelige of being alive. Although your character handles the same way no matter their state, using valuable Humanity items at a bonfire to turn your character back into a living being opens up a ton of online connectivity features. Although you can’t play Dark Souls in a multiplayer setting or set up matchmaking with your friends, each individual player does slightly connect to all others. You may see ghostly images of other players appear around you, real-time feed of where they are and what they’re doing in their own game. When you’re alive, you can find and use items to summon players into your game temporarily, using them to help you clear more difficult sections.

Ultimately, you get out what you put in to Dark Souls. There’s a dizzying amount of nuance and detail in the game’s setting, level design and combat, and it only gets more engrossing as you sink your teeth in further. The more you change up your fighting style and take risks, the more you learn about what makes the enemies tick, and brings possible methods for felling them to the surface. There’s no easing you into play mechanics or tips popping up on screen to give you a hand in Dark Souls. You not only need to take chances and be proactive in your approach to its many challenges, you need to remember everything that works and apply it skillfully.

Equipment choices can have more than one impact - heavy armor not only blocks more damage than lighter equipment, it also makes your character less likely to be thrown off balance when hit. Large shields have great stability, which allows your blocks to use less stamina, but light shields allow you to better land devastating ripostes. Some weapons inflict damage dependent upon attributes such as Strength. If you've neglected the attributes that modify weapon damage, you can instead use elemental weapons that don't rely upon attribute modifiers, or chaos weapons that scale with consumable Humanity points. If you find it difficult to get parry timing down, ignore it and use heavy shields for blocking or rely more upon rolling. Enemies and items don't scale in strength as you level, so if you become skilled enough at combat you can complete the storyline and grab the most powerful equipment as a very low-level character.

The Prepare to Die Edition also adds three new areas that provide some new insight into the setting's history: a crumbling cityscape, a forest, and an area of the Abyss that's haunted by Humanity ghosts. The cityscape is the only one that impresses, as the others feel too redundant next to the original content, but the new enemies make them worth playing, including some misshapen humanoids with headstalks that can be seen in darkness and some tough stone guardians who slam their hammer so viciously into the ground that yanking them out causes an explosion of turf.

The new bosses include the fallen Knight Artorias, a key figure in the lore, and a ferocious Dragon which is so tough that he's an optional fight. All of the new bosses are frenetic and extremely aggressive combatants, making them at least as tough as those in the original areas. One of those original bosses also makes a very welcome reappearance, in a manner that both fits well with established lore and gives a different tone to the original encounter.

With its high difficulty, punitive checkpoint system, and trial-and-error gameplay, Dark Souls isn't for everyone. But with the Prepare to Die Edition, PC gamers finally have a version of Dark Souls to call their own, and longtime fans of the game have some new content to work with. Graphical hiccups aside, that makes this port a success.

reviewText:
It's no secret that Dark Souls has become an emblematic symbol of the whole separate genre — brutal, distressful dungeon crawler with tricky challenges, gloomy setting and unusual narrative form. The blurred contours of the new gold standard in dark fantasy RPG began to take its shape starting with the King's Field series and its spiritual successor — Demon's Souls. But the final master image was formed precisely after releasing Dark Souls.

Beware! All things in this game can kill you. Even cute little mushrooms strive to gather in a flock to tore you apart. All the environments are deadly — danger is everywhere. It arises from the darkness, lurks in the muddy water under the feet, descends from the ceiling behind you, oozes into your consciousness. Despite the grim and dismal ambience, the game gives unforgettable feeling of immense triumph after each of your victories. It transfers you to an awesome, mysterious and fearsome adventure you'll never forget.

If you do decide to play Dark Souls, prepare to die. And may the Black Knight Halberd be with you!

10/10

reviewText: What is the best part about playing a video game? Is it the thrill of watching the visual effects of a plane crash through a building and the amazement of the graphical destruction caused by the building crashing down to pieces? Is it the Hollywood style action sequences which keep the adrenaline rush going till you eventually want to jump out from the window to try and catch that ledge? Is it the thrill of racing or playing in a football game which one might not be able to achieve in real life? All of these can qualify as perfectly valid reasons for playing video games. But for me, they’re a bit too superficial. My reasons for playing games are much more basic. For me, its all about failing and trying again to correct myself. The possibility of death and the chance of life after it really intrigue me. I love a challenge, and i love to be rewarded for playing well and punished for being stupid. And in that regard, i feel Dark Souls is one of the best games i’ve ever played.

reviewText: This game is literally all about you dieing over and over again until you know what in the ♥♥♥♥ you're doing. It's not as hard as people say but playing through the game for the first time can be really frustrating. This game doesn't hold your hand, but it doesn't try to cut off your wrist either. The story is very vague unless you take the time to dig through every description of every item or if you bother talking to the NPCs. You aren't told where to go but what you must do, its up to you to figure out what works best for you, how much you want to engage in the online play (which on this PC port it takes forever to connect to anyone without the use of mods), and how you wish to take on your enemies as you progress. There are quite a few optional places to go, lots of loot to find, and many enemies to kill along the way. Take your time and absorb all of the information the game throws at you, enjoy your first experience through the game. I recommend playing with a controller as the keyboard and mouse controls are just terrible without mods, if you want to play with a very active online community you should aim for one of the console releases of the game, though there is still a bit of a PC community for this game.

reviewText: If you're considering buying Dark Souls, you should ask yourself how much you really appreciate a good challenge. Dark Souls is a game that embraces difficulty, and not in a monotonous grind-y way like Ninja Gaiden or I Wanna Be The Guy. Dark Souls does not spoonfeed you victory like so many modern games: it expects you to learn from your mistakes and hopefully prevent them in the future.\n\nPersevering through From Software's epic may seem daunting, especially at the beginning, but if you open yourself to it, Lordran can be a fascinating and emotional place. Dark Souls is packed full of monstrosities and deities alike, and although its numerous bosses are not easily felled, triumphing over them will be one of the most rewarding victories you'll likely ever experience.

reviewText:
In a world where games are designed to give you kind of power fantasy feeling for doing jack squat, this action RPG is unafraid to punch you in the face. With an iron gauntlet. Spiked. Repeatedly. Telling you to toughen up, learn to dodge, block and/or parry, and above all, fight back.

But it's fair at that - when you do learn how to block, dodge, fight back, then you truly know you do deserve that power fantasy feeling. Or deserved to die for failing to dodge or misstepping that ledge and plunging into ever so eagerly welcoming embrace of gravity.

Come here if you want to know what a game designed ground up to be challenging, but fair, means. As opposed to misnaming ♥♥♥♥ easy difficulty as normal" and then making "hard" just by halfheartedly upping sponginess and numbers of enemies.

reviewText:
Dark Souls will be one for the ages to me. This is the kind of game that is completely brutal but rewarding at the same time. I raged, and raged hard at some encounters, because this game holds nothing back, but it forces you to also think on your tactics as you progress through the game. It will give you all the tools you need to get through it, you just need to think and plan accordingly. And they are completely right, the feeling of accomplishment you get upon beating a particularly hard section or encounter is unlike any most games out there can give you. I especially enjoy how big monsters actually FEEL like big monsters, as in, they can easily crush you if you're not careful. It was a thrilling and challenging ride, but I loved it and it is now easily one of my favorite games of all time. Highly replayable as well, there are tons of secrets to find here.

Elaborating why I liked this game though, hell, even discussing the minimal detail on this game would actually derail and spoil you the experience, in my honest opinion. This is one of those games you're supposed to pick up and play, while going in completely blind. You'll be shafted many times, count on that, and you'll probably seethe with frustration, but you'll adapt, improve as a player, and maybe even overcome the challenges ahead. This is definitely not a game for everyone though, the difficulty is up there.

The port wasn't the best, but I did just fine using an Xbox 360 gamepad and DSFix, an unofficial fix that fixes many of the problems it has - http://blog.metaclassofnil.com/?tag=dsfix. I was able to go through the game quite well, barring one single crash, and some minor framerate issues here and there. That's better than what any Bethesda RPG can really claim in terms of performance, and I love the hell out of those games too.

Bottom line, if you have this game on Steam and didn't play it yet, I URGE you to finish this review, and go install it and play it right now. You may end up loving it or hating it, but either way, you won't come out indifferent to it. Even better, now that Steamworks has finally been implemented, you have no excuse. Go die lots of times, go curse that one boss who keeps kicking your ♥♥♥, it'll all be worth it once you finally manage to beat him down, I promise.

Praise the Sun!

reviewText:
Let me clarify: this IS a good game. There are some significant problems, though:

If you don't have a console, this game can be made playable. It is fun in of itself, but the PC version is marred by no patches, GFWL, and various bugs. Users have to install small patches manually and hope it works. If you do get it, MAKE SURE you do the patching and GFWL sign-in BEFORE attempting to play, else you will lose all progress.

If you have a console, GET IT FOR THE CONSOLE. It is challenging, even if people overestimate/overhype its difficulty.

The game itself is very rewarding with an insane level of depth and a very widespread community. Figuring out how to proceed with fights is immensely satisfying, yet it's punishing (but fair) if you make a mistake. (However, due to the buggy nature I will say that it's infuriating when a glitch occurs, and say there's a 2-second delay in you trying to drink a flask.) The fights are epic (and sometimes outright terrifying) and you truly get to build your character the way you want to play.

Again, though, the functionality leaves a lot to be desired. Even after patches I frequently run into a sound bug and a control bug, the the prior being irritating as hell and the latter which has cost me several deaths. (I'll click to use a flask while standing, and the move won't register til 1-2 seconds later when I try to raise my shield, instead raising my flask. This has resulted in me being hit and killed numerous times.)

I got mine as a gift. I wouldn't've paid for it myself knowing the degree of functionality it is currently at. If you're more patient than I am, by all means go for it and enjoy it.

I AM looking forward to Dark Souls II, however.

reviewText:
One of the most brilliant RPGs of recent years, a legitimate heir to Severance: Blade of Darkness[en.wikipedia.org], Gothic (by Piranha Bytes) and Rune.
Dark Souls makes you re-evaluate your understanding of gaming process, challenges all your skills and nerves, and gives you a rare sense of deep immersion on that very special and rare scale.


Not recommended for casual gamers and kids. World of pain, tortures  and death ahead. And strange sun cults, and demons, and big snakes, and spiders, and skeletons. And Mushrooms. And lots of strange and crazy stuff.

Still, get the game and play it already! It's a rare gem you're missing.
And remember - it's only possible to learn through death.


TLDR: 10/10 brilliant

reviewText:
Dark Souls is easily one of my favorite games ever made. The gameplay is sophisticated, but it isn't  too complicated once you understand the stats and what they mean. Controls are tight, and everything works as it should. The world is deep and rich with an interesting lore. You'll want to read item descriptions and pay close attention if you really want to understand the world From has crafted. The story of the game is very implicit, but the direction is clear if you talk to NPCs.

Multiplayer is present in the game, with coop existing by summoning friendly phantoms to assist you in your world. There is also PvP, which is the main draw for me, and it's fantastic save occasional lag and balancing issues. One of the main problems with the game was that it used Games for Windows Live, but that's gone now and the multiplayer is better than ever. The PC Port is just god awful though. It's locked to a low resolution and framerate and the keyboard controls seem to have been designed by a monkey with half a brain. This is all fixed by Durante's mod DSFix, which is very easily installed. Once everything works as it should, the multiplayer of this game is phenomenal.

One thing I greatly dislike about this game is the LOLOL DAK SOULZ SO HAAWD!" stuff. The game has a reputation for being brutally difficult and unfair
date: but that's just not true at all and it's really annoying. The game's difficulty comes from its punishing nature. If you make a mistake
recommended: you're gonna get messed up. Playing carefully is the only way forward (read: get good). Nothing about the game is intrinsically unfair; that's a construct applied to it by the kind of people that always blame lag when they die in multiplayer games.\n\nThe community in this game is fantastic as well
hoursPlayed: but it has its fair share of tryhard children that will send hatemail at the slightest infraction of their self-imposed moral code. I've gotten death threats for not bowing before a fight before. You learn to move past these people
voteText: and you find some of the funniest players on the planet. Youtubers like VaatiVidya
helpfulPercent: Iron Pineapple
votesHelpful: and formerly OnlyAfro (Rest in Peace good Afro) make quality videos that add to the community of the game.\n\nIn summation
votesTotal: this game is a must-play for anyone that doesn't mind fixing a small amount of issues. The game is punishing
votesFunny: but never unfair and the multiplayer is to die for. Get it?\n\nAlso

reviewText:
Dark souls, My favorite game, My favorite series. I own 5 copies of this game. Why you ask? well Ill tell you.

Demon souls started this new genre. Its an action rpg yes. But its more than that. It is something so new to the gaming world that was desprately needed. A game that you actually play

So many games now hold your hand so much that you are not even really playing the game, you are just clicking a series of actions to keep the game progressing. There are not many games that actually require you to learn the world, the system, the enemies and Much, Much more.

Dark souls just does that. it throws you into this unknown world with nothing more that a few scribbled notes on the ground to get you started. Has you killed over and over within 2 minutes of the game, just to give you a hint on what is coming.

Yes dark souls is a challenge, But you know what has kept me coming back after nearly 1200 hours over multiple consoles? The reward.

The insanely gratifying feeling when you kill that boss after so many tries, Get through that area to that fog door, Finally kill that Hacker who has invaded you 30 times. Nothing, and I MEAN NOTHING   compares to that feeling, Especially no other series.

Dark souls holds a special place in my heart, It has been there in the hard times in my life to take my mind somewhere new. Get my head strait.

It may have an incredible reputation for being so difficult and you may hear someone say it is unfair.

It may be difficult, but it is not unfair. Any time you die, it is your fault it is something you didn't do, maybe you did not understand it yet. But that in its essence is what dark souls is. A game to help you understand. A game to help you overcome its challenges and make you better prepared for life.

Cause thats really in an essence how we deal with life, LIke a moth Flittering towards a flame.

reviewText:
Dark Souls, the game everyone recommended me to play, the game I tried to play a few years back, the game I couldn't play because I went in the wrong direction when I started...

A year or two later I decided to give it a shot one more time. This time, I took some time to explore every bit of Firelink Shrine (starting location) and found the ACTUAL easier/do-able sarting path, with ennemies that won't one-shot my character.

It's hard, very hard. Especially during the first couple of hours. The learning curve is steep but is also super entertaining. Getting your build right, upgrading your weapons and gears, fighting difficult ennemies and epic bosses, progressing through a fantastic storyline, all of these are the reasons I came to love Dark Souls. I died a lot, I sill do, but learning how the game works and how to defeat every ennemy by learning their patterns and their weak spots really helps a lot.

PvP in 2016 isn't like it was back then but it still works. I recommend this game to anyone who likes RPGs for their storyline and games with a difficult learning curve.

--------------------------------------------------------------
Single Player: 10/10 Amazing lore, goergous ennemy design and patterns, stunning landscape
Multiplayer: 7/10 Co-op and PvP both included in the game. Could be better
Graphics: 9/10 Amazing dark theme with beautiful landscapes and interesting locations. Not the most polished graphics but still amazing
Community: 9/10 Streamers, nice wiki and many videos
--------------------------------------------------------------

reviewText:
Dark Souls: Prepare To Die.

Oooohhh, Dark Souls. You know, I actually avoided playing this game at first (but still nabbing it in a pretty good sale, but let it sit for a year or two in my library...) because of the famed difficulty of the game. I just passed it off as something that it didn't really follow it's tagline.

Why did I pass this game up?

I completely missed it's prime. What do I mean?

This is a single player game that combines multiplayer in it's world. But how? Well, you're given phantoms of what other players are doing at random times, being able to make pre-written messages and warn others (or trick others) about the future obstacles. Some are even more friendly, extending their hand to help escort you through a zone, and even fight bosses with you! Some...will invade your world, in a attempt to take your experience points.

Everyone's moved onto DS3, so this game is quieter than it should be. Invasions are rare, co-oping with random players is a complete pain in the ♥♥♥♥...most of the PVP groups you can join in the game is rendered useless by the quiet of the game. Thankfully, there almost always seems to be at least a handful of people on, playing the game, at any time of the day.

I'm counting this against the game, as, in it's current state, the community playing it has mostly moved on to DS3. Onnnn the other hand, those who prefer to avoid the multiplayer aspect will have a alright time knowing that invasions will be far and few. But it's still something that deters from the experience.

Let me adress the tagline, Prepare To Die." Yes
date: this is a game where you cannot take combat as a joke. If you're unprepared
recommended: you will die. Nearly every single time I've died

reviewText: This game has an incredibly cohesive and immersive world, with great level design and enemy placement. It also features a very responsive combat system, and a wide range of possibilities in character design to add replayability. Unfortuntately, its pvp system features bad netcode and no cheat prevention, but it's still fun at times. The game gets called hard because it refuses to hold your hand and no one knows how to deal with that, but it's not really that difficult--it just has an incredibly steep learning curve. It does require the extensive use of a wiki to fully understand, which is very unfortunate, as there are some mechanics that the game only gives you hints for when in reality you need a textbook, for example, weapon upgrade systems. Luckily, such wikis exist, though at times they get things wrong. Overall, a highly engaging and enjoyable game with a very deep background lore. 8/10.\n\nBad PC port, though.

reviewText:
Dark Souls is a game, even if it doesn't always feel like it. By now, we all know what this game is. There's no need for me to tell you that this game will kill you, but this game will kill you. Before you start it even! Some people will be at work for an hour just trying to get it to launch! I know I did. The game doesn't like DLL files in system32.

This game is terrible to you. First, its keyboard controls are abysmally mapped by default, but because of the way the mouse controls work, you can never completely fix the abysmal controls without plugging in a controller, which may sting for the more hardcore PC users, such as myself. Second, the graphics settings are also seriously lacking, and beyond that, the graphics themselves are seriously lacking. The game isn't actually rendered in your resolution of choice and the framerate is locked to 30 fps. All that is putting aside the horrific instability and temperamental nature of this historically terrible port.

However, once you get used to the alien Controller" device and install a thing called DSFix[lmgtfy.com]

reviewText:
I'll divide this review into two sections: Game Review & PC Port Review then you can decide for yourself whether you would want to buy the PC version or look for a console copy.

Game Review
Intro:

FROM Software's Soul Series first started by Demon's Souls on PS3. At the time of release, that game revolutionized the concept of difficulty. It was truly a challenging game that needed mastering. Dark Souls is no different, it is indeed very difficult and offers little to no help along the way. Tutorial is nothing more than explanation of controls and a few gameplay basics, nothing more. Dark Souls is not for the faint of heart, it takes a dedicated gamer to finish the game.

Pros (+12):
- Achievement through struggle, unforgiving difficulty which is very rewarding
- Minimalistic plot that's open to player interpretation and fan theories
- In-depth character customization and lots of equipment to choose from
- Multi-player is uniquely integrated into single-player
- Beautiful art design and breath-taking sceneries, visuals are great
- High replay value which stems from the NG+ system
- Inter-connected world and amazing level-design barring a few rushed locations
- Each single step you take has permanent consequences, the game is auto-saved every moment
- Epic boss and enemy designs
- Even the weakest enemy can kill a careless end-game character, there is no true safety
- Teaches real life lessons and is full of metaphors
- No quests, no mini-map, no guidance, you are truly alone in a hostile world

Cons(-4):
- Audio and sound effects are boring and dull, soundtrack is uninteresting
- Persistent network issues which will never be fixed
- Intentional easy mode" provided by some items or play-styles
- Lousy English translation and occasional incomprehensible text

Gameplay = 10/10 ; Audio = 7/10 ; Visuals = 10/10 ; Story = 10/10

Verdict: 9.75/10 - Almost Perfect
Dark Souls is truly a gem and one of the finest RPG titles of this generation
date: it is a game with a point to prove
recommended: lessons to teach and controllers to break. This is a must-play title for any true gamer in this generation.\n\nPC Port ReviewThis horrible monstrosity called a PC port is truly one of the worst ports in all history if not the absolute worst. This game is literally unplayable without a controller
hoursPlayed: if you're looking to play with Keyboard+Mouse you're going to be deeply disappointed. The game always displays X360 Buttons on the screen. Apart from that
voteText: the game itself is locked to 30 FPS and unlocking the framerate with mods causes several issues such as broken ladder animations and extremely short jumping distance.\n\nThe port itself is borderline broken without the help of various fixes and modifications such as DSFix & PVPWatchdog. This is an utterly terrible PC Port with countless issues and problems that will never be officially fixed. If you have access to a last-generation console
helpfulPercent: I would highly recommend buying a console version instead because the PC port is plain broken.\n\nHowever
votesHelpful: if you insist on playing the game on PC
votesTotal: use of modifications and fixes is mandatory."

reviewText:
My Personal Score: 4/5PCGamingWiki Page[pcgamingwiki.com]
Issues: too many to mention. This is a very unoptimized port; look at the PCGW page for the fixes.

Dark Souls is one of the hardest games that I've ever played yet my experience with it can only be described as gratifying. It consistently challenged me and appropriately rewarded my efforts for taking risks, never treating me like a child that requires constant hand-holding but as an adult who can assess and adapt to the current situation that he's in. The game forced me to be patient and calculating, testing my limits, and taunting me to throw my controller against the wall but all of the hardships that I came across were worth it in the end because it gave me that satisfying sigh that one gets after saving the princess, or in this case, defeating the enemy that pummeled you a dozen times. It will be jarring at first but if you're prepared to die (a lot) and overcome obstacles which the modern gamer would quickly deem intolerable, I'm sure you'll be rewarded with the same satisfaction that Dark Souls gave its players.


And there you have it.

reviewText:
Dark Souls™: Prepare to Die™ Edition (With two ™'s, it's probably trademarked) is the port everyone asked for, but no one really wanted.

Prepare to die is a major tagline for the game, and is the last thing your computer will ever hear, because Dark Souls is so hard, it has the ability to manifest bosses in our world inside your machine, to destroy it from the inside.

You start off by making your hero with a powerful character creator, rented straight from Bethesda's The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion team, allowing you to create any type of potato you wish.

After you finish your vegetable appearing character, you can finally start the game. Owning a game controller will allow you to skip 3 of the bosses: Lord ♥♥♥♥-Camera, and the mentally handicapped siamese twins, Keybohd n' Mawz.

The gameplay is ripped from Super Mario 64, with platforming and hopping into paintings to fight bosses, with Metroid and Zelda thrown in for good measure.
The soundtrack is actually composed completely by Finnish metal band Apocalyptica, who also designed the whole game, Keeping the frames at a crisp 30 frames per second.
It also takes advantage of Microsoft's revolutionary service: Games for Windows LIVE, which brings the power of Xbox LIVE right to your PC! I hope you hate playing video games, because Games for Windows LIVE sure does.

Trademarked Souls™: Prepare to Trademark™ Edition is a fine edition to steam, and will compete directly with Valve's first person shooter action sidescrolling point n click adventure game DOTA 2.

Awful/5

reviewText:
Когда я впервые услышал об этой игре, мне её представили как очередной корейский гриндан с убитым сторилайном и геймплеем. Через некоторое время все-таки мое природное любопытство взяло верх, и я её купил. Это были не передаваемые ощущения, я наслаждался буквально каждой минутой этой игры и получил невероятное удовлетворение, когда прошел её. Итак, господа - Dark Souls.

Тут стоит сказать, что игроки в DS делятся на тех, кто дропнул её не дойдя и до половины, и на тех, кто прошел её и вероятно не один раз.

По началу не видно ничего, чем она бы отличалась от остальных подобных ей игр. Более того, она кажется скучной. Если это так - то мой совет просто перетерпеть, как это было со мной. Я поиграл день и дропнул её на месяц, после вернувшись - прошел буквально на одном дыхании. Через какое-то время , проведенное в игре, ты начинаешь её ощущать буквально всю пустоту и боль каждой локации, каждого моба, каждого пикселя.

Атмосферу безысходности и одиночества удалось передать просто идеально - все сделано так, чтобы донести до игрока мысль о том, что он ничего не решит, этому миру уже конец, и он здесь просто очередной смертник. Никто тебе не будет говорить, что делать и куда идти (не зря же эта игра породила столько шуток про свою сложность). Сначала все кажется серым и мутным, гамма красок так подобрана, но это только по началу кажется минусом - позднее понимаешь, что если бы что-то было бы сделано по другому, то DS не был бы таким прекрасным, какой он есть. Он не похож ни на что, кроме своей предшественницы. Концентрированный гримдарк.

Помимо прекрасной основной сюжетной линии (пусть и немного корейской, как по мне), есть огромное количество углублений" в сюжете

reviewText:
TL;DR
I've been playing games since the DOS era, I really lost count of how many games I had played. If my lifespan permits, I would like to experience all the great games ever created, new or old. Dark Souls, is one of the brightest diamonds in history, easily in my top5 of all-time. But 10 years from now, what will happen to the online aspect of Dark Souls? Nothing lasts forever, even all things good will eventually come to an end. Before that happens, if you are a true gamer, do yourself a favour, overcome your own Dark Souls, and you will never be the same again. Put simply, to emerge victorious in this Trial of Mentality, you have to become a stronger person than you are today.
9.7/10

IF YOU HAVE MORE TIME TO READ
For those of you sitting on the fence due to reviews of a bad PC port, worry not. I am playing this on Windows 7, without any controller, without any 3rd party fix, and it works just fine. My guess is they had released a recent patch to fix most of the complaints. You can always change the key bindings to something you like. My only issue is that sometimes the camera is too near, but that is more of a small annoyance since you can't really zoom out.

THINGS I LIKE:
+ Level up mechanic, reminds me of Diablo 2 but more extensive and better
+ Choose the level of online interaction you want at any time, you can play it like Single-player, Co-op or PVP! It's like half an MMO. At minimum there are still some subtle interference" between you and other online players (players can leave messages on ground to warn other players; bloodstains show a ghostly playback of how a previous player died; occasionally see "ghosts" moving around which is another real player)
+ Variety of weapons & their associated combat moves
+ Upgrading system of equipment
+ Checkpoint system wil restart you at latest "touched" checkpoint when you die
+ Epic Boss Fights
+ Looting is easy because there is a shiny bright light over anything that is lootable
+ No lengthy towning explorations or NPC conversations
date: just pure adventuring & combat\n+ 1-slot save system of no regrets\n+ Unlimited inventory space
recommended: take everything you want !\n+ Most importantly

reviewText:
TLDR VERDICT
Dark Souls is an innovative experience that provides challenging, yet extremely satisfying gameplay and a unique twist on multiplayer. Backed up with an intriguing narrative; absolutely stellar world design; all-round fantastic gameplay driven and atmosphere. An absolute must buy or at least try, as I believe everyone should experience this game, even if it doesn’t sound like your thing.

FULL REVIEW BELOW
”What is bravery, without a dash of recklessness” - Hawkeye Gough

You are cursed. You are destined to die, again and again. You will keep dying, until you have lost your purpose and you become nothing but a hollow mindless husk. However, just maybe, there might be something different about you.

This review is written from the perspective of a fan of story driven RPG games and games with well-designed open worlds, with an emphasis on player discovery and experimentation.

GAMEPLAY AND DESIGNDark Souls has fairly straightforward gameplay mechanics that are simple to understand but are supposed to be adapted to your playstyle. Contrary to popular belief, Dark Souls isn’t what I would call an especially hard game. Sure it has difficult moments, but it’s just completely different from what you might expect from an open world RPG, which throws a lot of people off. The game essentially punishes you for relying on what might be the norm in other games of its genre. You need to rely on a more practical way of thinking to get a grip of how the game plays. For example: heavy armour is hard to move around in and big swords are hard to swing.

The game introduces its fundamental mechanics very concisely and they aren’t anything you haven’t seen before. You have a health bar, a stamina bar, basic attack mechanics and so on. So if the game has such a simple and unoriginal sounding framework, why does it have such a massive following and a notorious reputation for difficulty? There’s a few reasons. The first is the enemies. Every new enemy in the game is different from the last. You need to observe their movements, their weapon and their body type to find an opening. The enemies are very firm, but fair (for the most part). They all have attack patterns and every pattern is avoidable, with a weakness you can exploit. Gauging what you attacks you can dodge and block and knowing when you can get hits in is all a part of the learning curve. Mastering bosses feels extremely satisfying. There are a few bosses that are arguably pretty “cheap” that might have you fighting the camera controls or jumping mechanics, but these are blemishes in otherwise fantastic array of enemies.

Weapon and item variety is also fantastic. Whilst the stats and levelling system may seem overwhelming at first, you get your head around it very quickly and start experimenting. Almost every weapon has different move sets and they all feel unique. Just like studying your enemy’s vulnerabilities, you’ll need to look out for your own and they come from the type of weapon you use. There’s a massive selection of pretty much every fantasy melee and ranged weapon you can think of, with varying designs. If you replay other RPGs for alternate morality choices, you’ll replay Dark Souls for alternate weapon builds. Different weapon types require you to employ different tactics and can make entire playthroughs seem completely fresh even though you only changed your weapons. There is also a very intricate weapon upgrade system, which adds even more depth to the game.

Dark Souls also has one of the best implementations of multiplayer I’ve ever seen in a game. The multiplayer is essentially built around the idea that we’re all screwed, but we’re all in this together. You can leave notes for other players that provide hints and sometimes good laughs. You can summon in other players to help you out with tricky areas. You can also invade other players and kill them in PvP combat if you feel really mean.

The world design in Dark Souls is seriously genius. A lot of the areas interlock like a maze with shortcuts in logical places that actually make sense within the space of the world. No two areas occupy the same space within the world, everything fits together perfectly and you can see areas in the skybox of other areas. The amount of detail that actually went into the world design is jaw dropping. You navigate the world by walking around and looking for bonfires, which equate to checkpoints. These allow you heal up and bank your hard earned souls, which is basically currency. You lose all of your souls when you die and need to go back to where you died to pick them up. If you die again before getting them, you have lost them forever. This naturally can lead to a lot of stressful moments, especially when there is an invading player standing between you and hours of progress. The stakes just makes triumph all the more rewarding.

STORY AND NARRATIVEDark Souls adopts some very subtle story telling techniques. You get a big grand cut scene at the start, that sets the scene for the world, but all the lore after that is pretty much hidden. You can interact with quite a few NPCs, but they only offer small snips of information at most and say more about themselves than the world around them. The other main source of information is item descriptions which can reveal information about specific events or people. This is quite good for people who like to piece together the story based on hints and clues. If you prefer storytelling to be more overt and involved then you might not be a fan.

Personally, I am a fan of involved and cutscene/conversation heavy storytelling, but I didn’t mind the Dark Souls approach. It essentially makes the story optional for everyone who wants to ignore it. The main downside is that those hungry for more story may not necessarily want to dig for it and will come away feeling unfulfilled. I initially felt that, as I was constantly discovering awesome looking areas and enemies and kept thinking “what happened here?” and there wouldn’t really be a proper explanation. Of course, the game has a great community and the story explanations are all on YouTube (lookup VaatiVidya after playing the game) but the fact you have to go to YouTube can be a detracting factor.

GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCEDark Souls is a really rough PC port. It is essentially a complete copy and paste of the console version. It runs at 720p capped at 30fps and used to have GFWL. GFWL has now been patched out and the game now uses Steamworks which is a huge improvement. The bulk of the issues are fixed by an absolutely essential mod called dsfix, which uncaps the framerate and offers better graphics options amongst other fixes. The multiplayer elements also had some serious connectivity issues whilst on GFWL. In my experience, the Steamworks patch works well when playing the game normally. You get a good amount of multiplayer play, but may have issues trying to play with a specific friend.

Dark Souls has absolutely stunning art direction. All the environments, equipment and enemies are really uniquely designed and definitely emphasise the variety of locations you’re exploring throughout the game. It also does an excellent job of conveying all these completely diverse environments, which are still seamlessly interconnected. The boss enemy designs are especially well done. Almost every boss evokes some kind of emotional reaction, whether its terror, pity or respect. The actual graphical fidelity in the vanilla game looks passable for the time (2011), but the aforementioned dsfix mod really makes the game a lot prettier, despite a pretty hefty performance cost.

reviewText:
One of the best and most challenging games i have played so far. Not only is the game setting pretty dark and scary, Dark Souls is also pretty hard so you will most likely always fear whats behind that door or fogwall, creating a similar atmosphere to horror games.

Concerning the difficulty of this game: You can beat the game pretty much naked, and without getting hit a single time for the most parts, but at the same time even with the best gear you can die in a few seconds to some easy monsters if you're not paying attention or do something stupid.

Learning from your mistakes is what this game is all about. You will die because you didnt know there was someone lying in an ambush. You will die even knowing there is someone behind that door, but you havent figured out what to to. You will die even knowing a good strategy to defeat a certain boss or clear an area. The game is fair, so dont blame anyone but yourself, just try it again and try harder, you will succeed eventually.

If you're searching for a nice action RPG, a dark fantasy game or just a challenge, Dark Souls is the perfect match!

reviewText:
I had heard quite a lot about Dark Souls: Prepare to Fun Edition before I went ahead and decided it was time I picked it up. I had actually heard about enough to give me the impression  that buying it would end up being a mistake because I would find myself quitting before I managed to get so much as a quarter of the way into the game because of the 2hard4me. Ironically enough I couldn't put it down because of the ♥♥♥ kicking I was getting initially being a lot different from the lackluster wins it seems every other game throws out.
Albeit that Dark Souls is just about as far as one can get from a walk in the park with a title made in recent times (save for the most irritating of indie games) it's nowhere near as bad as most will set it out to be. There are almost no situations where I felt that what was happening was just plain unfair and the deaths were anyone's fault but my own. Every challenge presented could be easily overcome by taking things slowly and getting the timing right. If you're used to the hand-holding of modern day pewpewbangbangbang games like I am then maybe you'll have a little (or a lot) more trouble than you should be having with whomever (capra, stop plis; it hurts).
The animation quality is to die for, I have never once played a game where I sat in an area toying with weapons just to see what the attacks looked like before but I've spent hours doing so here. Regardless of if I planned on using it or not when I got a new weapon different from what I had seen before I was excited to see what it was like. I've now gone as far as making builds just to try weapons I didn't get to use in combat before due to stats. Voice acting is another point of interest, most characters were unique enough to actually want to talk to.
On the down side the story could have been portrayed a lot better in game, I myself had to watch a countless amount of Youtube videos to get in on what was happening beyond the basic outline. If you decide to go ahead and do so then chances are you'll realize you missed quite a lot of the plot while playing through. The dreaded four letters also take a part in Dark Souls, GFWL (best system 10/10); on top of that connection is P2P so without DSCfix good luck summoning anyone, really. Although I've met a decent enough amount of people who have adapted to playing with mouse and keyboard I would still have to put down that playing without a gamepad is rather difficult.
Dark Souls easily places in my top five favorite games and I cannot wait to get my hands on the next one. Praise the Sun, praise the sun, praise the sun praise the sun, praise the sun.

TL;DR Gaem is gud, buy.

reviewText:
Despite its marketing, Dark Souls is designed to make you feel something. Rather than likening it to other games – most of which are purely about sensory stimulation – I prefer to compare Dark Souls to an album. More particularly, an extreme metal album. Like an extreme metal album, Dark Souls is incredibly inaccessible. It has no desire for mass appeal. In fact, it thrives on alienation. It wants only the dedicated, the people who will strive to understand what it is trying to convey.

Also, like an extreme metal album, Dark Souls has an emotional agenda. It has one united vision. It wants you to feel isolated. It wants you to feel empty. It wants you to feel like you are nothing, and that everything around you has more right to exist than you. It succeeds. The monster design, the level design, the sound assets, the silence – all these things combine to unnerve and depress you.

More than anything though, Dark Souls wants you to prove it wrong. It wants you to prove that you have a right to exist in its world, despite everything it throws at you. It pummels you to the ground, yet it gives you hope. It gives you a reason to press on, even when everything seems lost. It wants you to go in as one person, and leave as another.

reviewText:
Dark Souls is not a game for everyone. It will torture you, punish you and laugh at you, all at the same. But it will never be unfair. It will always play by the rules. Any mistakes you make are entirely your own. This game is hard. Maybe not all the time, depending on your build, but you will die. Not once, not twice. Hundreds of time. And you'll probably keep playing. Because the world of Dark Souls is something that needs to be experienced. I've rarely seen a world this detailed and this well executed. It reminded me a bit of a Metroidvania game, where instead of searching for upgrades you decide what to upgrade, thanks to the souls you'll collect from killed enemies. Before moving on to that part let me say that the textures in this game are simply amazing.

As I said, souls allow you to upgrade your character. But only at a bonfire. If you get killed before reaching a bonfire, you lose your souls. You'll resurrect as an undead (again) and get another chance at collecting your lost souls. But the enemies will have respawned and if you die again before reaching them, you'll never be able to recover them. It's tough and frustrating.
Enemies will attack you from all sides, there's danger everywhere. You have to remember when and how your enemy attacks, detect their patterns.

With humanity you can become human again. This allows you to summon NPC's or friends. These allies are extremely helpful in tough situations. The only consequence of being human is the fact that other players can invade your world. This is frustrating if you haven't saved at a bonfire or/and the other player is simply too strong. Defeat them and you'll gain plenty of souls, though.
It's a choice you have to make, but just remember that humanity is hard to come by, especially in the beginning, so summoning someone isn't always the proper solution.

As of today I still haven't finished the game. It should take you at least 60-80 hours to beat, and that's a first playthrough. You'll never be able to see, do and collect all the stuff you want in your first playthrough. It's simply impossible. There's so much to take into account.

Dark Souls is a brilliant game that only the strong will be able to finish. It's one of my personal goals, although I doubt I'll ever be able to finish it. It requires a lot of dedication. If you're one of those persons I strongly suggest you play this game. You'll not be disappointed.

(Use the Dsfix to improve the graphics and performance of the game. Don't start your first game without it.)

EDIT: I managed to finish this just a few days after posting the review. I'm not going to rewrite the entire thing as I still agree with most of what I've written. Dark Souls has entered my personal top 3 of favorite games ever so it doesn't need any further explanation.

[Rating: 96/100]

reviewText:
TL;DR: A game infamous for its difficulty, but for those with the time and patience to overcome the steep learning curve, they will find themselves in a deeply detailed beautiful game with one of the most competent combat systems in gaming. Though poorly ported it is still well worth playing with a controller at the ready.

Dark Souls is a game that I spent a large amount of my time with on console. Moving over to PC and experiencing it all over again, is time I don't regret spending. The fun from dark souls can be found in many different forms, though difficult as you progress through the game you can see yourself getting better and more powerful. The satisfaction of winning a boss fight, after they have crushed you countless time before is a feeling I have not found elsewhere. Though suffering from some issues such as the framerate cap and poor options this is a part of gaming history you can't miss.

Positive features:
-In depth combat and weapons variety that can be changed at any time
-Beautifully rich and detailed world with varying areas and enemies
-Difficulty harsh but fair
-Unforgettable boss fights
-Clever online system with active PVP community
-DLC comes included

Negative features:
-30 fps cap
-Requires a controller for best experience
-Lack of graphical options and settings
-Confusing navigation at times

To conclude Dark Souls is not a game easy to summarise. On console it was amazing and although considered poor for PC, it is still the same game only better and one that is well worth your time, a lot of your time.

reviewText:
Dark Souls™: Prepare To Die™ Edition is quite an easy game, perfect for kids, people with ptsd and people suffering from some sort of rage problem.

The gameplay is quite simple, you have to find the hidden cookies in the bushes, but WHATS THAT? Its Grandma, You have to hurry to find all the cookies fast before grandma catches you. Once you finish finding the hidden cookies the real battle begins.

So then you visit a war torn city and help out the nice but sad people who live there, maybe help an old man cross the street, donate some money to the homeless and talk to the head honcho of the neighbourhood.

After a nice conversation with him you keep moving towards the religious area of this war torn city and meet many nice people, a nice little piggy and even a trusty smith, you then move towards the chapel and talk to the nice priest there, he explains that the bell has not been rung in ages because the priest's back is not that well and he cannot climb the ladder anymore, so he sends you on a quest to ring the bell, and thats about as much as i want to spoil about this lovely and simple game.

Perfect port, Recommend playing with a keyboard or Racing Wheel + Pedals.
Score: 6 - Perfect Score.

reviewText:
There is no game I played in the last couple of years - probably since N64 times - that fascinated me as much as Dark Souls did (and still does). If you are capable of being patient, like to observe your enemies before attacking, like to suck in the atmosphere the world offers you, like NPCs who laugh a lot ( ;) ) and don't bother about using a controller or get yourself a couple of fixes for the mouse controls, then you're free to go to play one of the best games I've ever played.

Stuff you want to download before playing:
- DSfix
- DSmfix (in case you wanna play with keyboard & mouse)
- DScfix (in case you wanna play with friends)

reviewText:
I don't know what to say about this game, so let's start from the beginning.
I bought this game on a humble bundle just for fun and I kinda wanted to play the game for a long time.
Bought a cheap controller and started playing.

reviewText: Dark Souls is a beautifully crafted experience in a dark fantasy setting that will challenge the player to adapt and learn from their experiences rather than be spoon fed like many modern games.\n\nThe level design often creates a game of risk versus reward with the careful playcement of bonfires which serve as checkpoints where you can rest and level up your character. The question many new players will be asking themselves is weither to play it safe and go back to the bonfire and lose their progress, or to push on and risk losing their souls in hopes of finding another bonfire. Being the open world that Dark Souls is, each area connects with another logically and physically often through shortcuts opened up by the player. You can stop and look around at your distant surroundings and think to yourself,  Ah yes
date: I've been to that bridge before." and realise that each area of the game was perfectly placed with each other area in mind. This also serves the idea of experienced players being able to quickly build whatever character they want without being railroaded into a single path storyline creating replay value.\n\nSpeaking of storyline
recommended: there practically isnt any. Dark Souls is a lore rich game which often will be missed by first time players creating an atmosphere of hopelessness as you go around and around not knowing where to go. This aids in the player exploring the world on their own with little direction
hoursPlayed: but can be frustrating at times for the new player. The NPCs you find are primarily venders and story tellers
voteText: but will come and go with their own agendas further showing that the world doesnt revolve around you.\n\nDark Souls offers multiplayer in a few forms. Players can frequently see messages written by other players wishing to aid or hinder others as well as seeing ghosts and blood stains giving the impression of how others have died giving you a warning. Dark Souls also has optional co-op and pvp by recovering your humanity. Players needing help can summon phantoms to their world to help them progress and take down bosses
helpfulPercent: but this also invites enemy phantoms to try and stop you. The co-op and pvp however is totally voluntary and is not forced apon you at any time
votesHelpful: however you cannot have one without the other excluding playing the game offline and summoning NPC phantoms.\n\nDark Souls is an absolute must play for anyone looking for a challenge."

reviewText:
We all know that this game is famed for being 'difficult' or frustrating so instead of justifying this or telling you to suck it up, I'll write about my experience of the game so far.

'You Died'

But in all seriousness, Dark Souls: Prepare to Die is a game I think everyone should play at least once. It is reminiscent of old style RPG top-down dungeon crawlers in it's atmosphere with the level design allowing you to cautiously make decisions in which way you want to explore. 'Left or right? What if I miss a shiny by going this way?' you know the feel. It's really refreshing to see a more modern game handle this so well.

The combat however is what makes it really shine. You can't charge in and hope to obliterate everything by mashing a few buttons. Combat in this game, even against the 'trash' mobs, needs to be carefully planned. It's not forced like an RTS or turn based combat but if you don't think carefully about where and when to move, dodge and strike you will meet a bloodstainy end very quickly. While this probably sounds like less of a selling point, as you play the reward of overcoming a foe is that 'Awwyes' moment. Again, something a lot of modern games lack. It's also worth noting the class system is classic RPG style, with attributes that you level up so you can play the way you feel suits you.

The threat of dying is always there and the game does a good job of keeping you on your toes. Death is more of a learning curve in Dark Souls and half the fun is running into unexpected situations or biting off more than you can chew, each encounter (and subsequent death) asks you to take a moment to think how you could have handled that better. A boss may take more than a few attempts to overcome but when you do, you are equipped for future areas of the game. At first you'll probably be resistant to this, as many games treat defeat as the final stop, not a fully integral part of the mechanics. Once you accept this though, death is pretty fun.

The world, lore and atmosphere of Dark Souls is also some thing to mention. Without spoilers, the world is a dark medieval fantasy, which sounds cliche but it keeps a pretty unique feel and adds to the doomy storyline and mechanics. The creature and character design are also refreshing.

Now for some not so good things. Firstly, this is a port to PC. A lazy one. It's so lazy even the tutorial messages reference Xbox controller buttons *searches keyboard for RT button* While I've been playing with keyboard for the time being I'd suggest you buy an Xbox controller. Keyboard is okay, but I spent a fair while in the starting area mentally mapping what key did what. They aren't intuitive. You'll have a better time with controller.

The resolution can also be horrific on larger screens, which is a pity because the graphics are interesting. To remedy this there is an easy to install mod on Nexus, DSMfix. Almost a must have in my opinion.

Overall Dark Souls is a brilliant game worthy of time and attention. It has that old style feel that many games lack and is almost worth it just for that. However, if you are the sort of gamer who gets easily frustrated or doesn't like to be challenged in a game you should probably look into it more before buying.

reviewText:
Dark Souls is a fantastic and unforgettable experience with an immersive world and innovative multiplayer components. Brilliant level design and combat mechanics are what make this game great.

The difficulty in this game is often exaggerated. The game is challenging, but always fair. Whenever you die, its always your fault, not because of some cheap game mechanic. The game is not so much hard as it is punishing. Choosing to give an extra greedy hit against a boss can mean the difference between life and death. Unlike most RPGs, power in this game is more than just a numerical value, actual player skill plays a bigger part. The immersive atmosphere and the feeling of overcoming challenges are great.

This game is the most incredible gaming experience I have ever had. I can remember every moment of my first playthrough, from my naive first steps, to what I felt while the credits rolled. I have never before seen a game with such thought put into it.

However

After spending over 200 hours on the console version of the game, I decided to buy the game on steam. I was disappointed, the PC port is a joke. The graphical settings are extremely lacking, the vanilla game won’t run in full resolution and is capped at 30fps. The store page isn’t kidding when it says that a controller is recommended, the keyboard and mouse controls are horrible.  On top of all that, the game uses Games for Windows Live, which doesn’t let you access your save file if you are not connected to the internet.   Edit: The game has been ported to steamworks, not sure how this affects the online just yet, but at least you don't have to go through all of the GFWL account nonsense

Fortunately, some of these things can be fixed with mods, DSfix does a great job of fixing most of the problems the PC port has, and DSMfix fixes the problems with the controls (I still recommend a controller though).

I could go on and on about what makes Dark Souls so amazing, but this review is long enough already. If you are willing to install some mods to make it work, I would recommend this game to anyone, even to those who don’t like difficult games.

reviewText: Dark Souls is a dating sim where you play as pretty boy Choy Sen Unded trying to decide who to take to prom.  There are many suitors to choose from, ranging all the way from the quiet and reserved Petrus of Thorolund (who is constantly torn between you and his ex, Rhea) and the notorious playboy Solaire of Astora (who is still coming to terms with his sexuality).  Many of the players I talked with chose to date Kingseeker Frampt, and I can understand why.  There's a certain bit of old world charm to him and he acts like a proper gentleman (not to mention I hear he's marvelously well endowed), however, he simply wasn't for me.  His brother Kaathe is another popular choice as they share the same good looks but with Kaathe having more of a badboy" appeal to him.  Before I met either of them though I had already fallen in love with the well-intentioned but down-on-his-luck Siegmeyer of Catarina.  Siegmeyer is your quintessential nice guy

reviewText:
10/10
This game seems to be too hard or even unfair at first, but after a few hours and the first bosses it turns out to be super fun and it rewards you for for learning its combat.

+ amazing combat system
+ world completetely connected
+ can be played multiple time due to different possible ways/ covenants
+ skill-based pvp system, almost no lucky wins
+ coop play gives you the opportunity to summon help if you have trouble with some areas
+ great lore, although in the background (room for interpretation)
+ NG+ gives you the opportunity to collect a lot of the items

- almost unplayable with a keyboard (only gamepad)
- VERY hard to play coop/pvp with a friend, needs up to 2h to summon each other, even then no guarantee
- pvp works with p2p, meaning that heavy lags can occur (lagstabs...)

All in all an amazing game, completely worth buying, challenging but never unfair, hard beginning but huge learing curve!

reviewText:
Verdict:
Buy now!
Buy on sale
Save your money

Overall Score:
8.5/10

Summary:
I feel like Dark Souls: Prepare To Die Edition has been taunting me for 4 years - waiting for me to play it. I'd heard a lot about it and the hype so thought I'd experience it first hand.

To critique this game is not so straightforward. There are major issues. It's a pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ console port and you will spend your initial time downloading the DSFix 'mod' just so you can get it into a reasonably playable state. Forget about playing it on Keyboard and Mouse, unless you like extra punishment, a controller is a MUST (Steam controller worked well for me as an aside). The graphics are pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (even for 2012, but remember at its core this is a last-gen console game). The absence of a tutorial or tooltips will have you alt tabbing and searching YouTube just to try and find out even the most basic of info that will be crucial to your game.

Yet despite all that the game rises to be head and shoulders over the sum of its parts. Once you accept the basic premise that you are there to die and learn from your mistakes (the game even has a mechanic where you can watch other people’s death, via a ghost, by clicking on their bloodstain to help learn from their mistakes). Then you will practice and practice and finally get it right - rewarding you with extremely satisfying moments, a feeling not often found in today’s games. There is something to be said for taking on a boss 6 or 7 times then finally defeating him. It's not just a matter of doing the boss fight, it's clearing the trash every single time, occasionally losing your XP in the process, which will serve to both destroy your soul and have you punching the air in triumph when you are finally successful.

Overall the game is akin to flawed genius, you know something is not quite right, the game will brutally punish your mistakes and yet it is almost because of it that you will find yourself coming back for more. I'm pretty sure this is the only game I have actually Rage Quit in the last 5 or so years.

I've recommended picking up On Sale because the game has been around long enough and on sale enough times that you can save your money, add it to your wish list and then grab it at the next sale (unless of course you have a burning desire to play straight away).


The Good:Brutal and satisfying gameplay
Community support
Good old fashion boss fights
Sound is greatThe Bad:
Can feel lost as a new player, with very little information to go on
The graphics
You need to fix the off the shelf game (DSFix) before playing it to avoid a suboptimal experienceThe Ugly:
A terrible console port, NOT supported after release
Camera can be frustrating
Pro Tip
Although you may need to go to the Wiki / YouTube to get some of the basics of the game, I highly recommend you stay away from watching boss fights and reading guides - the most satisfying experience will be making your own way through the game.

reviewText:
Genre: Hardcore Action RPG
Game Time: 60~70+ hours

The PC port is passable. The game itself however boasts a solid combat mechanic ahead of it's time, which even in 2015 is one of the best on the market. The dialogue is minimal and the story itself isn't presented like traditional RPGs but the atmosphere just reeks of heart-crushing despair and helplessness. You can genuinely feel the fall of a civilization as you progress through the levels and see the destruction of monuments and countless fallen soldiers turned hollow.

The level design is a brilliant display of craftsmanship although in the later levels you acquire the ability to warp through specific checkpoints.
The colorful bosses will repeatedly destroy you until you get good to the point of not needing to rely on cheesy exploits.
Fitting music too. You will scream in terror at your first encounter with the Taurus Demon while the orchestra and chorus enhances the fear of being crushed to death.

Dark Souls has a crazy amount of content and great ideas executed perfectly, if not for the age of the game the full-price of $20 is a massive steal. It's multiplayer and co-op despite being released on the PC in Q3 2012, is still well alive. Of course not as lively as what it used to be but not dead to say the least.

Sometimes the player count can exceed what Evolve got on average during it's free-weekend, and that game came out this year.

There are so few criticisms for the game I would be nitpicking if I were to make one up. Besides it's obvious that the game had a limited budget and time constraints, but the fact that FromSoftware managed to create a game of this magnitude, is just inhuman. Seriously amazing job guys.

Oh, and don't forget to install DSfix![www.nexusmods.com]

reviewText:
Simply put: One of the best games I have ever played, alongside the Elder Scrolls series. The art direction, lore and player interaction are masterfully done. The amazing artstyle alone should come as no surprise from the individuals that have been creating numerous-but-unique mech designs for over a decade.

The game mechanics are simple, but satisfying. Allowing you to block, parry, dodge, light attack and heavy attack your enemies. What I like about the way the game handles itself with the combat system is how methodical it forces the player to be in unevenly matched fights. A lot of the enemies can be ran past once you understand the layout of the areas, but it can still be a rather tricky endeavor because of various environmental hazards that you'll find along the way.

The only true complaint I can lodge against the game mechanics are the absurdly generous input buffering for actions that usually do more harm than help. Also, be warned that since this game uses a peer-to-peer system for its multiplayer component, establishing sessions with friends or other people can turn into a frustrating ordeal.

The game itself is not nearly as diverse in terms of character creation/input as something like an Elder Scrolls game, but this is more than made up for with the gripping and unique world that From have managed to create. Obscurity is a major game mechanic theme of Dark Souls, and is what makes it so much fun to play. The joy of exploring areas that you previously had believed to be thoroughly searched, only to discover a new secret hidden within its crevices. It is this sense of exploration coupled with the very macabre atmosphere that make Dark Souls a truly wonderous experience.

reviewText:
Dark Souls will be remembered as a masterpiece that dared to go back to gaming’s roots and doing so perfectly. Away with regenerating health, minimaps and other forms of handholding. Lordran is an unforgiving world that wants you to take risk and learn from its brutal nature. The game will kill you… a lot. But as you die you will learn and eventually die a little less and overcome its obstacles giving you a fulfilling feeling of accomplishment.
In other words Dark Souls is a hard game. But that’s due to its unforgiving nature that punishes every mistake if you don’t play by its rules.

I played it on PS3 and even though the port has some obvious issues, I have enjoyed it just as much. This game is still a gem, and I can only encourage anyone to give it a fair try.
