reviewText:
Without a doubt the most dreadful PC port I've ever seen, this should have stayed console exclusive. If you don't have a controller, there is no reason to ever buy this game, and I'm not buying an XBOX controller just to play this game. Without a controller, menus are horribly irresponsive, mouse acceleration is all over the place, and the game never looks more than 1280x720p, regardless of effects, only options are motion blur and antialiasing.
Gameplay is, again, dreadful without a proper controller, developers don't bother with mouse sensitivity, so any turn will turn you 90 degrees regardless without mods and even then the game is a chore to play, you can't rebind mouse keys, game doesn't even show the computer keys, just controller keys.
Even ignoring the necessity for controller (which is, frankly, inexcusable considering the game could have been much more well implemented for mouse and keyboard), the PC port is still awful, since no changes were made to accomodate PC, a painful lack of graphical options, an extremely obtuse control scheme that makes no effort to change for a PC title and instead rebinds every button in a jumble across the letter keys, badly optimized graphics, no quality change, etc.
Now, the elephant in the room: Windows Live. Since June 1st, it has been impossible to go online play or save your game at all, which is, again, an inexcusable oversight for a PC port where save files can be saved on the computer. Don't trust any review before June 1st in regards to functionality, it's no longer relevant.
There is no way such a slapdash port should be seen as excusable compared to a console exclusive, regardless of developer of quality, period.

reviewText:
Renowned for being difficult and for good reason.  This game will test your patience as it throws you into a dark, dying world with little explanation and almost no equipment.  You will die.  You will die a lot.  But out of all the death comes understanding of the game.  And with understanding comes satisfaction.  Eventually the bosses will start to drop.  And someday you may understand what all the numbers in the menu mean.  Don't feel bad looking up guides to help you if you're super confused.  Better than quitting I say.  But don't let it do the work for you.  And don't spoil anything!  Discovery is the name of the game!

This game has an excellent setting and even better enemy design.

Praise the sun!

P.S. Subpar port to PC.  There are several mods out there to help make the game run better.  Please PM me if you need help.  Absolutely worth it.

reviewText:
Dark Souls; the game with an infamous reputation.
When it first released, I was skeptical as to whether I wanted to buy a game that had a reputation for being harder than trying to break into Fort Knox. So, as a result, I avoided buying it. However, in the summer of this year (2015), I decided, why the hell not?  During the Summer Sale I bought it for roughly £7. (I forgot the specific price.)
I can safely say now, after clocking up almost 300 hours on Dark Souls, and counting, that the purchase was absolutely worth it. So, let's get some context shall we? (There's a lot of context, so be warned!)
[Also! Dark Souls likes to follow the story-telling method of not telling you the story; if you want to know the lore, you've got to go research it!]

~Set in a pseudo-medieval fantasy world, the game explains that long before the present time, the world was grey, ultimately rocky and dusty and covered by huge 'Arch Trees'. This world was ruled over by the 'Everlasting Dragons' ; aptly named because they were immortal. At this time, there was no light or dark; no life or death in the world, only the Everlasting Dragons.
~At some point in this world, Fire was born (The game doesn't really explain how, so run with it) and from this flame was born four 'Lord Souls' (Souls in the game, act as a sort of power source for magic and the like, as opposed to being a representation of one's personality.) Three of these souls were found by the 'Lords', a race of humanoid creatures that would later become the 'Gods' of the world, while the fourth was found by the 'Furtive Pygmy', who is widely believed to have been the ancestor of Mankind/The first Human. (I'm not going to explain this story arc; go look it up if you wish to know more.)
~The Lords rebelled against the Everlasting Dragons, and using their one weakness (lightning-based magic), peeled apart the stone scales that gave the Dragons their immortality. (Without their scales, the Everlasting Dragons are not immortal) The Lord's succeeded, The Dragons were wiped out (supposedly) and this ushers in an 'Age of Fire'; where light and dark, life and death are brought into the world.
~Now, in between then, and the game start, there's a lot of lore that I won't go into (Again, go research the lore; It's really worth it), but it's safe to say that the Age of Fire began to dwindle and the power of the 'Gods' began to crumble.
~Fast forward to the present, the world is but a shadow of its former self; with both Kingdoms of the Lords and Human Kingdoms lying in complete desolation. This is because of the 'Curse of Undeath', a condition that replaces death with a form of immortality. However, the reason why it's called a curse is because those who are Undead with no purpose and no motivation/will to live will 'go Hollow', wherein they lose their minds and become reduced to mere husks. These husks are then plagued to wander the world forever; as nothing but shadows of humanity. They are hostile: attacking whoever gets close to them.
~This, is where you come in. You are a cursed undead waiting to go hollow in an asylum. However, you are freed from your cell to fulfill an ancient prophecy to 'Re-kindle the Age of Fire' (Again, go look it up). And from there on, your quest begins.
(Big nutshell I know, but this game has metric shed-tonnes of lore!)

So! With that explained, what's the actual game like?
~Well, the game does have a reputation for being very difficult, and whereas I didn't really have too much trouble with the game myself, I understand that it can be quite hard to get used to. The game could be said to be a hack 'n' slasher, but also an action-adventure game with RPG elements. At the start of the game, you pick a class to play, (classes include pyromancers, knights, sorcerers etc) and you then play through the game, levelling up and gaining new items to fit that class. The classes can be blended, so don't think that if you pick knight, you're stuck to using melee for the rest of the game; you could do a knight-sorcerer blend, or a knight-pyromancer etc etc etc.
~The combat (which is basically the core gameplay mechanic of Dark Souls), is very well polished and rounded. It's dangerous enough to maintain a high level of challenge, but balanced enough to be (relatively!) fair; if you die, there's a 90% chance that is was YOU that screwed up, not the game. This balance means that whenever you die, you don't become exasperated, you simply grit your teeth and go at it again. (Not always, but you rarely get to the instance where you might ragequit from the game) In addition, the game carefully avoids being artificially difficult (enemies with ridiculous health bars or stupid amounts of DPS etc), and is instead naturally difficult; with the difficult relying on how well you play the game, not how high-level you are. (It is entirely possible to complete the game without levelling up at all!)
~The game also includes a unique game-mechanic called the 'Humanity system'. I shan't go into the lore, but basically, humanity can be picked up from monster drops as an item, and absorbed from fallen enemies as 'liquid humanity' (Humanity picked up as items can be used to increase the amount of liquid humanity you possess). This 'liquid humanity' is used to kindle bonfires (basically more health kits at checkpoints), and also to reverse the hollowing process.
When you die in Dark Souls, you lose your liquid humanity, and also your 'Souls' (ingame currency for BOTH purchases and levelling). You can go to recover them from the last safe place you stood before you died, but if you die on the way there, they are gone forever.
~This is due to the constantly moving world of Dark Souls, and that you can't simply revert a save in Dark Souls; a choice made is a choice made, it cannot be reversed or altered for the rest of the playthrough. (Again, another way the game is naturally challenging.)
~You can also transition from two separate player states within the game; Human and Hollow. When hollow, you cannot interact with other players of the game, and you cannot summon NPCs to help you with certain boss fights. When Human, you can summon both NPCs and other players into your world for co-op play, but you also run the risk of being invaded by hostile players who seek a duel to the death. Therefore, it is recommended that you traverse most of the world as a hollow, only converting back to human when you need help with a boss or an area.
All of these factors combine to make the challenging, yet highly entertaining, odyssey that is Dark Souls.

ALL IN ALL, DARK SOULS IS A FANTASTIC GAME.
I sincerely enjoyed the time I spent playing this game, and I intend to play it for many, many more hours to come. It's tough, engaging, and ultimately, barrels filled with puppies and kittens of fun. This game is definitely worth you buying it!

reviewText: Much have been said about this game's difficulty, and while it is hard, it's not impossible and is rarely unfair. It has a deep combat system that's precise, easy to pick up, but takes time to master. It's set in one of the best designed worlds in video games; Lordran. A mysterious and often beautiful world that at the same time can overwhelm you with fear. How the areas in this world interconnects is just mind-bending genius. There are so many ways to play this game that it never gets old no matter how many times you play through it. A masterpiece.

reviewText:
If you like instant gratification, this game is not for you, however, if you have the tendency to put your genitals into the blender just to see what happens... This game might just be what you want. (Disclaimer: don't put your genitals, or any bodyparts for that matter, into the blender.

Dark Souls is hard, it is as hard as you've heard it would be and then some. But boy does it feel goed when you finaly kill that one enemy, usualy only to find out there's actually two more around the corner. The game gives you little to go on for that matter; if you die, you're propably not on the right track, yet. Either that or you have to step up your game a little.

But where the game itself doesn't tell you to much, the other players actually help quite a lot; with information scrabbled on the floor or as a spirit against a boss. When they are not helping you however, prepare for some prison shower ♥♥♥♥ invasions in which you will definatly get the worst of it. But that might just be my bad luck talking.

The short version of  real review would be:
Do you like to level up against foes you cannot beat? Do you like to see yourself die, a lot? Do you want to pummel your low level enemies into the ground when revisiting an area? Do you want the most awome stuff?
Yeah? buy this game.

If you do not want to try and try and try again, just so you can die 5 feet further, play farmville.

And don't forget: praise the sun.

reviewText:
Reminiscent of old-school gaming, Dark Souls is brutally unforgiving. It's fair though and 99% of your, frustratingly frequent, deaths will be due to your mistakes. When you clear one of the diverse and sometimes breath-takingly beautiful sections, another of the crazy and imaginative boss fights or find a secret area or piece of lore (of which the game hints at and can be delved into quite deeply if you so wish) you feel an immense sense of satisfaction and achievement. Interesting and exciting multiplayer opportunities (shame about Windows Live though), done in quite a unique way is thrown in too.

Most modern gaming has automatic transition. Dark Souls is fully manual and you'll stall many times. But once you can smoothly drive you will feel like you're king of gaming.

BUY THIS GAME.

reviewText:
Well, the title says a lot. You will die: a lot. However, you will savor every death as you struggle to improve your own abilities and survive in the oppressive world that From Software has created. The greatest achievement of Dark Souls, to me, is that it treats you like an adult. It does not hold you hand, it does not force endless tutorials or make you follow some generic NPCs as you mow down waves of unnamed brown dudes. No, Dark Souls let you jump into the action rather quickly and teaches you everything you need to know from the getgo in a very unobtrusive manner. Combat is a struggle as you try to read the enemies' attack patterns and react accordingly with your own moves. If you play it like a traditional hack and slash, you will die and go nowhere. Therefore, everything becomes a game of balancing aggression and defense as you learn when to engage, how to engage, when to evade, and when to block. If this sounds complex, that's because it is. Dark Souls will suck up numerous hours of your time with all of its nuances and secrets.

But the one glaring blemish on an otherwise fantastic experience is the PC port. To be blunt, it's just not very good. It's a very barebones port that utilizes very little of the aspects that we love about PC gaming. However, DSFix largely ameliorates many of these issues, allowing you to play the game at a higher resolution and higher framerate, making it the definitive version of the game. Games For Windows Live, unfortunately, exists in this game and is a huge pain in the ♥♥♥. You'll be disconnected from LIVE in the middle of an epic boss fight (it happened to me on the Bell Gargoyles the first time around) and kicked back to the title screen or have save data deleted because GFWL uses a primitive patching system that serves as a massive inconvenience. The keyboard controls, while functional (especially with community fixes) are far from optimal. You'll definitely want a controller for this game. Finally, the game can chug at times even on a high end rig, so don't expect a perfectly smooth experience.

However, despite all of that, Dark Souls is a fantastic game. In fact, I'd say it's one of the best games I've played in a very long while. The sense of accomplishment you feel as you claw your way through its brutal world or fend off hostile monsters that can easily kill you is practically uncontested. Most importantly, Dark Souls respects YOU as a player and does not baby you or insult your intelligence. It's a truly refreshing experience and one that most gamers should pick up, provided they're willing to overlook a lackluster port.

reviewText:
This game is REALY REALY HARD. You wont be able to keep your sanity without a walkthrough so here it is:

First off, when you launch the game, nothing happens, so you have to download a fix for it. Then when you try to install the fix you fail because you have 3 instances of the game running in the background due to your previous tries of launching it. Close the game running in the background and install the fix.
Ok So, you now have the game running, well, ♥♥♥♥you because this game requires Games for Windows live and if you dont have it the game will not save for some reason. Now go on and download the gfwl setup from the microsoft website and install it, go far enough until you find an error saying that you have no connection to the internet. Now go to properties and run the setup in compatibility mode and also as an administrator even though you are already the only user on your personal computer. You are now able to go a bit further in the instalation but then a wild error apears... To use gfwl you need the live sign-in assistant, so there you go again to the microsoft website to download the assistant. After you run it, go back to the gfwl instalation. Since you are dealing with microsoft software, you will get the same error. You are now trapped  in a labyrinth of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ software and bad pc ports so you will have to find another way arround. After some google searches you realize you wasted too much time with this ♥♥♥♥ and you give up. In the final cutscene you see microsoft and namco bandai collecting all the souls of gamers (along with their wallets).

I wanted a hard game to play, and thats what i got.
9 steve ballmers out of 14 skyrims

reviewText:
Prepare To Die is a good addition to this game's name. You will die. Lots of times. There is no getting around it. However, the first death is also the first step.

Dark Souls is a 3rd Person RPG, set in a fantasy world with very dark themes. You've probably heard about this game from a friend or some person on the internet, and one of the things you've probably heard is the challenge involved. Yes, this game is incredibly hard. No, it is not unfair in any way, and yes, you can do it.

There's a fairly high barrier to entry for the game, and even then the difficulty is higher than your normal game. However, Dark Souls is not unfair or just a bunch of cheap tactics. The kind of difficulty it presents is respectful. It isn't something like CoD's Veteran difficulty, where they just make the AI react as soon as you enter the room and one shot kills, making many certain spots impassable. Instead, they use creative enemy placement and tight controls to give you the feeling that even though you died this time, you can overcome it the next time. It has a great feelnig of trial and learning by error.

This is why the death mechanics are what they are, because when you die you lose all of your accumulated souls (kind of like EXP) and humanity"

reviewText: This game is the most satisfying game I have ever played to date. I highly recommend it to people who like games that will immerse you in the games world 100% and make you feel like your characters success is your success. When anything and everything can turn out to be an enemy or trap you will be kept on the edge of your seat for your entire play through. Throughout the course of that play through you will encounter next to imposable boss battles and relentless environments that will test your wits and sanity. However every time you conquer one of those ‘impossible’ boss battles the sensation is next to imposable to describe but the sound you’ll make may be something like this “gaaAAAFFFF-aahhhh-YES!!” as you either jump out of your chair throwing your hands and flailing your feet or slump back in your seat and let out a sigh of relief. Either way you will have felt like you’ve leaped over Mount Everest 300 thousand times over and high-fived the heavens. The environments in this game may seem like an impossible feat at times, and maybe a little unfair if you don’t watch what you’re doing or where you step, because that thought will always be in the back of your mind like it was mine when you only have 25% health and but a single estus flask left. “I have to fight a boss after this!?” But worry not future warrior for once you embark on this journey the one thing that will raise your spirits possibly more than conquering the bosses, avoiding booby-traps, exploring enormous landscapes and finding rare loot. “What could be better than all those things?” you may ask. I have but two words for you. The Bonfire. The bonfire is the light at the end of your monster filled tunnel, it is what keeps you going and what keeps you sane, it is your savior and your home, it brings relief and peace of mind in a chaotic world. This is a journey that in my book ranks above all others because it is a real ‘do it yourself’ kind of game that does not walk you through the game like a diaper baby, oh no. In this world you may enter as a naïve wanderer but you will leave a seasoned veteran who feels like they have the world in the palm of their well armored hands, that “this game wasn’t so hard, I bet I can do it again no problem” as you chuckle to yourself. Well Dark Souls will take you up on that, several times over in fact. Conquering this adventure once was by no means and easy feat but should you have the resolve and will for it, have another go at it, only this time lets amp it up and make every single thing two times stronger and seemingly a thousand times more deadly. Every time it gets harder but simultaneously more and more satisfying. Dark Souls will take you to the brink of death and then shotgun you to success if you have what it takes. If you think you do, than dive into the madness and delight. Just, press, start.

reviewText:
Gentlemen, I love PVP. Gentleman, I... love PVP. Gentlemen, I so love PVP.

I love parrying. I love riposte. I love backstabs. I love havels. I love buffs. I love fast roll. I love drinking estus. I love invasions. I love hosts losing.

On the bridges, in the anor londo, in the archives, in the forest, in the Oolacile, in the Depths, in the Painted World, in the Lost Izalith, in the Catacombs, in the Undead parish.

I cherish each and every pvp can be waged in this game.

I love the thunderous roar of asses, when casuls lose to the giant dad.

My heart dances when the asses of enemy troops are hurled into the air in pieces from pursuers.

I love it when a Havel smashes gankers with its giant club. It left a warm feeling in my chest when hosts would jump screaming from the blazing Giant Dad only to burn down lava.

I love it when the gankers overrun the enemy , while hitting him with a staff. It moves me when I remember the sight of a cheater in a state of panic, stabbing an already dead enemy over und over with infinite stamina.

I can hardly contain myself thinking of hanging the scrubs. And it is superb when the enemy undeads screams in time... with the roars of infested barbarians that smash them with boulders near Quelaag's domain.

And those newcomers from sales that fought us, even though they used ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Drake Sword. I even remember how I one shoted their entire group with dark bead.

I love russian players thrown into disorder. It is a very sad thing when their beloved npc's they should have protected to the death are killed by none other than them.

I love the English and American builds being crushed and annihilated. Their creeping about on the ground like vermin, chased by the Magic spammers, is the height of humiliation.

Gentlemen, I wish to see a war worthy of one in Hell itself.

Gentlemen, gravelords, darkmoons, darkwraiths... Pray tell, wat do you wish for? Do you wish for PVP as a matter of course? Do you wish for a merciless, shitlike PVP? Do you wish for a stormlike conflict which runs the gamut of blowing steel and striking flame, killing every host in 3000 worlds?

Invade!

Invade!

Invade

reviewText:
This game is great, but if your getting this because you're expecting the PC port is superior, hold on.
You're partially right.
Dark Souls no matter platform you play it on suffers from major frame rate issues, The pc port is no exception.
The game is tough to run and frame rate gets terrible in some places (Blighttown) .. but!
You can download a unofficial patch that's totally safe for steam  that fixes these issues called dsfix (disable anti aliasing)
DSFIX link here - http://www.nexusmods.com/darksouls/mods/19/?
It basically gives you access to a more advanced configuration settings (ini file) removes the frame limiter (normally 30 || <30)
Its an absolute must for Dark Souls.

If you're getting Dark Souls for PC, it is the definitive version of the game, provided you patched it
Have fun playing native resolution, 60+ fps

Masterpiece/10

reviewText:
This challenging fantasy action RPG throws you into a world where little can be taken at face value. The story is told in small conversations with NPCs and in item descriptions & placement. Incredible detail has been put into everything about this game which has a large community that regularly put out additional content (lore videos) that help expand a player's perception of characters. The combat is responsive and hinges of a huge variety of weapons, armour, and spells which really shines when you start playing online (and seeing all the crazy builds other people have come up with).
There are some technical hiccups however, with the biggest being the GfWL DRM causing some issues with the innovative co-op/PVP aspect of the game. GfWL is also set to go down at some time in 2014, so hopefully the game will be patched to use Steam to handle the multiplayer in the future.

In summary: this is a brilliant game, but a terrible port. If you can see past the technical issues, install the DSFix, and have a controlpad to hand, you may just fall deeply in love with this game.

reviewText:
Great game. It's not really the kind of game where you join up with a bunch of people and fight waves of monsters, it's more like you're one of the last people on the planet, everyone else is either undead or becoming undead, and every once in a while you can have the opportunity to join up with another player like you.

The game is locked at 30fps, but you can unlock it with a mod. Supposedly it's a bit buggy at 60fps, but I've never bothered to try it.

Dark souls is an RPG, you level up as you collect souls, you choose what stats to level etc. The contols are simple and within an hour or so you should have them down. This game shines in the customization department. There are tons of weapons and pieces of gear that can allow you to play whatever you feel like, even if you feel like playing some sort of green-skinned monster, you can do it.

The game world is lots of fun to go through, because it's all interconnected. There are no loading screens as you walk from one place to another, the entire world is essentially a labyrinth, and it is quite satisfying to discover all the connecting points and shortcuts throughout.

Personally I think what sets dark souls apart is the feeling of intimidation you get when you see a monster 10 times your size, and realize that you have to find a way to kill it before moving on. It's a challenge, based largely on trial and error combined with skill, it is not for those who want to be spoon fed an interactive story. As frustrating as dark souls can be, it matches it and sometimes exceeds it with the feeling of accomplishment.

reviewText: This game is a masterpiece. A flawed masterpiece, but a masterpiece none the less. It does not hold your hand at all, and is brutally difficult.  But that is not what makes this game so amazing. The atmosphere, lore, and tragic characters combined with great (but flawed) gameplay makes for one of the greatest games of all time. If I had to vote for a game of the generation, the only other game I would consider besides this is its sequel. The feeling of struggling through a once great kingdom fallen to ruin is something that only the Souls series has excecuted this well. This game will be remembered as one of the few that can truly be considered art.

reviewText:
Positive
+ A high learning curve for the gameplay, illustrating how important game knowledge and skill are in order to persevere through the numerous difficult parts of the game, truly encapsulating the rewarding feeling of beating a certain dungeon or boss; the game is rarely (if ever) unfairly difficult
+ Beautifully rendered environments and intricately detailed enemies makes exploring the world of Dark Souls simply breathtaking
+ A ridiculous amount of content to get stuck in to: with many huge areas to explore, bosses to defeat, and items to collect (personally, the game took me almost 55 hours to unlock all of the achievements, one complete runthrough of the game will take roughly 20-25 hours). The included Artorias of the Abyss DLC will add another 2-3 hours on top of that.


Negative
- While the gameplay is the main focus of the game, the story could do with some more fleshing out; the characters met along the way and their backstories only add so much to the experience.


Worth Mentioning
• When the game was ported to PC initially, certain technical limitations constricted the game, essentially making the game not run optimally (courtesy of From Software not having experience on PC architecture). Luckily, a member of the community created “DSfix”, which essentially optimises the game for PC and greatly improves performance, nullifying many of the problems that plagued the game on release (low resolution, no anti-aliasing, frame rate cap etc.).


Verdict
“Possibly my most engaging and memorable gaming experience to date. Dark Souls is simply one of, if not the best, action RPG I’ve ever played. With difficult gameplay that only sets out to weed out the weak gamers from the best, you would be a fool to want to not challenge yourself and beat this game once in your life.”

9.5/10 TJBs

reviewText:
Oh, Dark Souls...

This is one of those games that I have trouble expressing my opinion on it.
I've played Demon's Souls previous to playing Dark Souls, so when I got this one I kind of knew what to expect from it... How wrong was I!
I expected a great game, not an excellent one! This game is by far one of the best games I've ever played, hands down.

Right, the review.
Dark Souls: Prepare To Die Edition is a masterpiece.
Everything about this game is beautiful, the levels, the enemies, the weapons, the combat, the magnificent multiplayer, the lore (if you care about it), and much more!
So many secrets lie within the huge world of Dark Souls, you'll spend dozens of hours just to complete your first playthrough, not to mention that there is a new difficulty level each time you complete the game, to a cap of 7!
You'll also, uhm... DIE A LOT!
But that's only if you deserved it - if you're not good enough or are not approaching your enemies carefully, you will get punished for sure!

You can create your own character, name it and change the looks of it. Then you get to choose a class and some starting gear.
In this game you'll also meet NPC's, some of which have their own paths and objectives, and you can deal with those how you see fit.
Did you just meet with some guy and he seemed friendly? Why not joining forces? Or maybe you met with the son of the devil, you'll probably want to keep your distance. Or, just kill them all. No boundaries, right?

I won't go into much more of a detail, because the very first time I played this game I walked in completely blind and climbed my way up through some difficult situations, had to explore and learn how things worked by myself, and I loved every bit of it! So I won't spoil you the surprises.

Basically, if you're into RPG's with real time combat, where the story revolves around you (not some character made up by the developers), then this game is a must!
It's a very unique game (not counting the other Souls games) within its genre. But it has a VERY BIG PROBLEM called Games For Windows Live*. But if you have no issue with that, go ahead!

*The game isn't supported by GFWL anymore, and it is working decently so far (23/12/2014), so I'd still recommend you to buy this game.

Also, this game was meant to be played with a controller (since it's a PC port from consoles), so if you're having trouble using a PS3 controller, check out my tutorial about it on my profile.

reviewText:
Took me about 10 hours worth of frustration to finally get into the game and start enjoying it. Mostly because so little is explained in-game. I'd recommend watching a few beginners videos on youtube if you feel stuck. Once I got into the swing of it, I fell in love with this game.

It's the type of game that is so rage inducing, yet so satisfying. You actually fear for your life in certain areas because you are between bonfires, or deep in some unknown area exploring and trying not to die. The boss battles are great, particularly the design of the bosses themselves. I have found myself just appreciating them for a moment...and then they beat me to death in 2-3 hits...lol

The PvP and summoning are also great elements. I really hope that they switch it to Steamworks soon though, so that the game doesn't lose that aspect of the gameplay, or just die....

The combat in general is awesome. This is my first run through and I have just went for a strength/endurance build for the most part.
It's one of the only games that I have played where I am actually happy to go and check out things on a wiki page, while also trying to avoid any spoilers.

Anyway, it's a fantastic game and very satisfying...and it has also made me facepalm hard, swear at the TV, and temporarily quit the game to calm down, but when you beat the boss or area you are stuck on, and get to grips with the subtly of the combat, it is hard to top.

But you know what? It's Dark Souls. I'll do it with all my love again.

reviewText:
Dark Souls. The name alone sent shivers up my spine when a friend recommended it a month ago, notorious for it's sheer brutatlity and such little attempts to hold your hand or guide you along the way,I went in expecting to get my ♥♥♥ handed to me...i was correct xD Luckily i emerged victourious and haven't felt so majestic about a game in my life BAHAHA! I don't know what kept me going, but just that feeling of evolving from a scrawny, half naked, low level wanderer, desperately attempting to defend off simple hollows while wielding a striaght sword hilt...to an almighty force to be reckoned with wielding a Black Knight Greatsword battling Taurus Demons in the lava plauged wastes of Lost Izalith...was immense! This game also brings along a sense of strong entitlement upon completion, having beaten one of the most difficult games out in todays world, you can deffinitely call yourself a true gamer <3

reviewText: It's pretty much the greatest game in existence, top to bottom. reviewText:
wt r u, a casul?...
On a more related note, with Games for Windows Live dead and this being on sale for 5 bucks, it's worth the pick up... as long as you don't count the half-dozen controllers you are liable to destroy in the process... The graphics are rather poor for 2011, but don't let that get you down. Dark Souls is a carefully crafted experience that you can only really fully grasp the first playthrough. Many players wish they could go back and re-experience their first time playing.
The replayability of the game comes in the diverse weapon choices and character builds, as poking enemies to death with a dagger is way, way different than swinging around a gigantic two-handed blade and, well, crushing them, I suppose. If you want the intended experience, I suggest starting your first playthough as the Warrior, as its a well-rounded character with a decent starting equipment set, and choosing nothing (or the Pendant... don't talk about the pendant! Please!) as your starting gift, as the items, which you can acquire in the game itself, are really powerful at the start of the game.

So, what are you waiting for? We only want your precious Humanity...

reviewText: I'm not sure I've ever spent so much time on a game I've enjoyed so little. There are some silver linings, but they all come with big black clouds attached.\n\nThere's something compelling here - it's vaguely Metroid-like in how you really do feel like you're venturing into the unknown. And Dark Souls passes on the common flaws of modern cutscene-laden action games, which is nice to see. But in doing so it draws on the worst parts of old-school D&D, then adds in a few terrible design decisions on top. So at the end of the day it's just a disappointing dungeon crawler, albeit one with an sometimes-rabid fanbase.
voteText: 26 of 43 people (60%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I really wanted to like this game, I really wanted a hard game, What I got was a confusing mess. Dark Souls sets of to be an “Old School” game, where the term old school means confusing, unclear, vague, and downright purposefully clunky.

I knew what I was getting into, a game that is suppose to be tough at first, but over time has solid mechanics that keep you coming back in the same way Ninja Gaiden (Xbox) was. What this game is, is a complete miss an all cylinders.

The game starts off dumping you into a jail/keep where you have to escape from. During that about 20 minutes are very very basic tutorials. Right bumper = swing, right trigger = heavy swing. Which is good, but right after if gives you the button assignments, nothing. Oh and the stats system and leveling up good luck on that, nothing helpful is said about it. It's worth noting that any time your user has to look up a walk through to understand something as central as what stats do what to an RPG game, the developer should really take a step back and ask “How and what information am I communicating to the user?” If what is needed to be conveyed is central to the understanding of the game system, and is purposefully or negligently concealed you have already made a huge mistake. Dark Souls takes this mistake and makes it a central game mechanic.

I get the sense that at some point the developers wanted to make a fighting/hack and slash system that was consistent, in that there was no slicing through enemies (because you missed the hit box) which is a good idea. Again though the game comes to a crashing to a halt when you consistently die without any understanding of what you could have done differently to result in a better outcome. Again Dark Souls hides information from the user, you'll get combat pop-up bars that are conveying information but what that information is you are never told. Is that meter something positive or a negative? You won't know because at no point does the game ever clue in the player to what their avatar is dealing with.

I could go on but I have a feeling I'll be drowned out by people telling me I should have played longer then I did. I'm not a teenager, I have a full time job and I get precious few hours of free time. I do not want to use them dealing with a game that seeks to make itself more challenging by keeping information from me.

reviewText:
This game is good in the same way in the same way that aloe is good after a sunburn: you enjoy brief periods of respite between the annoyance that is most of the actual game.

I will agree that the game is well designed and the controls are actually pretty crisp, but that doesn't make up for the rest of it. Or maybe a better analogy would be that it seems like the game designers don't like the people that play their games and they are metaphorically spitting in their faces by making this game.

Start the game walk in any direction...die

Figure out where you're supposed to go...die

Make it super far into a new area, meet boss. Die immediately. Spend 7 minutes and 20 seconds (actually timed) getting back to the same place that you were at. Die. Repeat. Die. Repeat. Win. Move on to next area.

Find new type of enemy. They cursed you. Die slowly.

Before you get back to new enemy. Get restless and sloppy with easy enemies. DIE (even the average enemy of your level can 3 or 4 shot kill you within the space of maybe 2 seconds). Lose all you souls.

I wouldn't be so bothered by this game, but I was expecting it to at least be fair. If you mess up you pay, but the majority of your death is just guess and check. OH this enemy has some move that I couldn't have predicted without dying that can one shot me. That happens over and over and over.

All of that stuff being said, the game is relatively fun, but I usually can't stand to play it for more than maybe half an hour before it bothers me too much to continue.

reviewText:
THE EMPEROR'S NEW GROOVE is the funniest movie that I have seen in years. I initially had passed on watching it in the theater because I thought it looked childish, but was convinced to give it a try now that it was out on video. Boy, was my initial impression wrong.
The story revolves around a selfish prince who is turned into a llama by one of his subjects. With the help of a kindly peasant he attempts to regain his throne, and in the process finds there's more to him than he previously thought or wanted there to be. While the moral is a good one, it really plays a secondary role to the comedy, which is literally non-stop. GROOVE takes the rapid-fire humor that Disney perfected in Aladdin and combines it with cartoon-style hijinx, the wit of David Spade, and a hilarious lack of reverence for the traditional Disney animated genre. Spade plays his role to perfection, and luckily never crosses the line into being obnoxious. Seinfeld fans are in for a treat, as Puddy plays a very special side-kick role. You really can't take your eyes off the screen for a minute, because you're guaranteed to miss a gag of some sort. The humor works mainly on an adult level, even though kids will be rolling from the funny visuals and some of the more obvious jokes.
The DVD itself is a good one. The digital transfer was excellent and the sound quality is top notch. The commentary track is one of the better that I've heard, with interesting and funny insight from all contributors. Animated menus. There's a deleted scene that was probably best left out, but is interesting to watch anyway, plus a few other fun features.
In the end, this is one of the best Disney flicks to come along in years. Hardcore Disney fans will eat it up. But even if you're not a fan of Disney's usual animated features you should give GROOVE a shot. Cast aside your pre-concieved notions and you just might be in for a very pleasant surprise. I was. FIVE STARS.

reviewText:
This is obviously a very late review of Dark Souls so why review it now? Well to start things off simple, the big sales are coming around so if you feel the urge to buy it from Steam but not sure about it? Well here's a review you may or may not find helpful. The other reason is...Dark Souls II is just less than four months away and what better way to prepare than to review its predecessor for newcommers!

Combat:
The combat in Dark Souls is very basic, you have your left hand equipment for blocking and right hand equipment for attacking of two types, standard and strong attacks. Keeping this in mind that it can and might apply to all classes you may use, there are different classes you can make so you might be a sorcerer, cleric, strenght, dexterity, or mix. Also keeping this in mind, each weapon has a certain stat that scales and is required to use. This adds to the combat of what you can and can't use. Now onto the actual combat sequences: the actual combat is well designed and very fluid. Any time you die it is always your mistake of how you approached an enemy. It's no hack and slash game that's for sure, that is how you get yourself killed. Combat in this game is all about timing and approachment and it's glorious.

Story:
Now I will not get much into this, not that there is much surface story for you to absorb from just plowing through but, the story starts you off in a place called the Undead Asylum. After you escape you learn of these two bells and from there on out your journy continues There is a bit more of the surface story that can be hand fed to you but like I said, not going to spoil much. The lore or backstory of this is what links everything that may seem confusing together. Through From Software's brilliant design they have made it like a broken puzzle to find it all out. You learn everything through item descriptions, dialgogue, and even some times just by the looks of the area if your observant enough. It's hard work but the results will not dissapoint.

Bosses & Common Enemies:
To start this seciton off, we're going to start with common enemies, yeah those guys. The enemies in Dark Souls are of interesting nature, unlike in games like the First Person Shooters where they stand around like lost children, these enemies are aggressive and persistent. They are stupid enough to beat but smart enough to punish. Now when I say stupid I do not mean fit the shapes stupid, I mean they are trimmed down just enough to where they are not some diety sent form the gods to punish you, they are very much beatable. Some enemies may be smarter or tougher than others but all are beatable. The trick is they all know how to punish you for screwing up. Mistakes in Dark Souls are not forgiven.

This paragraph will all be for the details of the most epic fights you will face, even if the boss seems...eh. Okay, skipping the obvious known fact of Dark Souls being known for its intense boss fights, lets discuss WHY they're intense.  Music only plays on very few occasions outside of boss fights but when these boss fights do ensue, music starts that captivates the feel of your character's challange ahead of them, the terror that they are fighting. With that included you can even tell by the way the boss fights. If it's sad or depressing music, it is a story of tragedy or sorrow. Vice versa if it's loud and fast, you get the feeling the boss is  full of rage or beast-like properties that knows no mercy. These boss fights are something that are more than just a challange, they have a story behind them and are masterpieces, each and every one of them...except Bed of Chaos.

Graphics & performance:
Now this is a subject I usually leave alone but in Dark Souls's case, it must be adressed. Not because it truely matters if you played it on PS3 or Xbox 360 but because of how atrocious of a port this game was. Locked in at 30 frames per second with a very poor graphic quality locked in that wasn't even 720p made it look terrible on the stretched screen of the PC. It was an exact copy paste of the Xbox 360 version, no modifications to optimize this baby. Now before you start getting freaked out and shy away, there is a mod to fix this. It is called the DSFix mod and it unlocks the frame rate and graphics settings. If you don't got the mod the game will look muddy and not play smooth, with it installed you got a pretty, dark atmospheric game and have a smooth frame rate that doesn't murder your frames in the cruel area of Blighttown.

Final Verdict:
I know this review seems a bit short and very rushed and it is, 2:36 in the morning is not the ideal time to do these things. I am going to give it 2 scores, one w/o the mod and one with it. This is being done so you can get an idea of what  experience you will get.

WIthout the mod:  6/10.
This game is nearly unplayable without the mod. The keyboard bindings are not so hot, the frame rate is locked in at 30 which for a PC game is not the ideal setting to be playing at, and very muddy, stretched graphics from the locked in graphics setting of something less than 720p stretched out onto a monitor.

With the mod: 9/10
If you got the mod installed you will not regret it at all and you are in for a masterpiece only obtainable by the skills of From Software and the publishing efforts of Namco Bandai.


After notes:
-It is highly recommended to use a gamepad for this game. Keyboard bindings like I said are not that good and this is a straight up console port.

-Installation of the mod is easy, follow the files in the order below in whichever program x you have
Steam
SteamApps
Common
Dark Souls Prepare to Die Edition
DATA
Now drop the files you have extracted from the DSFix compressed into here and follow any remaining instructions.
Find DSFix and edit the game settings there.

reviewText: First things first: if you buy this game, get the fan-made DSFix patch to sort out the visual issues in what is a truly awful console port.\nOkay so: I still can't figure out whether or not I think this is actually a good game, but it's certainly the most fascinating one of the last console generation. The good things about it are stupendously amazing (combat, sense of place and immersion, Metroidesque world design) but the weird stuff about it is kind of crazily ♥♥♥♥♥♥ (opaque RPG mechanics, boss resistances/weaknesses that cannot be logically deduced). The barrier to entry is absurd and I would argue most gamers - not most people, most *gamers* - would need to take a look at the game wiki before even attempting the first level if they want to get any enjoyment out of it at all. I would also argue that half the reason for the fanatical cult following is that it's the exact opposite of all the boring lead-you-by-the-nose design-by-committee perpetual-quest-marker ♥♥♥♥♥♥-cutscene-riddled tutorial-fests that dominate AAA gaming at the moment. Like modern games are so scared you might get a widdle bit stuck somewhewe, so petrified of the rollercoaster stalling for a minute, that they've sacrificed the satisfaction you feel when you discover stuff for yourself and overcome real obstacles in exchange for an experience which is kind of okay fun the whole time but completely unmemorable afterwards. But boy oh boy is this game a crazy backlash against all these tendencies.\nI recommend it because I think it's utterly fascinating and totally fantastic that it exists, and that anyone who likes games should give it a go at least once because if you're the right kind of person for it you'll probably love it so much that it will ruin other games for you. But by the same token, The Legend of Zelda games conjure a lot of the same good feelings, without the trade-off of all that dread and fear and frustration. So this is a recommendation with a caveat I guess. I dunno. This is probably not a great product recommendation. I'm really bad at selling stuff to people. The only thing I could sell when I worked at a phone store was an iPhone most of the time, and that was because people would literally just come in and say Hello
date: I want an iPhone".\n\nEDIT: After an investment of a good 25 hours
recommended: here is my revised review: this game is amazing. Buy it. Buy it now."

reviewText:
If you are prepare to die this game is for you. You will die alot but each death will teach you something, If you like the challanging gameplay this game is one of the best. This game is hard when you first play it because lack of instructions for beginers but as you go on game will become easy.

Pros:-

Lots of unique enemies. Each area has its own type of enemies. I should say these normal enemies will kill you more than area boss.
Great Level Design. All the areas in the game are interconnected.
Some of the best boss fights I ever seen. It feels very satifying to kill some bosses.
Great sound design. Ambient music when you fight with boss feels great. Sound when boss hit their weapon and you block it with your shield feels real.
Lots of weapons to choose from. Every weapon has its own unique move set.
You can build your character anyway you like.
Great DLC content.
Coop and PVP battles.
Cons:-

Pyromancy feels over powered. Most of the bosses in dark souls are weak to fire, Even some of them are good against fire they still die easily with fully upgraded pyromancies.
Very bad PC port. One of the worst port I ever seen. Frame rate some times drops at certain areas not much but you can feel it. Although game's art style is great graphics doesn't feel that great.
This game is not perfect. It has its flows. I give this game 8/10.

reviewText:
Dark Souls is a marvel of its time, a game that reminds us that we shouldn’t be satisfied with well-produced mediocrity and “good-for-what-it-is” games.

It’s challenging, mature, deep, polished, and above all, a game that respects its players. There’s no hand-holding here, you’ll learn the ropes by playing, and the game will test you at every step, frequently killing you. The challenges are finely tuned, appearing almost impossible at first, but are in fact perfectly fair and doable, and a source of great satisfaction once beaten.

The fantastic combat takes the center piece here, being easily the best you’ll find in any Action-RPG. It requires tactic, demands attention and rewards patience like no other; all while providing you a vast array of weapons and armors to equip, and diverse enemies to test them, through expertly designed levels. Another high point, the melancholic story is masterfully told through subtle details in the scenery, hints in the items descriptions and concise, well-written lines from a cast of memorable NPCs, never relying in long expositions or lazy “Lore Books” by wannabe-writers.

From Software raised the bar with Dark Souls; it’s not the best game ever, but it’s one that excels in absolutely everything that it does.

reviewText: We had pizza for dinner tonight. I tried to eat it straight out of the oven and I burned the ♥♥♥♥ out of the roof of my mouth and now I can't stop using my tongue to rub at the raw spot where I used to have skin. Dark Souls is sort of like that—it hurts, but it's a good kind of hurt that makes you wonder if maybe you aren't a little bit of a masochist after all.\n\nThe story of Dark Souls centers around a customizable player character, know as the Chosen Undead. In a world where the undead are cursed to become vicious hollow" beings
date: the Chosen Undead embarks on a quest to gather the four Lord Souls of the realm and defeat Lord Gwyn so that he can rekindle the First Flame to put an end to the curse of the undead. The plot of Dark Souls is vague and unguided
recommended: with players receiving very little direction on which task they should be pursuing next or which area they should approach. The attractively lacking narration leaves much open to interpretation and requires players to explore Dark Soul's open world in depth—a perilous task in a world inhabited by enemies that are often much stronger than the player's initially weak character.\n\nBut it doesn't matter what Dark Souls is about. Dark Souls's unemphasized storyline allows for the main focus of the game to be given the limelight because
hoursPlayed: without a doubt
voteText: Dark Souls is a game whose shining element is its gameplay. Players are given a wide array of equipment options
helpfulPercent: allowing for an unending variation in playstyles. Where I played as a heavily armored knight with a spear and a greatshield that remained constantly on guard while poking out from behind my shield and slowly whittling my opponents down
votesHelpful: others prefer the lighter
votesTotal: more perilous style of a dual-handed dodger armed with daggers and wearing nothing but rags. All styles of play are valid in Dark Souls
votesFunny: with the well-balanced gameplay and stats providing each one with its own strengths and weaknesses.\n\nThe enemies of Dark Souls are often aggressive and powerful
commentsCount: with many of them being able to destroy the player in only a couple of hits. Players earn souls for defeating enemies
column16: which are used both as a currency and as an experience system in Dark Souls. When a player is defeated
column17: their souls are dropped down onto the ground—often several levels worth of experience
column18: all waiting for you to come back and claim it. Should you die before reaching those souls
column19: they're lost and you must start over again in order to build those levels back up. Hours upon hours of gameplay
column20: lost.\n\nHowever
column21: Dark Souls balances its risk and reward experience mechanism just as well as it balances its combat. Dark Souls is challenging
column22: but it never approaches unfair. Each death is well earned: maybe you didn't roll quite quick enough
column23: or maybe you tried to heal even though you knew you should have blocked. Every mistake is your mistake. Every death is your death. There are never moments where you believe the enemies
column24: despite their massive strength and formidable countenances
column25: are overpowered or undefeatable. It's not a question of whether or not the bosses can be killed; it's a question of whether or not you have the skills and the knowledge to make the final blow. And when you die (and you will die
column26: many
column27: many times)
column28: you learn and you progress. And next time maybe you won't be quite so slow or so careless.\n\nFor years my best friend and I would check the used games shelf at GameStop (back when we were both console peasants
column29: before the GTX series graced our lives) and we would see it: Dark Souls
column30: the game that we always wanted but never picked up because everyone lauded it as "too hard to play—like really hard
column31: man". And don't get me wrong
column32: Dark Souls is hard. It is crushingly unforgiving
column33: with a combat system that rewards cunning and tactics while testing both your physical and mental reflexes. The price for failure is high
column34: but the satisfaction of victory? Well
column35: that's the ultimate reward.\n\nAs a friendly heads up
column36: many people say that the PC port of Dark Souls is particularly low quality (and it is). Nonetheless
column37: the console version of this game runs at an abysmally low framerate
column38: making a bad port better than no port. Be sure to slap a little bit of DSfix on it and read up on how to get the optimal performance out of the PC version of Dark Souls. Once it's set up
column39: it blows the console version out of the water."

reviewText:
Things I had to learn from this game without being explicity told aka artifical difficulty padding to prolong it.

1) Fight bosses in the nude to dodge all their attacks OR in the bulkiest max poise armor to be slow, get hit, but not be stunned and interrupted from your attacking and healing animations.

2) A small group or even just two of any generic enemy can be stronger than any boss when their hitstuns combo you from full hp to zero. High poise heavy armor shrugs off this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

3) Since bosses will kill you frequently, you'll spend much time going from bonfires to boss fights.

4) There's a hidden bonfire at the top of seth's funhouse and somewhat close to the boss bed of chaos (hidden behind an illusory wall)

5) IMPORTANT: If you input a jumping slash attack (right bumper plus up) but can't start the animation immediately (you're blocking an attack) the game will eat your input and use the thrust attack (right bumper) with horrendous cooldown and start up. The game dropping that input killed and frustrated me more than anything by far.

6) You will get one or a couple black knight weapons. Upgrade it with twinkling titanite and it will carry you to the end of the game.

reviewText:
Seriously, this is one of the best games I ever played. Maybe /the/ best, so far. Why? I have no idea, I started playing, but I gave up, rather quickly, it was just too damn hard.  But then, I tried again and I made progress, where I failed the last time. What a satisfying feeling. And there the fever got me, I wanted to keep playing, to level up, to get the best equipment, or to just see how the next level looks like.

But on my way to the End, I cried, I danced in joy, or I was just happy I survive, with my heart racing like I've been running for miles. No game, I ever played, got me so tied up and made me want to play again, no matter how often I died.

Some people say, this game has no story, well. On the first glance, there is none. But one of the strengths of Dark Souls, is also it's Story Line, it's hidden. You need to find piece of a puzzle, that you never will truly complete, it gives you hints and you have to make your own story from it. You are in a hostile world, you against everybody else, this just get's underlined by it.

Seriously, who can take to die some times and is willing to play a game, where you aren't the Literal God of War, slaying everybody after a while without any problems.
You should give Dark Souls a try. This game is really a jewel in the RPG scene and a title, you shouldn't miss.

reviewText: Prepare To Die is an understatement. This game is one of the few games that when you defeat a boss or uncover a new area you really feel like you have accomplished something. reviewText:
Things I had to learn from this game without being explicity told aka artifical difficulty padding to prolong it.

1) Fight bosses in the nude to dodge all their attacks OR in the bulkiest max poise armor to be slow, get hit, but not be stunned and interrupted from your attacking and healing animations.

2) A small group or even just two of any generic enemy can be stronger than any boss when their hitstuns combo you from full hp to zero. High poise heavy armor shrugs off this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

3) Since bosses will kill you frequently, you'll spend much time going from bonfires to boss fights.

4) There's a hidden bonfire at the top of seth's funhouse and somewhat close to the boss bed of chaos (hidden behind an illusory wall)

5) IMPORTANT: If you input a jumping slash attack (right bumper plus up) but can't start the animation immediately (you're blocking an attack) the game will eat your input and use the thrust attack (right bumper) with horrendous cooldown and start up. The game dropping that input killed and frustrated me more than anything by far.

6) You will get one or a couple black knight weapons. Upgrade it with twinkling titanite and it will carry you to the end of the game.

You will be lost, you will learn how to die, and eventually you will learn how to NOT die.

reviewText: Dark Souls has a reputation for difficulty. Git gud, they say. But it's not that Dark Souls is necessarily difficult, more that it has a steep learning curve. It can be intimidating for newcomers, as it was for me when I first played it. I got as far as Gaping Dragon and hit what I thought was a brick wall. So I shelved it for nearly two years.\n\nWith the release of Dark Souls 3, I thought I needed to give the original another chance. Boy, am I glad that I did. This time I had encouragement, and some determination. Again I struggled at the beginning, f*ck this game!" being uttered on more than one occasion. But then it suddenly clicked. I don't know what it was

reviewText:
Качественный и интересный проект, который не боится идти в разрез с трендами.
Враги бескомпромиссны, дизайн локаций великолепен и даже затмевает средненькую по современным меркам графику. В кои то веки сюжет не разжевывается и засовывается игроку в рот. Сюжет рассказывают сами локации, боссы и вещи.
Мультиплеер так же уникален и что саме главное - тонко вплетен в сюжет. Пока второсортные разработчики просто пихают несколько сетевых режимов, оторванных от одиночной кампании from software разработали систему где кооперативный и соревновательный мультиплеер органично вливаются друг в друга и создают ощущение монолитного и продуманного геймплея.
Конечно игра немного потеряла актуальность на фоне выхода второй части, но все равно обязательна для прохождения, ведь сиквелам никогда не удается затмить оригинал.

reviewText: This game, if you're thinking about getting this, then I have a few things to say. This game is EXTREEEMLY difficult. I've wanted to smash my controller once or twice. You need lots of patience if you want to do well in this game. With the co-op, it's rather different than most games because you can't really play with friends. You're meant to get help from strangers. You also can't go through the entire game with a co-op partner. (At least I think you can't) It's a very good game, but again, it's very difficult. And you're also going to want to use an xbox controller of some sort because the keyboard controlls are horrible.

reviewText:
In 1987, my older brother and I asked for only one thing for Christmas - The Legend of Zelda.  Ok, fine, we also asked for TMNT action figures, but that's a separate review. In any case, I can still remember tearing open the packaging and pulling out the magical golden cartridge.  As all younger brothers, I took the instruction manual as my brother got to play first.  The game starts, of course, with the story of Hyrule and Zelda's abduction.  You then name your character (a first!) and are dropped into Hyrule with nothing but a tiny shield and three measly hearts of life.

Except for finding the wooden sword in the nearby cave, nothing was obvious.  You could travel any cardinal direction, monsters attacking at every turn.  My brother wandered west, a big mistake.  Somehow surviving monsters far above his life/equipment level, he found the third dungeon.  What kind of twisted, depraved game allows a brand new character to enter a high-level area?  The monsters assailed poor Link and his nano-shield. His feable wooden sword only aggravated most monsters and split the chu-chu into more pieces.  Badly wounded, game beaping (still gets my pulse up) we stumbled out of the dungeon, bewildered. After exiting, and breathing a sigh of relief, the nearby tektite promptly killed us. We choose to continue, but our character now had a scarlet letter (number) by his name. With each death, and there were many, the number grew, a grim reminder of how many times we had met a horrible demise.

With persistance (and yes, a bit of help from Nintendo Power), we eventually defeated Ganon.  This was the greatest accomplishment in the first ten years of my life (judge me if you will).  The victory was richly rewarding, and I continue to replay Zelda to this day, trying to win the game in under 90 minutes with all items and no deaths.

My point, beyond reminiscing, is that Dark Souls is the actual sequel to The Legend of Zelda.  Yes, Ocarina et al are technically the sequels, but they have betrayed the essence of the original game.  Zelda has become cutesy, easy, and the amount of hand-holding and tip-giving led me to stop playing the series altogether.  Dark Souls, on the other hand, drops you into a deeply engrossing, unforgivng world with measly weapons and no direction (sound familiar?).  Fine, they tell you to find two bells, but in my original game, I somehow ended up in Drake Valley on my first foray after leaving the asylum.  I walked up to a drake, thinking it was a cut-scene, and he torched me into ash.  I could only think of my brother wandering into the third dungeon.  And like Zelda, the game punished my character with shame for dying, returning me to humanless form.

I'm half-way through (I think), and find myself completely absorbed.  Like Zelda, victory will be sweet and replay will be wonderful.  I hear some people can beat it in a couple of hours. I can't wait to try.

reviewText:
Dark Souls ist ein herausforderndes Rollenspiel mit fantastischem Kampfsystem, toller Atmosphäre, taktisch tiefer Levelmechanik und hohem Wiederspielwert. Wer die frustreichen ersten Spielminuten übersteht, findet hier das beste Rollenspiel, das derzeit auf dem Markt ist.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Dark Souls is a challenging RPG with fantastic combat system, great atmosphere, tactical levelling varieties and a high replay value. If you endure the frustrating first minutes of the game, you will find the best RPG on the market.

reviewText:
Totalling more than 1200 coupled hours between PC and PS3, this definitely is my favourite game.

While, in my opinion, the settings and the athmosphere are slightly inferior to its predecessor Demon's Souls, Dark Souls fills the gap with efficient mechanics, deep lore and a feeling of loneliness and despair that accompanies you throughout the entire story.

As for the PVP aspect of the game, the community is still very alive and populated by skilled players roaming Oolacile Township. GFWL is a big detriment, but with the Steam patch coming soon all will be forgotten.

Remember kids: if you're getting front-stabbed it's only your fault for not anticipating your opponent's network latency. Stop complaining and come get #rekt with us.

reviewText:
PC port quality aside, this is a VERY well made game no matter which platform you play it on.  With that in mind, let's get down to the dirty details :)

For starters, one thing I love about this game is that it is relatively noob-friendly (at least it was for me having never played Demon's Souls).  Its initial linearity helps new players learn the mechanics against increasingly difficult obstacles without necessarily having to worry about navigation *most* of the time.  While the enemies are by no means easy, for Dark Souls they are very primitive and therefore, make a good introduction for the kinds of attacks you will face throughout the game.  Enemies that are initially big bosses become plentiful regular enemies later on in the game, giving a massive feeling of personal growth and achievement to the player when the enemies that used to kick ♥♥♥ are getting cut down one by one.

The art direction in this game is extraordinarily well done.  By this, I mean how its sound design, visual style, and character design work with the underlying themes of the game to completely immerse the player.  Much of the world is filled with hulking structures worn down or destroyed, giving the player the sense that they are scavenging a once great civilization come to ruin.  There is almost never any music in the game, save for the boss fights and one area that is so awe-inspiring that it requires fitting music.  In many of the boss fights, the music is hectic and rushed, simulating the players' emotions when they just walked into a room with a giant behemoth eyeing your supple body for tenderizing.  Everything in this game looks and sounds like it wants to tear out your intestines with all manner of sharp or blunt object and wear them as various pieces of clothing.  Many of the NPCs in the game have very subdued voices and seem to be only sometimes be aware of your presence.  As the game title states, you will die and you will die a lot.  Caution is the word of the day and not paying to the environment later on in the game will prove very deadly indeed when many of the game's traps are introduced.

The story is told almost entirely through the environment, with some details being vaguely provided by NPCs.  As the story picks up with the player's journey beginning, the world has already fallen to ruin, with many of the once great heroes and gods of the time either dead or driven insane by the coming darkness.  Many (ignorant) people claim the game has no story whatsoever but paying attention to the environment is key to discovering the backstory and motives for many of the other characters ever coming to Lordan.  Some youtubers like VaatiVidya have very strong explanations for many of the characters in the game and they are incredible.

The combat in the game has a very weighted feel to it.  This game doesn't have a combat system like Call of Duty where everything happens at breakneck speed.  When the player swings their sword, the character has to quickly wind up for the swing.  It isn't slow by any means depending on your weapon of choice but it definitely requires deliberate action.  The combat is very much about decision making: when to block, when to counterattack, when to dodge, even when to run away to regroup.  Don't run into the game flailing around expecting to fight like Bruce Lee, it's just going to end with your death.

A topic on everyone's mind when talking about this game is obviously the difficulty.  While the game is very hard, it isn't for the reasons many people state.  As hard as it may be to understand at first, YOU are what makes dark souls as hard or as easy as it is.  Your ability to observe your environments and predict the actions of your enemies will determine how successful you are in Lordran.  Overcoming difficult boss fights is a result of your very own hard work and determination to succeed.  The game never hands you a victory, it puts your prize on the opposite end of a room filled with traps and deadly foes and tells you to take what is rightfully yours.

Don't go into Dark Souls thinking you will know how everything in the game works, even after playing for a while, without consulting online information.  While the game takes a hands off approach to educating the player about the mechanics of the game and how everything works, it isn't equipped to give *any* information on some things like how invasions and coop works, as well as some stats like poise.  This is my biggest problem with the game especially when it comes to new players.  There isn't any explanation for what being human does or what benefits you gain from consuming humanity without spending it.  Without consulting online information, your experience will be much more difficult especially later on when the level design becomes less intuitive.

This review is written while Games For Windows Live is still functioning and as such, I have no idea if the online will still work after the shutdown (probably not).  The game's online component is a mess, barely functioning for PvP and almost nonexistent for Cooperative play.  Thankfully, there is a brilliant mod that branches off the DSFix mod that makes coop way better than originally and that is very much appreciated especially if playing with friends.  PvP works but the amount of lag is unforgiveable in a game where losing to an invader can mean losing all your souls (currency) and a lot of progress.  98% of the time, I don't feel like anyone bested me in combat out of sheer skill, but because the latency with the servers condemned me from the start.

In short, the game is incredibly well put together and while a few things need improvement and the PC port DEFINITELY could have been made better, that doesn't make the game itself bad.  Especially with the community fixes for resolution, framerate, coop, mouse and keyboard, etc. the game is downright beautiful to play.  For sure, the game is VERY difficult, but it is by no means as hard as people make it out to be.  If you want a game that can bring you immense satisfaction as a player, you absolutely must buy this game.  One of my favorite game series of all time and I would recommend it to anyone who has the balls to overcome real challenge.  Incredibly deep and immersive, this game is a MUST BUY

reviewText: The game is a flawed masterpiece, held back by a bad port. Getting the running takes a bit of work, and be sure to get the DSfix mod. I also reccomend a controller, the keyboard controls are mapped in a very odd way. Despite all this, it is a unique experience that is one of the best gaming experiences I've ever had.

reviewText:
The Good:

Unique difficulty, unique setting, and unique gameplay.

Difficulty relies on skill in combat and evironment awareness, unlike modern games that rely only on damage modifications, and, or enemies with infalable aim. The setting doesn't rely on set pieces or glorified hollywood cutscenes to sell itself.

The Bad:

Lackluster PC port, and Games For Windows Client requirement.

Low resolution textures riddle the game, mouse and keyboard support is nonexistent, or at the very least horrid, resolution render is capped at 720p, and framerate is capped at 30fps.

Conclusion:

Install DSFix mod, DSCFix mod, and High-res textures from Nexus website, and I'll guarantee you'll have a damn good time with this game!
