reviewText:
I’m fairly late to the Dark Souls party however once I started playing the game I could not stop playing, from the clumsy yet once mastered combat, it is extremely fun. I did a lot of research into the game such as weapons, armours and so on but a lot of the discovery of the game has to come from just actually playing the game. I read that “so-so” weapon was great and “this was terrible” but learned that I loved this weapon for its ability to do this, and hated that weapon because it was too slow and so on.

The story:
The Story in Dark Souls is interesting, like many RPG games the lore is very deep with a strong and rich backstory to almost everything. You have to dig for all this however, searching online for the lore is the easier way to go about doing that so that’s what I did. The main story in the game however starts with you, whatever you are, man or woman and you can choose a class of a Mage all the way to the Knight, or a poor naked scrub. These affect how your character starts and how to can effect the work around you. You start in a cell, and are allowed free by grabbing a key from a hallow. After escaping you are thrown into the jaws of Dead Souls pretty violently though if you have any experience with games like this before you should easily grasp the ropes of the game. The rest of the Story is mainly about you completing quests and overall to beat the main boss. That’s all i will really say on this however.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is a classic RPG structure with Dark Souls combat system that is designed to be tricky but with trickery, come mastery, and once you master the combat in Dark Souls nothing can stand in your way.
Many times you will encounter enemies, countless huge bosses and even real players who invade your lands and try to take your souls, however if you beat them, you can take their souls so the game has some gamble in it. Please be aware however the game has a scaling system that in my own opinion doesn’t really work. Sometimes I was thrown against high-levels who I was skilfully better than, however due to armour and weapons were no match for. Then I was thrown against enemies that didn’t know how to block and were cut down faster than wood so the imbalance was annoying however extremely exhilarating. When a player joined my game to duel I got a very high rush of adrenalin, will he be good, will he be bad and fights were often extremely intense and amazing. I’m not a very big PvP person but this game has the perfect combat system for such a PvP system.

My only issue with the game it’s self is guiding. The game is open world however that’s all you are told, you must pay attention in all cut scenes to know what to do and even then sometimes it’s a guess so yeah, I don’t like handholding, but this game is a bit like those mothers who leave there children and supermarkets and drive all the way home, make dinner and then realise, however by this time the child’s already been beaten to death & ♥♥♥♥♥ several times and found his way back home already. But welcome to Dark Souls is the common reply hahaha.

Graphics:
This is when I can start getting picky with the game. The graphics are nice however the game is locked at 30fps and I believe is still locked at the rendering limit and is upscale. Please note however you can download a mod that fixes both issues. For the experience I chose against that but I’m going to download them now and play the game again at 60fps and non-up scaled res.

The art style of the game is very well done. The game is very dark however (again you can download a mod to fix that) one of the greatest things about the game is the Physics system however, a lot of destructible environmental objects is always fun for some known reason and sometimes event he buggy corpse ragdolls when you run past them and they get stuck to your foot and fly in the air as you run always brings a smile to my face.

So overall, I loved Dark Souls. The game is not the hard-case I’ve been told but the game has its challenges (Just saying. ♥♥♥♥ the Crystal section, invisible platforms can die in hell. They are cheap deaths and I find them to be a very lazy developer’s way of adding difficulty to the game.) Apart from the 30fps lack, 1024xsomething up scaled res and that specific level I have literally nothing to bad to say about this game I absolutely love it so much I actually played the game for 12 hours straight.

I will give the game a strong 9/10 - It lost that extra 1 for been a poor port. Mainly in the eyes of 30fps, it may not bother some, and in this game it's not a ballache to watch however more is always better. Oh and it looses points for Cheap deathts, even in very hard games, its lazy and unwanted. *puts up middle finger*

Pro’s:
-	Great combat system once you get it down
-	Strong lore, great RPG roots
-	Great weapons and armours along with designs of them are incredible
-	Great built in physics system and large amount of bosses and enemies
-	Good PvP system, still needs some tweaking however.

Con’s:
-	30fps Lock and up scaled res
-	Cheap deaths
-	Reused bosses (only some, I don’t mean mini-bosses either)
-	The game is sometimes very confusing.

reviewText:
Atrocious port, one of the best games ever made. 'Prepare to Die' is pretty accurate: the first half of the game is brutal.

Gameplay

Pretty much requires an Xbox360 controller. Mouse & keyboard controls are incredibly bad, and feel terrible even with a mouse fix mod.
DkS has the best melee combat outside Mount&Blade. Every swing has weight, every hit counts. Attacks are always telegraphed well in advance: everything can be dodged with proper timing. This works both ways, and it might take some time to get used to the player's attacks not being instant, but requiring a similar wind-up that the AI has.

Excellent weapon variety, with nearly every weapon having at the very least some minor unique quirk, and most weapons having full, unique movesets. The player's equipment choices are mostly personal preference: the weapons feel different and they're all perfectly viable when upgraded. Armour variety is also great, but what you wear doesn't make a huge difference. Resistances from armour are good, but dodging and blocking are far better tactics than eating hits.

The magic system is a bit intimidating at first. Highly limited amount of casts, and very long casting times. Three different schools of magic"
date: all of which feel powerful and interesting. Playing a sorcerer does make the game significantly easier
recommended: especially later on when items that increase magic damage are easily available.\n\nThe player character levels up by spending souls ( currency
hoursPlayed: essentially ) to level up individual stats ( strength
voteText: dexterity
helpfulPercent: etc. ). A single character can
votesHelpful: in theory
votesTotal: be a master of everything. Leveling up gets more expensive every time
votesFunny: so most of the time it's more advantageous to plan a build in advance and stick to it. At character creation
commentsCount:
the classes only really determine the starting equipment: the classes don't lock a character into a single path.

Incredible freedom in the character development system; encourages replayability by having a massive amount of perfectly viable builds to come up with.

Enemy design is
column16: overall
column17: excellent. They range from undead knights to giant mushrooms and clams. They all have unique movesets
column18: and despite the AI being very basic (run at player
column19: try to kill)
column20: the combat feels fresh when you move through the levels and encounter new enemies.\n\nThe levels are (for the most part) designed masterfully. A maze
column21: with shortcuts available everywhere. The world feels real: all the areas are connected perfectly
column22: and highly encourage exploration. Huge variety in the design of the levels: Duke's Archive is a huge library
column23: Tomb of the Giants
column24: a pitch black cave full of skeletons. Some areas
column25: like Lost Izalith
column26:
were clearly rushed and lack the complex geometry and intelligent enemy placement of levels such as Undead Burg.

Story

Highly unconventional storytelling in this one. Most of it is delivered through item descriptions accessed in the inventory. If you never read them
column27: all you'll really know is that there's a prophecy
column28: and you killed a bunch of dudes. The story hidden in the descriptions
column29: environment and NPC "quests" is absolutely brilliant
column30: however.\n\nHaving to dig for it makes figuring things out so much more rewarding than being told everything in cutscenes. There are 'holes' in the story
column31: and those are filled by the player
column32: and his actions. Everything in the game exists for a reason:  nothing is randomly just 'there'.\n\nI found the main storyline and the NPC stories extremely interesting
column33:
but it definitely takes some effort to be able to really enjoy.

Graphics & Audio

The graphics are terrible. Looks like a console game
column34: because this is literally a 1:1 port from the xbox360. Locked to 30fps
column36: relatively with low res textures. All of these can be fixed on PC
column37: though: I run the game at a 4k resolution
column38: 60fps and with fan-made HD textures. DSFix by Durante has a bunch of variables that vastly improve the way the game looks. Well worth installing.\n\nWeapons and armour  look pretty good
column39: but that's mostly due to their brilliant design
column40: not graphical fidelity. The environments range from beautiful (Painted World
column41: Ash Lake) to hideous (Lost Izalith).\n\nSound design is ♥♥♥♥ing incredible. Very little music: only plays at a central hub area and boss fights. The rest of the time
column43: monsters and other environmental sounds. The lack of music gives the rare times it does play so much more impact. Hearing the Firelink music after a raid on the Catacombs is very comforting
column44: and hearing boss music gets the adrenaline pumping as you face Smough & Ornstein.\n\nIn conclusion
column45: Dark Souls is one of the greatest games ever made. It is a terrible PC version
column46: but most of the issues can be fixed
column47: and the result is an experience no gamer should miss."

reviewText: This is one of the best games I played so far. It's not easy, actually it is one of the (if not THE) most difficult games I played. Every step of your path must be chosen wisely, you can't undo a mistake in most situations, so beware of your decisions. Every single battle is a challange and will put your patience, skill and timing to the test. Even situations in which you already excel normally might be the end of you if you're not carefull or rush too much. There are some minor setbacks, like the fact that the controls' explanations are not adapted to the computer version. Nevertheless, the game is awesome. Unlike other games, the storyline won't be given to you, except for the introduction, so be ready to find out what's happening on your own. Time to grab a sword and face the journey that will change Lordran as you know it... that is... if you're ready to die.

reviewText:
In the world of easy, linear and scripted AAA games for masses, players who are aching for some challenge are forced to either play indie games or... grab Dark Souls :P This one doesn't ♥♥♥♥ around, it just throws you directly in its hostile world and says 'good luck, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥' :P No clues, no tutorial. Just figure everything out or die.

I really appreciate that oldschool feel attached to this game. No health regeneration, one hit kills, clever design (no invisible walls for example, you can go everywhere you want. Provided of course that you can pass through that badass, much more skilled knight blocking the path :D), etc. In other words - at last, game for hardcore gamers, where getting to the next checkpoint makes you really proud of yourself :P

Sure, there are lots of flaws and pet peeves with this game. Like lousy PC port or controls, that require some time to get used to. But honestly, it's not that big deal and when you'll adapt to the game's mechanics, you'll love it with your whole heart!

Awesome game! :)

reviewText:
I bought this game out of curiosity during the last Steam Winter sales for less than 6€, after having read many reviews over the years, and I must say that it is well worth the money. Let’s get straight to business: DS – PTDE is a 3rd Person Fantasy Action-RPG, directly ported from the Xbox360 and PS3 version. The setting is a standard high-fantasy medieval world with lots of undeads, demons, lizardmen, dragons, knights in black or shiny armors of all sorts, but the lore and plot is rarely mentioned at all throughout the playthrough, as you mostly play alone (or with friends/other players in online co-op) with very rare encounters with sentient NPCs which can offer a little bit of insight on your mission and objectives. Game progression is almost non-linear: after having beaten the first obligatory “tutorial dungeon” you character reaches the first (and only) main quest hub and is given the generic mission to “fulfil the prophecy and ring the two Bells of Awakening”, with absolutely no clue on how to proceed: it is the player’s duty to start exploring the world and find a way to progress and clear a path, and this is where the real fun begins.

Even if you have been living under a rock for the past 2 years and have read no other review of DS – PTDE, you will understand one basic concept during the first 10 minutes of gameplay: as the name itself implies this game is INSANELY HARD. The developers have intentionally designed it to challenge the player at every turn, with absolutely no mercy even for beginner’s mistakes (even in the tutorial dungeon you will die A LOT during your first playthrough). Some examples, just to give an idea:

-          No save-load mechanic is implemented: the game autosaves your position and progress basically after every action you perform, causing every gameplay choice to become instantly PERMANENT. Did you just killed a NPC with a fireball by accident due to him being too close to a menacing skeleton? That NPC will be permanently DEAD, even if this means losing access to his wares (in case he was a merchant) or to a side quest. You will have to find another way around the locked door or find someone else to sell you those precious arrows you were looking for… The good news is that the developers have literally thought of everything, so an “unwinnable” scenario is virtually impossible to achieve (without cheats), even if you mindlessly slaughter every living and undead being in sight (including merchants and questgivers)

-          Even if your character is cursed with the undeath and technically cannot die, every single hostile monster or NPC can single handedly ♥♥♥♥ you and send you back to the spawn point with little effort. Even the least menacing zombie, armed only with a broken sword, can AND WILL kill you a dozen time if you do not remember to dodge his attacks or keep your shield up the whole time. Underestimating any encounter, even when overgeared, will lead to the usual YOU DIED screen in few seconds

-          If you are so lucky and brave to reach one of the various checkpoints placed at various strategic locations, and use it to rest and replenish your forces before proceeding EVERY SINGLE MONSTER YOU HAVE KILLED UP TO THAT MOMENT WILL RESPAWN (with the exception of bosses and minibosses), leaving you stranded in the middle of a dungeon with no way to get out without fighting your way back to the beginning. There is no turning back in DS – PTDE, sorry

-          Is it also worth mentioning that being killed will result in the same effect: respawn at the checkpoint and a horde of fresh monsters to fight all around you. Oh, did I mention that spawn points are usually very far from bosses, punishing the player even more for deaths during boss fights?

Although the above points could be interpreted as lazy or poor design, the reality is that DS – PTDE is one of the best balanced games I’ve played in many years of PC gaming: every encounter and situation can be easily won by using the correct strategy and taking advantage of the weakness of the enemy; if you are rushing through an area while swinging your sword or throwing fireballs without any care for the surrounding environment you will soon be overwhelmed and the familiar YOU DIED screen will be shown. A tactical approach, with perfect knowledge of the surroundings (to avoid the frequent ambushes) and the correct gear combination will increase your survival chances immensely, and some boss fights will even become trivial with the correct strategy.

Of course this implies a trial-and-error process, but there is a reason why this game is called “Prepare to Die Edition”.

Unfortunately this game has also blatant flaws, and the most important lies in the graphic engine: being a direct console port (made by a SW house which was specialized only in console titles with no PC experience) you can forget about HD resolution, smooth framerates and all the eye-candies of a typical PC AAA title. But it is even worse: the PC version of DS – PTDE is locked to 720p resolution and 30fps, IN 2014! You know that 3500€ gaming rig that you just bought and that runs BF4 at ultra in Surround on 3 27” monitors? It is completely wasted since you will experience the same resolution and detail of a 2005 console anyway.

And what about mouse and keyboard controls? Forget about them, as all the menus and in game text refer to Xbox360 control layout and using a M+K combo will be a frustrating experience (Steam even has a warning on the store page claiming that a 360 controller is strongly recommended for this game).

Luckily for you, my friends, the modding community has solved this issue since a long time with two brilliant an small pieces of software: DSFix and DSMfix (http://blog.metaclassofnil.com/?tag=dsfix and http://steamcommunity.com/app/211420/discussions/0/864979455329386779/). After a very simple setup process you will be able to enjoy the game on your PC as it should have been since release, with full HD graphics, 60+ constant fps (with the possibility of downsampling to push the detail even further, if your rig can take it), SSAO, MSAA, FXAA, smooth mouse controls and customizable keybindings. Last but not least, there is also a co-op fix called DSCfix which improves the experience of online co-op play over the standard GFWL junk (http://sdrv.ms/128mNwY).


TL;DR version:

PROs

-          Very challenging gameplay, but never too difficult to become unbeatable. If you die too much, it is generally your fault
-          Longevity (50+ hours of gameplay for a single playthrough, with the possibility of New Game+ with increased difficulty!)
-          Endless combinations of character growth and gear allows for very different approaches, all equally rewarding, to the game
-          A sequel is in the works!

CONs

-          Direct Xbox360 port: use of unofficial mods is mandatory to make the game playable
-          Awkward game controls with M+K (also fixed by a mod)
-          Absurdly steep learning curve
-          Some gameplay mechanics are obscure unless google is used (e.g. crafting)
-          Even with mods the graphic engine does not take advantage of all the possible features of a modern gaming PC

reviewText:
The famously difficult Dark Souls has the ability to burn images into my head and conjure up powerful emotions with its carefully-presented story. It is both bleak and beautiful, and is one of the most impressive games made in recent years.

Thematically, Dark Souls is about death and perseverance in an unforgiving world. This is echoed in the gameplay by a near-complete lack of guidance; for example, techniques critical for success go completely unexplained, like how to kindle bonfires (and what that even means). Thus, community involvement such as reading guides or walkthroughs is a must. The online elements within the game are also helpful, but the game is just as much fun to play offline.

If the inaccessibile presentation wasn't bad enough, it turns out that Dark Souls really is too hard. I'd probably enjoy playing it more often if it weren't so repetitive (dying and repeating the same segment over and over again). Frankly, I have the most fun late in the game, when I've powered up enough to explore new territory and take on bosses with relatively few deaths – you know, like a normal game.

On the whole, I still can't deny how absorbing and satisfying the whole experience is. There are so many fascinating details hidden away that are exciting to uncover. I love the powerful images, tense moments, and sense of accomplishment that comes when my perseverance pays off. Dark Souls is not for everyone – not by a long shot – but for those who can get past its steep learning curve and cruel difficulty, it can be a wholly unique and inspiring experience.

(Rating: 9/10 “Great”)

Notes: I played this PC version with an Xbox 360 Controller for Windows. It is nearly identical to the PS3 version of the game I played before, and comes packaged with the Artorias of the Abyss DLC.

reviewText:
Atrocious port, one of the best games ever made. 'Prepare to Die' is pretty accurate: the first half of the game is brutal.

Gameplay

Pretty much requires an Xbox360 controller. Mouse & keyboard controls are incredibly bad, and feel terrible even with a mouse fix mod.
DkS has the best melee combat outside Mount&Blade. Every swing has weight, every hit counts. Attacks are always telegraphed well in advance: everything can be dodged with proper timing. This works both ways, and it might take some time to get used to the player's attacks not being instant, but requiring a similar wind-up that the AI has.

Excellent weapon variety, with nearly every weapon having at the very least some minor unique quirk, and most weapons having full, unique movesets. The player's equipment choices are mostly personal preference: the weapons feel different and they're all perfectly viable when upgraded. Armour variety is also great, but what you wear doesn't make a huge difference. Resistances from armour are good, but dodging and blocking are far better tactics than eating hits.

The magic system is a bit intimidating at first. Highly limited amount of casts, and very long casting times. Three different schools of magic"
date: all of which feel powerful and interesting. Playing a sorcerer does make the game significantly easier
recommended: especially later on when items that increase magic damage are easily available.\n\nThe player character levels up by spending souls ( currency
hoursPlayed: essentially ) to level up individual stats ( strength

the classes only really determine the starting equipment: the classes don't lock a character into a single path.

Incredible freedom in the character development system; encourages replayability by having a massive amount of perfectly viable builds to come up with.

Enemy design is

reviewText: As the game title says, prepare to die. And when the developer says, you should really do that, because you're going to die, big time. Death in this game is like one of the main characters: you're going to encounter it as much as you possibly can imagine. The game is as straight as an arrow, but the level-design left me speechless. Bosses are hard, enemies are smart, riddles are tricky, death is around every corner almost every time. The game overall could be too hardcore for your average casual gamer, but it's certainly worthwhile. One of the best action-RPGs of the 2012. I'd give it 9 out of 10.

reviewText:
I originally played Dark Souls on the PS3 back in 2011 at launch, coming from Demon's Souls after about 100 hours or so, I was quite excited and avoided a lot of pre-release material, and all I could say was wow, and I still feel that way, if I were to add up the amount of time I've spent playing Dark Souls on PS3 and PC, I would estimate that I've put 1,000+ hours into the game, I also obtained the Platinum Trophy on PS3 for the game.

Nowadays, it seems a lot of developers are getting more scared to take risks, particularly the bigger guys making AAA titles, this is understandable as these companies will either stick to a winning formula, or follow the trend of what people are buying and liking, From Software on the other hand, has strived to make games that they find fun, rewarding, complex, varied and memorable, in this regard, Dark Souls 1 is a gem, and one of my all time favourite games.

There is absolutely a learning curve if you've never played the game(s) before, but once you get past this, you'll be surprised at really just how easy it is, knowledge is power when it comes to the Souls games, and as you obtain knowledge about the world, the weapons, the crafting system, the magic, general equipment, enemies, bosses and environments, you will be asking yourself why is this game considered so hard again?"

reviewText:
--DISCLAIMER--
first of all, in my review the thumb doesn't matter. I could also pick a thumbs down rating, Only the text review represents my oppinion about this game, nothing else.
The other thing is: I'm not someone who purely says that the game isn't possible. I'm just pointing out, what was enjoyable for me in an objective way. If you don't agree with my critics to this game, then it's fine by me. I'm not telling you what to enjoy and what not and if you actualy enjoy the things I don't enjoy, then have it your way. But then I ask you to respect my oppinion aswell as I respect yours.
--DISCLAIMER END--

Dark Souls is an interesting experience indeed. It always keeps you on your toes but it also gives you a break if needed.
It is a challenging game without being unfair to the player, at least overall to a certain point. It is an action RPG game to my liking but, unfortunatly, it has also alot of downsides.

First of all, and I'm sure everyone agrees with me is, that this is a very poor port of a game. It is a shame that there was no effort put into porting this game or even optimizing it in general, since a constant and high framerate in this kind of game is the most important aspect (timing in general). Now luckily, I have an Xbox controller for my PC and I highly recommend a controller in general for this game, since the controls on the keyboard are messed up. Now there are mods out there which help making this game playable, but I am talking about a product the developers delivered to us, not the fix that the community came up with without the developers giving a crap about there game and doing it themselves.

Now the most thing I enjoyed in this game was the first playthrough. I created 2 characters and managed to play through the game with both of them with 2 different playstyles. The first character was a more tanky character with a greatsword. My 2nd character was a high lightweigth build for pure dodge and counter with a katana. The game provided me with a decent challange and, although the game has it's frustrating moments, it never made me quit the playthrough.
NG+ (New Game +) on the otherhand is something I don't recommend to anyone searching for an enjoyable playthrough, simply because the difficulty scaling is to dull. Giving them more Healh and higher damageoutput doesn't mean difficulty, it just tests your patience with the game. I'd rather have smarter enemies with different attackpatterns instead of just heavylie based trial and error" enemies. This counts especialy for dodge builds. In most cases
date: if you happen to stagger from an attack
recommended: you will die because you'll get stunlocked untill you die. While this alone is not a problem
hoursPlayed: some enemies will be more of an annoyence because of their high hitbox detection (4 Kings for example) where it doesn't matter if you dodge their swing or not you'll get hit anyway.\n\nAnother positive thing about this game is that it doesn't hold you on your hand

Atrocious port, one of the best games ever made. 'Prepare to Die' is pretty accurate: the first half of the game is brutal.

Gameplay

Pretty much requires an Xbox360 controller. Mouse & keyboard controls are incredibly bad, and feel terrible even with a mouse fix mod.
DkS has the best melee combat outside Mount&Blade. Every swing has weight, every hit counts. Attacks are always telegraphed well in advance: everything can be dodged with proper timing. This works both ways, and it might take some time to get used to the player's attacks not being instant, but requiring a similar wind-up that the AI has.

Excellent weapon variety, with nearly every weapon having at the very least some minor unique quirk, and most weapons having full, unique movesets. The player's equipment choices are mostly personal preference: the weapons feel different and they're all perfectly viable when upgraded. Armour variety is also great, but what you wear doesn't make a huge difference. Resistances from armour are good, but dodging and blocking are far better tactics than eating hits.

The magic system is a bit intimidating at first. Highly limited amount of casts, and very long casting times. Three different schools of magic"
date: all of which feel powerful and interesting. Playing a sorcerer does make the game significantly easier
recommended: especially later on when items that increase magic damage are easily available.\n\nThe player character levels up by spending souls ( currency
hoursPlayed: essentially ) to level up individual stats ( strength
voteText: dexterity
helpfulPercent: etc. ). A single character can
votesHelpful: in theory
votesTotal: be a master of everything. Leveling up gets more expensive every time
votesFunny: so most of the time it's more advantageous to plan a build in advance and stick to it. At character creation
commentsCount:
the classes only really determine the starting equipment: the classes don't lock a character into a single path.

Incredible freedom in the character development system; encourages replayability by having a massive amount of perfectly viable builds to come up with.

Enemy design is
column16: overall
column17: excellent. They range from undead knights to giant mushrooms and clams. They all have unique movesets
column18: and despite the AI being very basic (run at player
column19: try to kill)
column20: the combat feels fresh when you move through the levels and encounter new enemies.\n\nThe levels are (for the most part) designed masterfully. A maze
column21: with shortcuts available everywhere. The world feels real: all the areas are connected perfectly
column22: and highly encourage exploration. Huge variety in the design of the levels: Duke's Archive is a huge library
column23: Tomb of the Giants
column24: a pitch black cave full of skeletons. Some areas
column25: like Lost Izalith
column26:
were clearly rushed and lack the complex geometry and intelligent enemy placement of levels such as Undead Burg.

Story

Highly unconventional storytelling in this one. Most of it is delivered through item descriptions accessed in the inventory. If you never read them
column27: all you'll really know is that there's a prophecy
column28: and you killed a bunch of dudes. The story hidden in the descriptions
column29: environment and NPC "quests" is absolutely brilliant
column30: however.\n\nHaving to dig for it makes figuring things out so much more rewarding than being told everything in cutscenes. There are 'holes' in the story
column31: and those are filled by the player
column32: and his actions. Everything in the game exists for a reason:  nothing is randomly just 'there'.\n\nI found the main storyline and the NPC stories extremely interesting
column33:
but it definitely takes some effort to be able to really enjoy.

Graphics & Audio

The graphics are terrible. Looks like a console game

reviewText:
I originally played Dark Souls on the PS3 back in 2011 at launch, coming from Demon's Souls after about 100 hours or so, I was quite excited and avoided a lot of pre-release material, and all I could say was wow, and I still feel that way, if I were to add up the amount of time I've spent playing Dark Souls on PS3 and PC, I would estimate that I've put 1,000+ hours into the game, I also obtained the Platinum Trophy on PS3 for the game.

Nowadays, it seems a lot of developers are getting more scared to take risks, particularly the bigger guys making AAA titles, this is understandable as these companies will either stick to a winning formula, or follow the trend of what people are buying and liking, From Software on the other hand, has strived to make games that they find fun, rewarding, complex, varied and memorable, in this regard, Dark Souls 1 is a gem, and one of my all time favourite games.

There is absolutely a learning curve if you've never played the game(s) before, but once you get past this, you'll be surprised at really just how easy it is, knowledge is power when it comes to the Souls games, and as you obtain knowledge about the world, the weapons, the crafting system, the magic, general equipment, enemies, bosses and environments, you will be asking yourself why is this game considered so hard again?"
date: just as I ask myself at this point when I play through it.\n\nThere is fantastic level of variety in all aspects of the game
recommended: when it comes to the enemies and bosses you encounter
hoursPlayed: the weapons you can use
voteText: the different armour sets
helpfulPercent: the spells and miracles you can obtain
votesHelpful: the locations and environments you come across and travel to
votesTotal: it all adds up to make you want to push on and master the game
votesFunny: and once you do obtain that level of skill
commentsCount: you'll understand why this game has such a hardcore
column16: passionate fanbase
column17: and one of the most dedicated in gaming as a whole.\n\nIn terms of character variety
column18: Dark Souls has a system we calls "builds"
column19: basically there's different starting classes to choose from
column20: each of which starts off with different stats and equipment
column21: frankly
column22: this only matters for the beginning of the game
column23: typically I will personally start off with a Knight
column24: and then level my stats in other areas to make a highly proficient Spellsword character
column25: I have made other builds as well
column26: but stat investment is VERY important
column27: weapons in the game also have what is called "scaling"
column28: and as well as leveling up weapons with the brilliant crafting system
column29: this scaling aspect will affect the damage you can do with a particular weapons based on your stats
column30: so for example
column31: a "Dexterity" or "Dex" weapon
column32: like a Scimitar
column33: will have a high "Scaling rank" (Like "A") when it comes to the Dexterity stat
column34: meaning that the more you level Dexterity
column35: the more damage you will do with that Scimitar
column36: scaling ranges from S (the best) all the way to E (the worst).\n\nAs far as the story goes
column37: mainstream reviewers criticized this part of the game for being non-existent
column38: and this is not the case
column39: the basis of the story is explained in the opening cutscene
column40: but the story and lore in general present themselves in a more mysterious way than most games out there do
column41: they present themselves through item descriptions
column43: and through emotion and general feeling
column44: by simply paying attention to what is going on while playing the game
column45: it's a superb way of telling a story and uncovering the rich lore of the game
column46: you'll find yourself making connections from one item description to another
column47: and coming up with your own theories for what may have happened
column48: if you look at VaatiVidya or Epicnamebro on YouTube
column49: you'll see that the story and lore are extremely deep and interesting
column50: and we all certainly had a lot of fun putting the pieces together back in 2011 and beyond
column52: we continue to come up with new theories and we continue to discover new things about the game
column53: which is incredible.\n\nThe Multiplayer of the game is incredible and super unique
column54: it hosts a realtime MP system which can be accessed without the need to go to another menu
column55: the MP relies on the use of in-game items including a "White Sign Soapstone" (in order to place your personal "sign" down and be summoned to help another player in their own world)
column56: and a "Red Eye Orb" which will allow you to invade and attempt to kill another player in their world
column57: there are other items in the game that allow for MP interaction
column58: and co-op of up to 3 players can take place
column59: the MP system can make for some extremely fun scenarios and some epic and fun battles.\n\nThe general sound in the game is amazing and perfectly fitting
column60: everything sounds just as it should
column61: the music that plays during boss battles is incredible
column63: I have nothing to complaint about in regards to the soundtrack
column64: it is amazing.\n\nAs far as the PC version goes
column65: it was disappointing at launch in a lot of regards
column67: it lacked a lot of the basic features a PC version of a game should have
column68: such as high resolution and framerate support
column70: a brilliant modder named Durante has since implemented a modification called "DSfix" which allows the game to run at higher resolutions and 60fps (albeit with a few issues when it comes to the higher fps)
column71: and also support for texture mods
column73: anyone has access to this tool and it's simple to download and install.\n\nOverall
column74: I cannot recommend Dark Souls enough
column75: if you are a fan of Fantasy Action RPG's with a dark tone

column82: armours and just about everything else
column83: you owe it to yourself to play this game

reviewText:
Praise the Sun!

Fantastically hard experience that offers little to no hand-holding both in and out of game.  The PC port is full of issues resolved in round-about ways by community mods.  If you don't go mad trying to get a resolution above 1024x720 (Tip: google DSFix), you'll wish you would have just bought a console instead when you try to get your mouse and keyboard to work (Tip: google DSMFix).  After you wade through a SEA of options hidden away in .txt files, and troubleshoot a dozen additional problems you may encounter, you're finally off to the races!

Of course, the races are probably going to punch you right in the mouth because this game can be so hard the metaphors don't even make sense.  The game doesn't tell you much, other players tell you even less, and you can throw yourself at an impossible cemetary of skeletons for hours without the game even suggesting there's an easier path.  You need to learn from your deaths quickly.  If you don't seem to be doing much damage, you're NOT going to survive so turn back and try another path!

Once you finally get on the slow, purposeful drudge to success, you'll meet all sorts of FANTASTICALLY designed monsters, see AMAZING set peices, and discover a deeply burried treasure-trove of lore.

Just keep in mind that if you want to experience the full effect of multiplayer, you have to stay human.  You can always see the fleeting ghosts of other players, and you'll find their cryptic orange messages scrawled all over the world, but if you want to meet them in the flesh you have to be living yourself.  Summon your white and golden allies whenever they offer to help.  Be wary though, others may come as an agent of chaos, as your righteous executioner, a collector of souls, or even as a guardian of nature.

At least it's not using Games for Windows Live anymore!

Above all, PRAISE THE SUN.

Dark Souls is like taking a really huge dump over and over.
It can hurt! It can REALLY hurt! You may bleed a bit!

reviewText:
NOTE: Get DSFix to change the game's internal rendering resolution to whatever you like and unlock the FPS to 30 or 60.

Oh, Dark Souls. The hardest game ever to hear some people talk, but in all honesty, the game's difficulty is vastly overstated. Yes, it can be brutal, and yes it's going to drop you into a big mean world full of intimidating uglies that want nothing more than to paint the walls with your warm red fluids, but NOTHING in Dark Souls is insurmountable. It's a game that merely plays on some of your worst habits as a player of games and will punish those who think they can rush things their first time through. It's tough, but fair.

Combat comes down to analyzing your enemies, knowing your weapon and defenses, and managing your stamina. You don't need an overpowered build to win any encounter, just awareness and the ability to react. Nearly every piece of equipment in the game is viable and allows the game to be played pretty much however you wish. (Just don't put ANY POINTS AT ALL into Resistance. It's pointless.) This is definitely not the kind of linear stat progression and equipment system most RPGs present players with, and the game feels much more satisfying overall since you have so much of a say in how you want to defend yourself.

Being dropped in fresh will be overwhelming at first since the game provides no real direction on how you need to progress, but exploring the dreary and imposing world of the undead is rewarding in itself. You'll never know what's around the next corner, but that's part of the fun. It's hard to think of many other games so focused on atmosphere and discovery these days in the same ways that Dark Souls is.

I can get why the game may not necessarily appeal to everyone, but those who can tough out those initial few hours are in for an immensely rewarding experience. One of the generation's best, right here.

reviewText:
One of the best games I've ever played. When this came out on the 360, I had no media knowledge of it (I recommend this for most hyped games) and came in completely blind. I got my ♥♥♥ kicked up and down because I thought it was a hack and slasher, obviously there is that but its much more controlled and precise.

Pros:
Level design - There are hardly any loading screens during the entire playthrough of this game, maybe a handful. The first 75% of the game is chock full of beautiful interconnected environments, and you will not get tired of running through them when you inevitably die :)

Combat - Very visceral and precise. You will be punished harshly for using the last of your stamina and missing that risky shot. There is dodging and rolling which give you the tools to dance around your enemies if you are skilled, but even a skilled player can easily be overwhelmed by an over aggressive group of enemies. One of the best parts of the game.

Enemies - Great variety of enemies and bosses, both challenging enough to not get tired out quickly.

Online play - Theres nothing besides boss fights that gets my heart pumping like my world getting invaded. These invasions keep you on your toes and give you such a rush when you kill your invader as well. The messages and summoning are also great aspects of the online play, with overused and sometimes witty messages popping up to describe the levels around you. If you find an area to hard, summon a friend!

Unfortunately summoning in some places is hard because there simply aren't enough players to find (especially within certain level ranges) to summon for a boss. Each boss is definitely killable via solo, but O&S boss will be tough if you cant find a co-op partner.

Dying actually matters in this game as well, so the sense of riskiness is always present when holding a large amount of souls and youre trying to decide whether or not to cash them in or save up more.

Cons:

Framerate - The framerate can get a little bogged down sometimes, especially in Blighttown. It was way worse on the 360 though.

The last sections of the game feel rushed and are not nearly as good as the rest (75%) of the game. This is not a huge con though because for the most part its great.

Lack of summoning in some places due to lower player counts is somewhat of a negative, especially if youre having a hard time with the boss.


All in all this game is a must buy for RPG fans, if you dont own it and youi call yourself one then please revoke your badge until its in your library :)
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This game.. There's a lot to it and  there's a lot to say about it.. Let me start off by saying that this game is pretty casual, it's not challenging whatsoever, it's almost as easy as Minecraft. But the fact of the matter is that it's super fun! You can play it with KBM (keyboard+mouse) WITHOUT any downloaded fixes that are required in order to make the game playable with KBM. If you have a controller, you can use it. But I'd say stick with KBM. The game itself is really unique, especially the humanity system, basically your character starts off as an undead without his humanity, unfortunately there are absolutely no pros for being an undead, only cons. You can restore your humanity by using an item called 'humanity', by doing so you will open the bridge between you and other players and it is AWESOME! When you become human, NOTHING BAD WILL EVER HAPPEN TO YOU. NEVER. Friendly people will ocasionally come to your world, helping you with the game if you're struggling (which would be weird because the game is pretty easy). You can go to other worlds as well! Only as human though.

Now the bosses. Oh, the good old bosses. They're average difficulty I'd say. You don't really need any tactics while fighting against them, they're just very predictable each encounter. Whenever I play this game, I CAN NOT WAIT for another boss battle because they're so relaxing and calming. Then there's this awesome RPG system, I must mention that you can not go wrong with your souls (the game's currency) spending, you can recklessly and without any thinking spend your souls into any stat you desire and it will not affect your game drastically. There's not a lot to choose from, weapon and armor wise. It's just enough to keep the game simple and casual.

If all of that didn't convince you to buy the game I'll list all the things to summarize everything.

Reasons to buy the game:
1. It's really casual.
2. It's not very challenging.
3. You can play this when you're in a bad mood or just feel sad. It will definitely cheer you up!
4. No need to think a lot how to spend your souls (the game's currency).
5. Boss fights are really relaxing and calming!
6. No fixes required to be downloaded in order to play the game using KBM (keyboard+mouse).
7. Controller is optional (not really worth using in my opinion since the game has full KBM support).
8. Everything I said is a load of crap, the game is fk-ing annoying and cancerous, for your first playthrough the bosses are fk-ing impossible and makes you want to slit your damn wrists and choke on your own blood (Bed of Chaos, Artorias etc.) .
9. The euphoric feeling that you get after beating every boss after countless tries and different approaches.. I sh-it you not, it's better than an org-asm. Your heart's racing, body shaking, palms sweaty, knees weak, arm's are heavy, mom's spaghetti.

In all honesty, this game is hard as sh-it, but it's the good kind of sh-it, you should definitely buy this game if you feel like everything you're playing is easy. It will definitely make you rage quit at least 20 times before finishing your first playthrough. I absolutely love it. I recommend you get the game and try for yourself. And if you do, here's the first tip, DON'T SPEND ANY SOULS IN RESISTANCE. And for Christ's sake, use a controller.

reviewText:
Dark Souls is like taking a really huge dump over and over.
It can hurt! It can REALLY hurt! You may bleed a bit!
But as soon as you made it you feel so incredibly relieved! And then it's time for the next dump!

To be serious it's not THAT hard. Yeah you die sometimes. No big deal.
As soon as you get used to the controls (controller strongly recommended) it's a fantastc game in an awsome dark fantasy setting where all npcs are depressed or insane unless they are sunbros. Sadly it has a really werid coop System that forces you to play a mayor part of the game by yourselfe even if you want to coop 24/7.
I would even call it a singleplayer game with the possibillity of killing bosses in jolly cooperation.
Oh, and PvP. PvP is ok.

8/10 Because i have feelings for Solaire of Astora!

reviewText:
One of the best games I've ever played. When this came out on the 360, I had no media knowledge of it (I recommend this for most hyped games) and came in completely blind. I got my ♥♥♥ kicked up and down because I thought it was a hack and slasher, obviously there is that but its much more controlled and precise.

Pros:
Level design - There are hardly any loading screens during the entire playthrough of this game, maybe a handful. The first 75% of the game is chock full of beautiful interconnected environments, and you will not get tired of running through them when you inevitably die :)

Combat - Very visceral and precise. You will be punished harshly for using the last of your stamina and missing that risky shot. There is dodging and rolling which give you the tools to dance around your enemies if you are skilled, but even a skilled player can easily be overwhelmed by an over aggressive group of enemies. One of the best parts of the game.

Enemies - Great variety of enemies and bosses, both challenging enough to not get tired out quickly.

Online play - Theres nothing besides boss fights that gets my heart pumping like my world getting invaded. These invasions keep you on your toes and give you such a rush when you kill your invader as well. The messages and summoning are also great aspects of the online play, with overused and sometimes witty messages popping up to describe the levels around you. If you find an area to hard, summon a friend!

Unfortunately summoning in some places is hard because there simply aren't enough players to find (especially within certain level ranges) to summon for a boss. Each boss is definitely killable via solo, but O&S boss will be tough if you cant find a co-op partner.

Dying actually matters in this game as well, so the sense of riskiness is always present when holding a large amount of souls and youre trying to decide whether or not to cash them in or save up more.

Cons:

Framerate - The framerate can get a little bogged down sometimes, especially in Blighttown. It was way worse on the 360 though.

The last sections of the game feel rushed and are not nearly as good as the rest (75%) of the game. This is not a huge con though because for the most part its great.

Lack of summoning in some places due to lower player counts is somewhat of a negative, especially if youre having a hard time with the boss.


All in all this game is a must buy for RPG fans, if you dont own it and youi call yourself one then please revoke your badge until its in your library :)
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Dark Souls is a splendid realization of an action RPG, beign well refined under both the aspects. Action gameplay includes dodging, parrying and blocking, while every weapon - and there are a lot - has its own moveset, multiplying the fighting possibilities against many different enemies.
The ambientation is dark and criptic; a deep and imaginative creature design builds a stunning dream-like atmosphere, while short npc dialogues and hidden plots clothe the adventure in a curtain of indifference.
The map is like a Rubik's cube: hidden connections and intricate geometries enrich every area, and at the end of the exploration, the whole path scheme is elegantly resolved.
The game is hard to master and requires a high level of concentration, because mistakes and superficiality are punished, in 99% of the case, with instant death. In addiction, no kind of help nor indications are ever provided to the player, which have to try and learn by his own.
Controls and camera are unfortunatly badly developed, eventually leading to some gameplay obstructions, while hitboxes needed a better precision.
New game plus and lots of way to customize characters extend the game experience to hundreds of hours, as every game run might have a different evolution.
Beign a true and solitary challenge, with little rewardings and tons of game over, DS is made for real gamers.

90/100

reviewText:
Dark Souls is an 'open-world' game in the vein of 'Metroidvania' titles, which is to say it's open ended but not as open ended as Western titles tend to be. The map design is such that areas are generally linear, but paths branch out at points into other linear areas, which either lead to dead ends  or to connections to previously explored areas, or a new area altogether. This design in linearity with branching paths and backtracking is synonymous with 'Metroidvania' titles. Ultimately all linear areas connect and its your duty to explore them thoroughly and keep a mental note of places you've yet to visit due to a present task, since its completion will then lead to yourself asking, ''where to next''.

''Oh right, there were those two areas that I didn't explore, time to get to it''

The old school comparison goes further, as the game also has a ton of secrets. This game's secrets can be divided into three categories: alternative paths in levels (self-explanatory); illusory walls (walls that, when struck, disappear thereby revealing a path); and item-environmental interactions. alternative paths and illusory walls typically contain items behind them, sometimes unique items and weaponry not attainable otherwise. ''item-environmental interactions'' are best described as items that are used/equipped in conjunction with being in a particular area. These are fewer in number, but lead to optional boss fights and optional areas to explore. There's a lot to love in a game that has a lot to uncover in addition to just straight up exploration.

Dark Souls is also an infamously difficult game, a reputation that isn't entirely merited. If you die you keep everything in your inventory minus Souls and Humanity; Souls being currency for weapon upgrades and levelling up whilst having more Humanity means better resistances and more item drops from enemies. Dying even once sounds bad, but the bonfires (which work as respawn locations and checkpoints) are always spaced apart evenly and you never lose much progress when you die since, in general, you can always get to where you previously were after death in as little as 1 minute or less.

As for Souls, in general losing them doesn't matter since enemies respawn everytime you rest at a bonfire, and you can easily grind them back again. Typically if you're in an area that gives you more than a third of the souls required for a level-up with each death then its beneficial to grind the area for levels rather than constantly dying and losing all those souls. With all the deaths you could've stopped dying and levelled up a bit more rather than wasting time. The idea is to not carry around a ton of souls because you will often die, but you will also often have a checkpoint just a few seconds away from your place of death anyway.

It's the type of challenge that is fair and welcolmed, but also highly overrated. There were a few spots that were difficult to get past due to enemy placement and level design, but typically if the area is hard to the point of causing rage inducing deaths, then either you shouldn't be there yet or you should but are slightly underlevelled and therefore can easily grind a few levels and upgrade weaponry and armor. Don't let talk of this being THE HARDEST GAME EVER dissuade you from trying it, because it's challenging but also fair and has levelling, which can, if EVERYTHING ELSE fails, just lead to you theoretically being level 100 with perpetual grinding and beating whatever area you're presently in.

Not that grinding matters anyway, you get the majority of your damage and defense from upgrading weapons and armor. Unlike most RPG's, your stats don't matter as much as you'd like them to. Weapons generally have stat requirements to wield them (typically in dexterity or strength), so your initial points will be to meet these requirements. But weapons also scale off those stats, so that mid to late game when you have a significant number of points into whichever stat said weapon scales off of, it does a lot more damage than before. So you have a dual system whereby weapon damage is dictated by its upgrades, but also by your stats. Different weapons scale differently as well; there's a rating system from S to E, where the higher the rating a weapon has on the spectrum for a particular stat the more damage it gets off said stat. This system dictates which weapons you wish to keep and wish you'd do away with (along with their attack animations), so the RPG elements and item management make this a sort of action-RPG/Metroidvania hybrid.

Speaking of 'Metroidvania', I'll harken back to the point and say that just like the first few Metroid titles Dark Souls also starts with as minimal a narrative as possible, and it's to its detriment. One of the hardest things in starting the game was giving a damn about it. You get a 4 minute cutscene in the beginning vaguely talking about Gods, and are then thrust into the gameworld with a very vague, ''go ring bells plz'' objective. It's very difficult for me to really get into something when there's no plot to it. I understand that no one wants an experience that sacrifices atmosphere for 100 NPC's and 500 cutscenes with PC's strung about the land detailing 10 pages of the game's plot in each.

But it's not a scenario whereby you have to sacrifice one to get the other. Dark Souls supposedly has a considerable amount of lore but good fuc*ing luck getting it all in-game in a comprehensive fashion. It's the type of lore that was pieced together by the fanbase after multiple playthroughs and really analyzing item descriptions. I assume the rest was either in developer interviews and artbooks or stuff that came in the later titles. Some is fan conjecture. It's such a shame because you can weave a narrative that takes advantage of the groundwork laid but if, for the majority that played the game, it dwindles down to, ''I gotta google it'' then you've failed to convey a story.

The game's narrative is akin to walking into a room mid-conversation with three people talking, or watching the last 20 minutes of a movie; you can understand it by the end of it if you piece it together, and if you were to view it again you could understand it all moreso but it's a REALLY bad way of relaying a story. It's one of those games that starts with the assumption that you already know what's going on, and talks about what's going on here and there. In other words, something that would require multiple playthroughs and rewatching and re-reading cutscenes/dialogue scenes to understand what the creators made. Like I said, it's a failure in story-telling and what prevents something from being damn close to perfect.

Plot aside everything else in the game is awesome, and if you're into the exploratory nature of Metriod titles (old and the Prime series) and are looking for an action RPG then you can't go wrong with this game. Very few games merit the praise they typically get, but Dark Souls lives up to expectations. You'll need to google the upgrade system as it pertains to weaponry, but otherwise the barrier to entry isn't as steep as you might imagine.

reviewText:
If you like to die, get this game.
No I mean it.

This game will be a big challenge for both your gaming skills but also your patience and psychology.
This might be the most difficult game that I have ever played. To be honest, I didn't have the patience to sit there and die, die, die, die, die, die, die, die and DIE all the time. But that's me.
The bosses are cool to fight, you need tactics, and sometimes even luck. Because they do different things from time to time, depends on where you are standing and stuff, so it can be hard to predict. It's not always easy to find a pattern.
There are a lot of bosses to beat, and even the mobs before bosses are dangerous, they can easily kill you.

I will go as far as telling you that you can't play this without a controller.
I did not finish the game, since I did not have the patience or heart to do so, my controller got a few punches and hits.

But even if this game is like this, it's still good.
If, and only if you have patience and LIKE to DIE all the time in a game, then get this.

reviewText:
Genre: RPG/Open World
If you're the person who loves challenge, and who don't mind dying a lot and also want to try new things, then you're gonna love this game. Otherwise if you're the person who plays games at easy/normal just so you can experience the game and move on avoid this. This game takes time, and to get better you need to die a lot.


Gameplay(+)
Gameplay is different than in other games and it doesn't feel that smooth in the beginning. Some people find it slow at first, but that's cause Dark Souls is one of the games that tries to be more realistic as far as the gameplay is concerned.

Weapons/Armors: You have two slots in each hand, for weapons or shields(you can put weapon or shield in whatever hand you want). You also have armor. You can combine parts of armor sets however you want. Game offers a big variety of weapons, armors, shields etc. There are many classes of weapons: Straight swords, Greatswords, Ultra Greatswords, Axes, Katanas, Hammers, Whips, Bows and many others. When choosing armors and weapons you need to worry about their weight and your equip load. Other than weight weapons and shields also have stats requirements. Usually you need certain amount of points invested into Strength or Dexterity, or both, and sometimes you need to invest into magic, miracles etc. Some weapons scale of strength, some of dexterity, and some of both, which means that increasing those stats increases weapons damage, and also weapons have different types of scaling. You can also upgrade weapons, shields and armors with some materials and souls(souls=Dark Souls money and exp points).

Magic/Miracles: Game also offers a big variety of magic spells and miracles. They have their stats requirements too. You need to invest points into intelligence/faith to increase magic/miracles attack and defense, and to be able to use those spells/miracles. There are  additional items that improve magic or miracles attack or defense.

Enemies: Enemies are very creative, there are many type of enemies and a lot of them are hard to kill at first. Boss fights are absolutely amazing, and killing a boss in Dark Souls feels like great accomplishment. Game has plenty of bosses, and many of them are optional. After killing the boss you'll get souls. Some bosses also drop boss souls which you can either eat to accuire more souls or save them for later, so you can craft boss weapons at blacksmiths. Every time you die enemies will respawn at same places, but bosses won't. Once you kill them, they're dead till the next new game + cycle.

New Game +: After you finish the game, you'll automatically progress into new game +, with everything that you've collected in ng. You can play ng+ endlessly, and the game's difficulty increases every time untill you reach ng+7, where it stops increasing.

Some other things about gameplay: Bonfires are checkpoints in this game. Every time you rest at bonfire, all enemies will go back to their place, and all enemies will respawn, except from killed bosses. Every time you die you lose all souls you have and you need to find that same location to pick them up before you die again, unless you want to lose them forever. After dying you'll respawn at last checkpoint you had been rested.

Multiplayer(+)
This is one of the things that makes Dark Souls games pretty unique. You can invade worlds of other players with special items and fight them there, or get invaded in your own world. You can also call other players from their worlds by activating signs on the floor with purpose to either fight them or play co-op with them, and you can post your own signs too.


Atmosphere(+)
One of the things that makes Dark Souls so great is dark and gloomy atmosphere, that makes you feel lonely in that cruel world. Not knowing what's behind the next corner, it forces you to have your eyes wide open all the time.


Story/Lore(+)
Story in Dark Souls is not told in the classical way. To find explanation of the story you must listen to what NPCs have to say, and read descriptions of items, and still after that you're not gonna be able to understand a lot of things, so you must create your own theories about what happened. There are good theories on internet from youtubers like VaatiVydia, Silver Mont, Dave Control Live, TerraMantis,etc.


Bad port(+-)
This is really a bad port, and it's almost unplayable without DSfix which can be found here: http://blog.metaclassofnil.com/?p=684 .You can't get banned for using this, and almost every Dark Souls player uses this. Port by default is locked at 30 fps, but DSfix lets you unlock fps, and it also makes game pretty stable with improved graphic. Still some people complain that they have dips with unlocked fps and set on 60, but I really can't help you with that since I am playing on 30 fps since beginning without any problems.

Verdict: This is an an amazing, very challenging game, and that combined with an amazing gameplay, atmosphere and lore makes it a masterpiece. Sadly it is an awful port, but there is a mod that fixes most of the issues.

Personal rating: 10/10

reviewText:
I played this game all the way through the first non-tutorial boss. this includes a big detour fighting some skeletons in a graveyard for about an hour before my friend told me that those things should have been killing me and I was supposed to go the other way. Basically the whole thing is a giant patience test, where the only way you ever die is by being greedy and wanting to end an encounter sooner by getting more hits in. When the only way you can lose is if you're anxious for the central gameplay to be over with sooner, there's something seriously wrong in the game's design.

If this game is challenging, it's after the first boss, who I beat on the first try because he telegraphed everything like mad.

If this game is atmospheric, it's after the first boss, because I just had generic medieval castle to go through.

If this game is rich or deep in story, it's after the first boss (and an NPC who talks to you a while afterward), because I still have no idea what the series is about or how anything is supposed to work (including a lot of gameplay elements, for which there is no written information anywhere - wiki walks are fine for sandbox games but just annoying in a beat 'em up).

If a game doesn't give me a reason to play it by the end of the first real area, then either it has nothing to offer, or it's stringing me along instead of respecting me as a customer. Either way DS1 was a huge letdown and I really don't get all the hype.

In a word, the game is tedious"

reviewText:
Great game! There is a fairly steep learning curve, and it is a difficult game, but success in the end is very rewarding. There are a wide variety of spells, weapons, armors, and techniques at your disposal; and there are unique pros and cons to each. The game also looks great, especially if you are using DSfix.

The storyline is pretty fantastic as well. There are several sub-plots as well and they will differ based on your actions.

Gameplay is absolutely wonderful. Truly a skill game, there are very few points where you feel like there was nothing you could do, or that you got cheated by the game into dying.

reviewText:
You will loathe yourself for playing this game.

Let me explain: it is the most sadisticly addicting games ever created.

Let me furher explain: This game will test your skill as a gamer and you patience as a human being. Its challenges are numerous and seemingly endless. You will die and die and die again then, probably, hurl your remote (or keyboard, I'd highly recomend a remote though) across what ever space you are playing in and swear that you will never play it again... But then like Rihanna you come crawling back begging for more. The worst thing about all of this is that even though it will make you want to rip your teeth out, you'll love every second of it. The feeling of finally figuring out how to beat a challenge is so amazing at times you might feel like throwing a small party in celebration, and the rush you get when beat the game (your tormentor for the past many hours of game play) is even more so. You will be hard pressed to find a gaming experience as thrilling and rewarding as sDark Souls, as soon as you start playing it will become your most hated addiction.

reviewText:
You've crushed me under boulders, had me torn apart by giant bugs, cursed by googly-eyed frogs, spooked solid in a flooded ghost town, thrown off the side of a cliff from a giant mushroom-man, poisoned from a swarm of mosquitoes, squashed by a hot chick with a spider body, and skewered by an oversized dude with an oversized spear.

I've traveled through labyrinths filled with gassy frogs and sprinted for my life in caverns full of man-eating clams. I got lost in a giant library guarded by lizards, octopi, and people made out of crystals. Hell, I even met up with a giant talking snake with a nose and ears in the middle of a black void at one point.

Although you keep smacking me across the face, pushing me off cliffs, and throwing the wierdest mosters I've ever seen at me, you're still one of my most hated favorite games. I'm talking about you, Dark Souls.

Dank Souls Game of the Year 2016

reviewText: This game is bloody ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fantastic! It has a steep learning curve, for sure. But it rewards the patient and persistent. One can easily glance over the story since it isn't presented in the same way that most AAA games today present their stories. But the world of Lordran is full of deep, interesting lore. The game may seem like it plays stiff at first, but the combat is actually fairly intricate and quick reactions can mean the difference between life and death. From beginning to end, you feel like you're just a frail human up against the world and its gods. And because of that, you'll feel all the more accomplished when you finally triumph over them all.\n\nAnd I can't write a review for this game without mentioning the incredible community. I feel online play is an essential part of this game. Whether I'm bringing in a sunbro or two to help me bring down a boss or I'm getting invaded by Dickwraiths every 5-10 minutes, I've always had fun with it. Every coop fight feels like an epic brothers-in-arms" struggle. Every invasion
date: even the ones where I get roflstomped and mocked
recommended: feels like another hurdle that I have to give my all to overcome. Also
hoursPlayed: the humor that comes out of this game's community...just beautiful.\n\nPeople praise or condemn this game for its difficulty. I feel the difficulty comes mostly from the fact that the game respects you as a player: It doesn't pull any punches and it doesn't take you by the hand to guide you through it. It acts as though it assumes you have the capability to overcome what it throws at you. Still feeling overwhelmed? You can seek help from the community through messages on the ground or possibly even from walkthroughs if you're truly desparate. It's part of the lore after all. And so are the troll messages
voteText: watch out for those haha.\n\nI didn't expect it but this game quickly became one of my favorite games once I started playing it. I feel that this is something that all gamers should at least experience. It's not perfect but nothing is. That said

reviewText:
Dark Souls.... doesnt the name just make you cringe?! Well, it shouldn't!

People will play games forever, whether it's marbles or Dark souls, but either way, somebody is gonna rage quit! some people will play a video game just to 'Beat' it. However, this game does it a little different.... instead of giving you a choice of beating it or not, it decides for you - and it's never in your favour! This game beats you.... to a pulp.... then runs you over in it's car.... and gets it's mates to help beat the crap out of you.... not even exaggerating a little bit!

But why should that scare you off? It's just a game right?

Wrong, ♥♥♥♥♥♥!

This is more than a game, it's an achievement, an accomplishment, a challenge and a test for all gamers out there!
This game is not reccomended for those who are prone to rage quitting, and it's definately not for the faint at heart!

'But what's the point if im just going to die all the time?'

Shut up, you're adopted! let me tell you what's in store for you!

The rewards may be a few souls and a weapon.... but thats in game! Inside your head you have just played the same part of the game about 500 times, and you've died equally. You were about to walk away when you gave it one more shot!

finally, you got the SOB down to its last bit of health and you stabbed it right in the ♥♥♥♥♥! You stood with your head held high when you finally killed that boss and you made it known that you owned it and you had intercourse with it's mother while shouting at the screen. The satisfaction levels are over 9000, and you could even say that you smiled after so much anger and frustration.... and trust me when i say that THAT very smile feels amazing!

this game will take you a LONG time to finish..... the first area..... let alone the whole game! but it's not about time, its about how much you want it! it's about your desire to accomplish something! You can say to your weaker friends 'Hey look noob, i finished Dark Souls! what did you do in the last 600 hours of your life?'

having said that, this game IS NOT a waste of time at all! if you play for an hour and dont even get to a new bonfire (Checkpoint [Very Rare]) dont decide it's no use, just keep trying.... there are more secrets in this game the illuminati dont even know whats going on!! Look for shortcuts, try new areas dont get caught in a rut!

So yeah, thats what i think anyway! please consider playing this game (If you can get it working on steam [Need a games for windows account])

Dark Souls..... You are worthy of nothing less...
9.3/10
Dylan Burton

reviewText:
What can I say about Dark Souls that hasn't been said before?

It's fantastic. It's unrelenting, challenging, stimulating and at times, incredibly frustrating. But all of those things are precisely why the game is so great. It doesn't hold your hand. It doesn't let you save whenever you want. It forces you to think and use reasoning. Instead of relying on the game mechanics to save you, you must learn to use it to your advantage. Once you take control, it's an incredibly rewarding experience unmatched by most modern action RPGs.

This game will go down in history along with the likes of Elder Scrolls, Final Fantasy and Legend of Zelda.

reviewText: Dark Souls brings back the toughness in games. Remember playing Zelda on the NES? Remember how hard it was to find everything as a kid? But when you achieve whatever it was you were trying to do, you seriously ♥♥♥♥ your pants and punch your baby in the face in joy. You scream at your wife and tell her you want a divorce. Thanks Dark Souls.

reviewText:
You awaken in a prison cell, hollowed and stripped of all humanity. You are an Undead, a cursed being trapped within the purgatory that is the Undead Asylum. Who you are and what brought you here are a mystery. The curse makes one forget it seems. As you break out of your cell messages written with soapstone start to appear. Slowly you will make your way through the Asylum, heeding the cautionary tales written by those who came before you. You will seek comfort in the warm embrace of the bonfire, an oasis amidst the rubble and death. Before long however, you will be faced with insurmountable odds in the form of the Asylum Demon. This is where you will most likely die. However death isn't the end of things, you're an Undead after all. Soon you'll feel the warm embrace of the bonfire once more. At this point you will try again, again and again. Until at long last you slay the beast and are liberated from this place. This is where Dark Souls starts and your journey begins.

That journey will be beautiful and engaging. The world you'll explore, the characters you'll meet are all lovingly crafted and will stick with you until long after. The gameplay is brutally unforgiving and exceptionally rewarding. Every bit of progress you'll make in this game will be a personal victory. It is incredibly captivating, challenging and simply put fun. If you are looking for a lengthy hands off narrative with compelling, tense action orientated D&D style gameplay. Then do yourself a favor, pick this game up and praise the sun!

That being said, it is not without it's faults. The port of this game is sloppy to say the least. Natively it runs at sub par resolutions and has it's gamelogic locked at 30fps. This means that out of the box this game is practically unplayable for most PC gamers. Luckily there are ways to fix these glaring issues in the form of DSFix. (V2.4 at the time of this writing) It is a third party injector created for Dark Souls Prepare To Die Edition that enables you to alter render settings at the engine level.

All in all I can not recommend Dark Souls enough.

reviewText:
You have to learn the moveset of every boss in order to beat him - let's take knight Artorias for example - the boss fight is so good you have to experience it to know what I am talking about. You will die maybe 4-5 times and then you start changing your tactic. After you learn every move the knight Artorias has, you can kill him if you are careful. It took me over 18 tries. I died 18 times trying to kill him, and I was HAPPY about it. The feeling of dopamine and endorphine flooding your brain after you finally beat the boss is the greatest feeling I ever had in gaming.

I wish I could erase my memory of playing this game, forget absolutely everything about it (beacuse at this point I probably know almost everything, even that the Ingward returns to Firelink Shrine after you talk to him after beating Four Kings, I found this information after 3 years of the game being out) and play the game all over again.
The Best game I have ever played, I have the sweetest memories about the time I first played Dark Souls.
I love Dark Souls. So should you, if you give it a chance.
