reviewText: Dark Souls is a very difficult 8/10. The underlying game is genius, truly wonderful that eggs you on to discover what lays around the next corner. The fusion between Fighting game, Adventure, RPG is almost magical. But it is let down by it unforgiving personality. Some of the bosses I beat first time round (so it's not a skill problem), and nearly all of the bosses (up to the Lordvessel) were destroyed within a handful of attempts. However, this game really shouldn't take 50-60 hours to complete! A lot of that is wandering around trying to figure out what to do next, or trying to figure out the game logic. This game would be 10/10 if it was designed so that the same content (main) would take the average user 30 hours at most to complete. The first 30 hours were amazing for me, but it just became a plod and some of the later bosses felt like boring trial and error until something worked. Some of the challenge was not real challenge" either. It was bad level design (even though overall the level design was rather superb)

reviewText:
You have to learn the moveset of every boss in order to beat him - let's take knight Artorias for example - the boss fight is so good you have to experience it to know what I am talking about. You will die maybe 4-5 times and then you start changing your tactic. After you learn every move the knight Artorias has, you can kill him if you are careful. It took me over 18 tries. I died 18 times trying to kill him, and I was HAPPY about it. The feeling of dopamine and endorphine flooding your brain after you finally beat the boss is the greatest feeling I ever had in gaming.

I wish I could erase my memory of playing this game, forget absolutely everything about it (beacuse at this point I probably know almost everything, even that the Ingward returns to Firelink Shrine after you talk to him after beating Four Kings, I found this information after 3 years of the game being out) and play the game all over again.
The Best game I have ever played, I have the sweetest memories about the time I first played Dark Souls.
I love Dark Souls. So should you, if you give it a chance.

reviewText: This game is bloody ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ fantastic! It has a steep learning curve, for sure. But it rewards the patient and persistent. One can easily glance over the story since it isn't presented in the same way that most AAA games today present their stories. But the world of Lordran is full of deep, interesting lore. The game may seem like it plays stiff at first, but the combat is actually fairly intricate and quick reactions can mean the difference between life and death. From beginning to end, you feel like you're just a frail human up against the world and its gods. And because of that, you'll feel all the more accomplished when you finally triumph over them all.\n\nAnd I can't write a review for this game without mentioning the incredible community. I feel online play is an essential part of this game. Whether I'm bringing in a sunbro or two to help me bring down a boss or I'm getting invaded by Dickwraiths every 5-10 minutes, I've always had fun with it. Every coop fight feels like an epic brothers-in-arms" struggle. Every invasion
date: even the ones where I get roflstomped and mocked
recommended: feels like another hurdle that I have to give my all to overcome. Also
hoursPlayed: the humor that comes out of this game's community...just beautiful.\n\nPeople praise or condemn this game for its difficulty. I feel the difficulty comes mostly from the fact that the game respects you as a player: It doesn't pull any punches and it doesn't take you by the hand to guide you through it. It acts as though it assumes you have the capability to overcome what it throws at you. Still feeling overwhelmed? You can seek help from the community through messages on the ground or possibly even from walkthroughs if you're truly desparate. It's part of the lore after all. And so are the troll messages
voteText: watch out for those haha.\n\nI didn't expect it but this game quickly became one of my favorite games once I started playing it. I feel that this is something that all gamers should at least experience. It's not perfect but nothing is. That said
helpfulPercent: this game still provided an experience beyond my expectations.\n\n10/10
votesHelpful: Grossly incandescent"

reviewText:
+ Hard, but fair gameplay
+ Interesting, memorable world and locations
+ Amazing music
+ Rich lore
+ NPCs have their own side-quests which you can follow
+ You can do whatever you want, you see that super important NPC? Kill him and see what happens.
+ No pause button, only time you can have rest is at bonfire
+ No saving, if you kill someone usefull you gotta handle game without their assist till end of the game
+ Very interesting Covenants allowing you to e.g. protect forest and invade players who dare to make step inside.
+ Character can be build in a lot of different ways, light armor, magic, shields or bows, its up to player.
+/-Sometimes can feel lost without idea where to proceed
- Can be frustrating when sitting in one place for too long
- Few bosses can be killed with few hits or without even fighting due to implemented exploits.
- PC port

Do I recommend this game? Hell yes, its one of best games I ever played.

reviewText:
Truly one of the best Action Role-Playing Games of all time.

From Software combined realism and RPG elements for one of the most unique and satisfying combat systems ever created. Enemies and bosses alike based around this combat system creates the most fun I've ever had killing anything in any game EVER.

Pros: Well designed enemies, weapons, bosses, armor, you name it. The world is immersive, the gameplay fun and challenging, the characters believable, and the lore interesting. Fun enough to outweigh all the cons.

Cons: Bugs, faulty physics, anything below Lower Undead Burg, Duke's Archives, difficulty spikes, hackers, Windows Live, and some enemies (Bonewheels, Torch Hollows, Misquitos, Ghosts, etc.) are incredibly cheap, the PC controls are absolutely horrific (thank god you can use an Xbox controller, with one the controls are great and responsive).

Overall, the good parts of the game completely outweigh the bad. Sometimes you just need to consider the cons a necessary challenge so you don't smash your controller.

I give Dark Souls an 87/100.
To put things into perspective, this is my favorite game of all time.

reviewText:
This game is one of my favorite games and does many things extremely well, but does suffer from some flaws that will cause many people to miss out on experiencing the game.

My criticism is that the PC port of this game is awful and you must resort to outside fixes to make the game playable. The DSFix mod and the recent switch from GFWL to Steam for the online component of the game both allow you to play the game, but shouldn't be necessary in the first place. There are also some glaring flaws in the game design that are an added annoyance in the already frustrating game (looking at you Bed of Chaos).

Now for everything that I love about Dark Souls. The amount of work that FromSoft put into the level design is astounding. Everything just seems to flow perfectly, your eyes are drawn to (or away from) things that you are supposed to find. Unlocking a shortcut or finding a new path can sometimes stop you in your tracks and blow your mind. The characters, the lighting, and the scenery all come together to immerse you in the world, every playthrough I find myself pausing from time to time to just stop and gaze at everything around me. You get the sense that you’re a part of something so much bigger than yourself (literally in a lot of ways). The lore is deep and rich, but you only scratch the surface in game, everything else is mystery or up to your interpretation. The frustration and feeling of accomplishment that follows. Getting stuck in an area and subsequently beating it is so satisfying.

I can only recommend Dark Souls to someone that is not only willing to face the difficulty of playing the game, but also the difficulty of making the game playable.

Good luck to all the Chosen Undead out there!

Praise the Sun!   \[T]/

reviewText:
Dark Souls... said to be one of the hardest games made in many years. Well, this review is from a 100% Completionist of the game :D

Ok, so to start, Dark Souls: Amazing game. Great storyline, large variety of combat styles, plenty of sorceries & miracles to mix the game up a bit. Overall, super fun. Dark Souls... however does have its own infamous quirks, such as its ridiculous difficulty compared to modern AAA titles. Features like no Health Regen, No Map for guidance, Enemies with the ability to One-Hit Kill even in the best Armour, etc etc.

Does this make it bad? Certainly not! For me (and thousands of others), its a welcoming change to the overly-easy game market nowadays. Really makes you think how to approach the next room, or avoid the next bosses attack patterns.

Ok, on to my personal ratings of the game:

Pro's
> Deep Lore for Storyline Background.
> Amazing variety of areas & enemies to take on
> Very Ambient & Atmospheric Soundtrack
> Large variety of Weapons & Magics to choose from
> Unique approach to Co-Op / Multiplayer
> Requires Strategy, and not just Blarargahrgara run in and swing

Con's
> Occassional frame rate drops in certain areas
> Bosses can glitch out sometimes & either insta-kill or insta-die
> Lacks information on how to progress at certain points

Overall, I think the Positive outweigh the Negative alot!

And being this is the Prepare to Die Edition, it comes with the Artorias of the Abyss Expansion, which is verrrrry fun and very different compared to the base game :3

Would I recommend Dark Souls? Yes. Especially if you enjoy a game that will make you struggle to beat, then this is the perfect title to pick up ASAP!

9.5/10 would 100% Achievements Again! XD (Seriously, that nearly killed me to do :P )

reviewText: This goes high on the list of games that are truly my favorites, and that surprises me because I have yet to defeat the whole game! Endless deaths and trial somehow push me through wanting to collect my souls for a level up and move on through a tough boss battle. The game is very punishing but rewarding in all the right ways, making me come back for more each time. If you like a challenge, are prepared to die many times, and enjoy unique level designs then this is the game for you. I don't just recommend this game but i highly recommend it. I've become addicted to it and I am an overall BAD player. I suck. If I can do it so can you. I can promise that its well worth your time. Practice makes perfect in a game like dark souls. The lore is rediculously interesting and the amount of replayability is high as well. There is a lot to do in this game and every time you move forward you will feel relief and happiness before the despair of realizing the next area you are about to go to seems to be an even bigger trial than before. Its all part of the fun!

reviewText: Dark Souls é um RPG Dungeon Crawler Hardcore de Hack and Slash de uma jobabildade excecional. O design e arte dos inimigos e masmorras bem como o seu combate são as estrelas deste jogo. Que é díficil mas justo, com um ambiente de fantasia medieval profundo, encantador e mortal. Onde a morte nos espera em cada canto mas que mesmo assim nos convece a ficar lá. É um dos melhores jogos do género. Possuí também uma história mistoriosa e complexa mas coerente e muito bem feita (que tem uma ligação forte ás sequelas). E também um modo de Multijogador (Co-Op e PvP) bastante divertidos.\nSimplesmente um clássico e uma peróloa de jogo.\nDark Souls é suberbo, profundo, encantador, perigoso, dícifil, justo, poderoso, glorioso, coerente, inesquecivel, indispensável e épico!

reviewText: This game is not beginner friendly and most new players are going to hit a brick wall for a few hours. But, once you start to get a grip on the game, it's very rewarding. It's an amazingly deep and complex RPG that rewards exploraration and skill. I actaully tried this game many months ago and had really bad first impressions because of the difficulty. But, I decided I really wanted to experience this game, so I picked it up again. One thing to note is this a really bad PC port, but at least it doesn't have GFWL anymore. Now, you can unlock the framerate without getting kicked off of GFWL. I highly recommend getting at least DSFix. Lastly, please use a controller for this game. If you're not going to use a controller, you're better off not playing it all to be honest.

reviewText:
Dark Souls is the very definition of a game. It has action, it has stats evolution, it has an intrisic rich lore and universe that's there for those who wish to dwell into the story, but it also has one of the best and most beautiful level designs of all time. It's highly dificult, it's ruthlessly punishing, it's highly rewarding. One of the few games I can't get enough and keep replaying over and over again,  and even doing countless attempts of (utterly failed) speedruns. Possibly the most perfectly structured game of all time. One of my all time favorites.

Always remember:
1. Be patient.
2. Don't get greedy.
3. Study your enemies and surroundings.
4. Persevere.

(PS: ♥♥♥♥ Bed Of Chaos. Just ♥♥♥♥ it.)

reviewText:
If the horror stories are to be believed, Dark Souls is a punishing game that only those with infinite patience will ever see the end of. As with so many legends, there’s a grain of truth to these claims that’s been exaggerated out of proportion; yes, Dark Souls is a merciless beast whose demanding nature will put off a lot of people. But is it insurmountable for the average gaming enthusiast? I’d argue no.

After a cryptic intro that raises more questions than it answers, Dark Souls places you in a prison cell armed with only a broken sword. On top of that, your character died before you even had a say in their life. All this sets the tone for an adventure that pulls no punches, and by the time you find a decent weapon you’ll have already run into some lethal creatures. But there’s nothing inherently unreasonable about the opening segment of gameplay; you’re told what buttons do what, then given a weapon and left to figure out the most efficient means of killing stuff with it. The result is a game that trains you to approach new areas with caution, never underestimate an opponent, and always have an escape route if things go ♥♥♥♥-up. It’s an intriguing hybrid of old and new game design, sans most of the cryptic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ your nostalgia doesn’t let you remember.

The combat is the dominant gameplay feature, of course, and I don’t hesitate to call it some of the best I’ve seen: a dagger feels completely different from a giant hammer, and neither can be called definitively better than the other. Dodging attacks and getting backstabs is a legitimate tactic, but so is tanking damage and punching through blocks with heavy weapons, not to mention the abundance of magical options I was too scared to try for a long time. It’s a strategic experience that something like Skyrim can barely dream of unless modded up the wazoo.

Speaking of strategy, Dark Souls is one of precious few games that actually give meaningful penalties for death. Every time you die, you lose your accumulated points and have precisely one chance to retrieve them. If you ♥♥♥♥ that up, the points are gone forever. It’s harsh, to be sure, but checkpoints are never obscenely far apart and I learned early on that if you know your downfall is imminent, you might as well try and die in a spot that can be reached easily. It’s just another system to use to your advantage and will only screw you over if you push your luck: know when to retreat and spend your points, rather than lose them deep in enemy territory. That the entire world respawns when you use a checkpoint is bizarre at first, yet makes a lot of sense to me; sitting at a bonfire becomes a tactical decision, since it provides safety at the cost of undoing your progress elsewhere. And as crushing as it is to lose your hard-earned points, those moments are also the best times to throw yourself at a boss or speed through a tough area to grab items.

Navigating the metroidvania landscape is the other great art of Dark Souls. Locales are varied (along with their inhabitants) and frequently bigger than they first appear, overflowing with hidden loot, shortcuts and even optional bosses. Backtracking does become a nuisance beyond a certain point, and the teleport option is hard-earned, but the only places I truly dislike are the handful suffering from framerate dips (on consoles) and finicky platform segments. Other than that, I find the game’s setup enjoyable, not least due to its role in one of Dark Souls’ most surprising triumphs: storytelling.

There’s a wealth of lore to be found in subtle background details and item descriptions, and it really felt like I was piecing together the world’s history from the clues left behind. The slow realisation of just how boned the land is fits perfectly with the sense of dread pervading the gameplay, and even your character’s ability to rise after death is contextually justified. For a game that could’ve relied solely on its combat, I find it doubly impressive that Dark Souls manages to have a memorable world, and with a minimalistic style that’s refreshing in an industry whose attempts at storytelling often rely on overwritten cutscenes.

Another remarkable aspect of Dark Souls is the online integration: players can leave messages that randomly pop up in people’s worlds. Some are helpful, some are amusing, and some are outright lies. Then you have a clunky but workable co-op mechanic, along with the danger of being invaded by other guys whenever you de-zombify yourself. The whole arrangement is seemingly unique to the Souls franchise, and has created a profound sense of community while also reminding you that nobody can be trusted.

At its core, Dark Souls represents a raw yet fair challenge where death is almost never anyone’s fault but the player’s. And while your initial perception may be one of cruel chaos, dig deep enough and you’ll find a sense of order. By almost any measure, I think Dark Souls must be called an impressive piece of work. The only question is whether you’ll enjoy an action game which requires you to be methodical and treat every fight like a matter of life and death. Unlike some parts of the fanbase, I understand that it’s possible to not like something for reasons other than sucking at it.

reviewText:
Dark Souls, I consider it to be one of my favoirte games of all time. Dark souls has many things going for it but also some negatives about it as well.

What is Dark Souls: Prepare To Die Edition? Dark souls is an Open World, Action RPG and a very good one at that. You are a Chosen Undead who is suddenly freed from a prision cell and begin your quest to venture out into the world that is Lordran to find out what is happening in this Depressing and Dying World and what you, the Chosen Undead, must do. Gameplay focuses mostly on PvE(Player vs. Enemy's) and if you wish to take part in PvP(Player Vs. Player) that is up to you. Combat in the game is mostly melee combat but also uses sorceries, pyromancy, miracles, and ranged combat(bow and Arrows). Pretty basic stuff.
Souls, which is the games currency, can be used to buy various items from NPC's throught the world as well as Level you up(if you have the required amount to level up)

What's so good about this game that people always talk about it?
Well for starters one of the key features I found to personally be my favorite is that it gives you no direction whatsoever. I don't have a mini-map telling me where to go or what objectives i need to do. It just throws you into this Huge world and that's it. Go on and explore it all you want. Second is the story it tells. Most games normally have a cutscence in-game and tell you about the story and so on. In this game, the story is all around you. The Boss souls you aquired, the NPC armor sets, rings, items, etc., each have their own little story to tell in this world. Lore is everywhere, your job the find it and piece together what has happened in this world or what has happened to the NPC's. Another is Graphics. Tho Graphics don't really affect gameplay but the game looks beautiful on it's max settings as well as the lack of lighting in some areas give that immersive feeling to the game. Combat system is tight although it does have it flaws for PvP, but besides that it works just fine. Another i feel is a good thing is the Trial and Error system in place. Let's say your going to fight a boss for the first time and die, the game DOES NOT and WILL NEVER hold hands with you.  The game expects you to LEARN from your mistakes about why you failed to kill this boss or enemy. If you keep going in, not learning from your mistakes and expecting anything will work, you are wrong. Learn form your mistakes and perform better and you will be greatly rewarded for your tirals.

While this game is great it indeed has it's flaws.
Diffiulty in this game is high. This game will be very difficult for anyone new since you are expected to know the mechanics quickly after the tutorial area is done. I, myself, am guilty of raging and not playing this game for a while but i got my act together and finished it. Lack of knowledge is another one. Although i did mention this as a pro but it can also be a con if one doesn't know where to go and what to do. Although it should be fairly simple where to go in my opinion. Next is about the networking issues. Standard game has some issues indeed which is why you need to download the DS Fix if you want to play PvP and summon friends to aid you. Next would be PvP networking. Sometimes if either you or the host have bad connections, either party can have a bad time at fighting against each other such as lag backstabs and lag hits as well as host disconnects. Shame but it happens so be wary of these.

So is this game worth getting? Is Dark Souls, the game considered to be the hardest ever made, good?
To answer both those questions I say Yes and ♥♥♥♥ YES
This game brings alot to the table and more if you wish to have a varied experice trying out different covenants, builds and PvP. Excellent game if you wish for a true challenge that will challenge your intelligence and how you can handle yourself in certain situations.

IMPORTANT STUFF *READ IT*
As a sidenot that it is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED to have a controller. As the keyboard and mouse is ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Also it is HIGHLY RECOMMENDED that you have the DSC Fix which is a mod to improve networking in the game. Also there is a possible issue with the windows live and market that will auto install after you finish downloading it via steam. When it's finished downloading be sure to uninstall live and marketplace and then download the latest version via windows live website. As this will fix the issue of your gaming crashing 3-5 seconds after launching it because of the old windows live issue.

reviewText:
My favorite Dark Souls game out of the two that have been made thus far.

It's a love/hate relationship with this game, mostly good. It's a real challenge I like that, and offers plenty of hours of replay value but the thing that I hate about is it's really designed for a controller and GSWL drm but besides that I enjoy it. PVP is pretty ♥♥♥♥ing rad, though hard to do at times. It isn't watered down with what exactly to do nothing to hold your hand all the way, though there are hints. Boss battles are amazing, and rewarding once you defeat your first major boss. Can't rush through things all the time, you have to think before you make your next move. Even looking for off the wall areas is a challenge in it's self exploring even the most unlikely places you think there could be something there is a chance something is there. Lacks in lore but I'm willing to look past that because it excels in everything else. Lastly I seem to have not got bored  40 hours in, that's usually a good sign.

*So TLDR? (aka your brain can't read more than a sentences words because your dumber than a inbred redneck)

The main thing is it's a challenge, a great one at that on the level I felt playing games as a kid even greater at times. The port to PC could have been better though. Even if you die thousands of times don't give up the reward of feeling victory is the more so sweet.

reviewText:
Originally, many years ago in a distant land. I had purchased this game for PS3, as its cover (and back of it) had reminded me of 'Monster Hunter FU' for a whopping 70 AUD. Turns out it barely resembled 'Monster Hunter', unless you can call it a dark and medieval variant of it. Aaaanyway, I got the game and got p*ssed off by the first boss (patience wasn't my strong point) and didn't play it for months. Then I came back to it after awhile and passed the first boss quite easily as I had decided to roll between its feet instead of in its attacking range. From then on I was hooked by it. Did a couple play throughs and cursed my way happily through the game.

Then one day I decided I'd buy it for my computer too, I couldn't be bothered loading up the PS3 anymore, so here we are. Since DS1: Prepare To Die Edition on the PS3 I moved onto Dark Souls 2 which was fun, but it was great to play the this one again after a fair while.

This game is fun and addictive, however you can get easily frustrated and p*ssed off by it too. Dark Souls can be a bit vague at times and you'll feel like you have done the same thing for the past eternity if you get stuck...but this game is very much worth buying and playing!

reviewText:
***Spoiler-Free Review***
Dark Souls is by far, the most immersive, addictive, and well-rounded RPG I have played in many years. I recommend true RPG afficionados to play it. That being said here is a brief run-down of the most common quesions I have received from early adopters:

-The Difficulty -
While it is a game that is willing to punish the player, it does not do so unfairly. If you are the kind of player who expects to run headlong into an ambush of 12 undead skeletons and live to tell the tale, this is not the game for you. You gain no special status by being the player, other than your ability to learn. If you like that, you will LOVE this game. If you dislike having to learn how to play a game properly, you will dislike this game. It is that simple. The immense sense of accomplishment you gain from learning more about this game is what keeps players coming back again and again.

- Level Design -
Dark Souls understands something that I think Bethesda has missed with Skyrim, and that is that the immensity of a map does not equate to content. Dark souls is by no means a monster of a game, but the number of things to do and places to explore is quite overwhelming. Every nook and cranny of the game is jam-packed with new characters, invisible walls, diverse weapons, and extensions of the storyline. Another thing that is to be applauded is the masterful connectivity between areas. You may not know where you are until you find a shortcut to some previous area you had been. Learning about these shortcuts makes the map a bit easier to traverse, but also puts on display the genius of the game designers. Everything is connected and makes perfect geographical sense. The use of depth to create distance and elevators to reduce it was a stroke of pure genius. It makes it all the more satisfying to travel to an area using the shortcut you found.

- The Story -
There is as much story in Dark Souls as you want there to be. That is not cryptic language or market-speak either. If you so wish, you can completely ignore the story of Dark Souls and kill everything in the game. For a lore-lover like myself, that would be a travesty. Through dialogue of the NPCs as well as item descriptions, you can gain insight into this deep, rich, and intriguing universe full of betrayals, discovery, wonder, and of course darkness. Many of the NPCs who aid you in battle have motivations, hopes, and backstories of their own which give them reasons to help you along in your quest. Discovering these relationships and motivations is part of Dark Souls' charm.

- The Combat -
Dark Souls uses a very deceptively simple combat system. Without going into too much detail, melee combat consists of timed attacks and blocking as well as some critical attacks, while the various magics are mediated through their respective wands". When you kill enemies
recommended: the world's currency. These can be used for leveling up
hoursPlayed: buying items at vendors
voteText: or improving items at blacksmiths. Dark Souls rewards players greatly for specializing early
helpfulPercent: but does not punish those who choose to spread their experience points around. Upgrading weapons and armor encourages you to try many different configurations to find the one that suits you as well as the different enemies you are fighting. For example
votesHelpful: you may want to have high fire-resistance for a dragon fight
votesTotal: if you intend to take the flames head on. Another major factor is that Dark Souls contains dynamic weight for your character. Want to wear 120 lbs of armor? That's fine
votesFunny:
but you will have to accept that your character is going to move around like a sloth until they are strong enough to move around in it comfortably. All of these factors combined make battles in Dark Souls different every time you play them.

- The Bottom Line -
So is Dark Souls good? I would go beyond saying Dark Souls is good. It is masterfully simple

reviewText:
First: yes, the port isn't really good. It's pretty much a straight port from Xbox 360 without much work done to accommodate the game for the PC.
Second: modders fixed the greatest problems with it, which makes this game far more enjoyable.

You are the Chosen One. Destined to save the world. You know, like always.
The twist? You are undead. Dying isn't something you need to be really afraid of. You actually shouldn't be afraid of dying, because you will die. A lot.

It's a tough game. Even your standard enemies might pose a threat to you.
And then come the bosses. Not only can they be quite big and hit REALLY hard, simple attacking them won't do you any good.
Learn their attack patterns. Learn when to strike. And after you've learned, die a lot and try again until you get it.

Afraid to face the bosses alone? Try jolly co-operation!
Turn into a human at a bonfire, summon a player and try to tackle the boss together!
But beware of invaders!
As soon as you turn human, other players can invade and attack you. And believe me, they will.
You also may find some messages left by other players; warning you of great danger, pointing you to amazing chests or tell you to roll down a cliff (don't do that).
Be aware that there might be cheaters around, so if you wanna be save from other players, stay undead, but keep in mind that you won't be able to do co-op that way.

The story may not be the greatest, but the lore is quite extensive, albeit mostly hidden behind conversations (with some really messed up people) and item descriptions. You want to know something about the world you're in? You'll need to work for it.
This also isn't your typical medival fantasy world. There are no populated towns or cities filled with NPCs, shops and quests. It's a post-apocalyptic world, where death and destruction reign supreme.
You will encounter the odd friendly NPC here and there, but don't ♥♥♥♥ them off or they will try to kill you. Again and again.

Beat the game without breaking a sweat? Try New Game+! Done that? Try New Game++! And that gets one for a while.

Imo an absolutely fantastic game with a great art direction and lots of challenges to conquer.
I'm really glad this game came to the PC. And it did so because of a petition! Isn't that amazing? How often does something like that work?

In this regard: Praise the Sun and prepare to die! A lot.

reviewText:
THE PROS:
Dark souls is known for its difficulty, its teeth grinding, controller breaking difficulty. But to me it is much, much more. Dark souls is a game that takes years to master, and has been part of my gaming history for years and I cant stop coming back to it. The game has the most depth in its lore I have ever seen and I am doubtful I will see a more complex story then this one. There is a story behind every room, item, and character, and quite frankly I am in love with it. The way the story is told is just fantastic. You are dropped in a universe you know nothing about, right at the beginning you can go one way with enemies that are suitable for a new player, or you could take the wrong turn down a dark shadowy path to a group of enemies that one shot you. Thats what I love, you see something too hard for you, progress in another area only to come back and best that enemy. It is insanely satisfying. I love the fact that while progressing at any time you can be invaded by another player who will utterly destroy you. It adds so much unpredicatability to the game that you are on the edge of your seat when you see that invasion notification. The pvp is also insanely in depth and has many different ways to play it. Not only this but I have never seen such a strong community. Players are always sharing stories and things they find in the world. With a wide range of fan art, it shows the true appreciation the players have for the art style of the game and themes the game holds.
THE CONS:
The only cons I can find in this game is the port. To be blunt about it, the game was literally copy and pasted from the xbox 360 version. That being said you need to use mods online to fix up the game to be playable if you are not using a controller.

reviewText:
If you want more reviews for TV shows, movies, games across all platforms, and more, come check out my blog!
http://gandhigaming.wordpress.com/

Also, be sure to use this link below if you do purchase this game, otherwise it WILL NOT work.
http://steamcommunity.com/app/211420/discussions/0/864980153227392683/
Thanks to my friend Shadow for sending me this link before I purchased this game!

To be honest, I meant to do this review earlier because it would take too long for me to beat the game, as the average playthrough is about 60 hours long. To add on to that, my crave to review games is pretty hard to contain. So, here's my review of Dark Souls, arguably the best RPG of last gen to many.

Dark Souls has been highly praised by gamers and critics and was a solid GOTY contender, but it was overshadowed by Skyrim, which got all the attention. It's true, I am a Skyrim fanboy and I love everything to it, but this game still deserved a lot more recognition than it got. Plus, now that I got a handy Xbox 360 wireless controller, I wanted this game bad. However, I still was worrried due to GFWL ruining my experience. Thanks to one of my awesome friends though, he gave me a link that would fix that annoying problem. But, I don't want to provide negatives because of GFWL and all of that, Enough of my nonsense, to the review!

Graphics
The visuals look outstanding yet bland at the same time, depending on how you look at it. The world of Lordran is beautiful about 70% of the time, while the 30% is the more dull part of the game. The dull parts of the game though are harder to explain, and half the time you won't even realize the bad parts to the visuals. The atmosphere is thrilling, dark, and epic. Not much to say for the visuals, heck, even the character models aren't too bad, but there's nothing too great about it.

Gameplay
The gameplay is easily the strong point to the game, no doubt. Everyone says the game is hard, and that's certainly true, but when someone describes the gameplay to Dark Souls, they always just say Wow
date: this game is HARD! Did I also mention it's hard?" and whatnot. I'll give you an unbiased non-hard mentioning gameplay review here. The combat is smooth and actually pretty realistic. Your supplies are actually LIMITED for once
recommended: and also the combat is nice and slow because you aren't some kind of MGR Raiden or DMC Dante. You're a regular warrior/sorcerer/knight/pyromancer/whatever else there is. And plus your stamina actually is important unlike other games. Because of the realism in the combat
hoursPlayed: this game can be very slow at times. Therefore
voteText: Dark Souls is for the most patient of gamers. They don't mind repeating the same part over and over again while discovering new ways to get to the next point in the game. The successful realism and well paced gameplay makes Dark Souls have some of the best Action-RPG gameplay seen in years. Phew
helpfulPercent: check it out
votesHelpful:
no mentioning of the difficulty! Woohoo!

Story
The story may seem vague at first
votesTotal: but then you realize it's basically a puzzle- find the pieces and put them together to make one big picture. It isn't straightforward at all. It wants you to talk to the NPCs and all of that
votesFunny: which makes Dark Souls pretty heavy in lore when you know where to look. You're no god or some kind of super prophecized legend or anything (although in a way you are) and yet Dark Souls successfully does that. The story is what most dark fantasy games should have. There's also Solaire of Astora (Praise the Sun!) on the "bright" side of things and he is known to be a very enjoyable character in the game. I also made a song I'm still working on
commentsCount:
but let's not get off topic.

Audio
Dark Souls' audio is among the best I've seen when it comes to sound effects. Again
column16: Dark Souls successfully captures some of the realism intended into the game. The knight
column17: more specifically
column18: sounds amazing with the sound effects instead of listening to the normal quiet footsteps even the most armored of people have in other games. As for the voice acting

column20: a major pro to a game that's trying to have a dark theme to it. And for the music

column23: you know you're in big trouble or you're in a safe place. The soundtrack actually is a guide in this game
column24:
providing signals to you when traveling throughout Lordran.

Replayability
The replayability is pretty strong I hear. Like I said

the people who stay to enjoy this game get an easy 120 hours.

Verdict
In the end
column28: Dark Souls is an outstanding RPG no one should miss
column29: given you don't mind a challenge. Dark Souls is what dark fantasy games should be like. The atmosphere is perfect

column31: and the gameplay smooth. In fact

column37:
dark adventure other Action-RPGs should be looking at.

Story- 8.5/10
Audio- 9.5/10

.:9.1/10:.
+Smooth gameplay
+Strategically placed lore
+Amazing sound effects
+Brilliant atmosphere (No game has been that good with atmosphere since Bioshock)
+Lots of realism for a fantasy game
+Solid replayability
-Mediocre to above average visuals"

reviewText:
Dark Souls is, to put it briefly, a masterpiece with minor flaws.

It's an incredible game, with an entrancing setting that can be both beautiful and haunting.
As you guessed from the title, it is very dark, in terms of both setting and themes. However, it's not pitch black. There's always some hope, or some beauty, or some light that keeps this game from being nothing more than a depressing march from start to finish. The game feels more like 'Purgatory' than 'Hell', if that makes sense. Hope is frail in Dark Souls, but this game will never leave you feeling completely hopeless. There is ALWAYS a way.

Finally, the big question everyone asks: Difficulty?
Honestly, Dark Souls is not the brutally difficult game everyone tells you it is. Aside from two or three actually tough bosses, Dark Souls is only as hard as you allow it to be, as cliched as that sounds. If you appreciate learning, can think laterally and can adapt to meet changing situations, Dark Souls is a very enjoyable challenge. If you allow yourself to get easily frustrated, insist on blindly rushing things, and stubbornly refuse to change tactics if required, the game will punish you, and rightly so, because you're stupid. There is no one-size-fits-all" plan. Dark Souls doesn't punish "unskilled" people
